abroad]] [[Category:Pakistani people imprisoned on charges of terrorism]] [[Category:People associated with the 2008 Mumbai attacks]] [[Category:Executed Pakistani people]] [[Category:People from Okara District]] [[Category:Punjabi people]] [[Category:People executed for murder]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by India]] [[Category:People executed by India by hanging]] [[Category:People executed by hanging]]

revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/2.122.14.27|2.122.14.27]] ([[User talk:2.122.14.27|talk]]): Needs a source. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} The '''Ashya King case''' concerns a boy with a [[brain tumour]] named Ashya King, whose parents, Brett and Naghemeh King, took their son out of [[Southampton General Hospital]] (England) in August 2014 over a disagreement with doctors regarding his treatment.<ref name=bbc>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-32013634 | title=Brain tumour boy Ashya King free of cancer, parents say | work=[[BBC News]] | date=23 March 2015 | accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref>
King had a [[medulloblastoma]], which was successfully removed through surgery on 24 July 2014. He received further neurosurgery on 22 August.<ref name=bbc/>
King's parents desired their son be treated with [[proton therapy]], which they felt was less harmful than conventional [[radiotherapy]].<ref name=bmj>{{cite journal|last1=O'Brien|first1=A.|last2=Sokol|first2=D. K.|title=Lessons from the Ashya King case|journal=[[British Medical Journal]]|date=10 September 2014|page=g5563|doi=10.1136/bmj.g5563|subscription=yes}}</ref> At that time the [[National Health Service]] (NHS) did not provide proton therapy in the United Kingdom, however it has funded treatment abroad since April 2008 where evidence has shown there to be benefit.<ref name=nhsengland>{{cite web | url=https://www.england.nhs.uk/commissioning/spec-services/highly-spec-services/pbt/ | title ='NHS England: NHS Commissioning: Highly Specialised Services: Proton beam therapy'| accessdate=14 March 2017}}</ref> In this case the doctors did not support moving the boy so that he could get proton therapy, and in response, on 28 August 2014, the parents took their son out of the hospital without telling the medical team and boarded a ferry to [[France]].<ref name=bmj/>
On 28 August 2014, an international manhunt for King and his parents commenced.<ref name=cbc>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/ashya-king-s-father-says-u-k-boy-cancer-free-after-prague-treatment-that-led-to-manhunt-1.3005156 | title=Ashya King's father says U.K. boy cancer-free after Prague treatment that led to manhunt | work=[[CBC News]] | date=23 March 2015 | accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> On 30 August, King and his parents were found in [[Velez Malaga]], [[Spain]]. King's parents were arrested and their son was sent to a local hospital for urgent treatment.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/31/ashya-king-found-spain-parents-arrested | title=Parents arrested as missing Ashya King found by police in Spain | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=30 August 2014 | accessdate=23 March 2015 | last=Khomami|first=Nadia}}</ref> They were held in prison for more than 24 hours and released when the request to extradite them to the United Kingdom was withdrawn.<ref name=bbc/><ref>[https://www.judiciary.gov.uk/judgments/judgment-and-family-court-orders-in-the-matter-of-ashya-king/ ''Judgment and Family Court Orders in the matter of Ashya King'']</ref>
The issues about treating the boy were brought to the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] to be resolved, and on 5 September 2014, the court ruled that King could receive proton therapy in [[Prague]].<ref name=guardian/> Doctors from Southampton General Hospital said the treatment would have the same side effects as conventional radiotherapy.<ref name=guardian/> On 9 September, King arrived at the Proton Therapy Center in Prague, where he underwent proton beam therapy.<ref name=bbc/><ref name=cbc/>
In March 2015, Brett King said that a brain scan showed no evidence that Ashya had a brain tumour.<ref name=bbc/><ref>{{cite news | accessdate= 29 July 2017 | url = https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/ashya-king-is-cancer-free-9813409 | title = Ashya King 'is cancer free and back at school' says dad three years after brain tumour treatment row | date = 14 February 2017| work = Mirror}}</ref>
A 2015 report reviewing the case stated that King's parents' decision to deny their child chemotherapy had reduced his chances of survival by 30 percent.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/nhs/11749505/Ashya-Kings-parents-reduced-his-survival-chances-by-30-per-cent-report-reveals.html | title=Ashya King's parents hit back at report which claims they 'reduced his survival chances by 30 per cent' | work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | date=19 July 2015 | accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> Reviews also called on health providers to do a better job communicating with parents.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-34338007 | title=Ashya King's removal from hospital 'put him at risk', report finds | work=[[BBC News]] | date=23 September 2015 | accessdate=30 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/sep/24/parents-ashya-king-put-him-risk-report-says | title=Parents of Ashya King put him at risk, report says | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=24 September 2015 | accessdate=30 January 2016 | last=Cowburn|first=Ashley}}</ref>
In 2016, following the publication of a prospective phase II trial<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yock|first1=T. et al.| title=Long-term toxic effects of proton radiotherapy for paediatric medulloblastoma: a phase 2 single-arm study. |date=29 January 2016| journal=[[The Lancet Oncology]]|volume=17|issue=3|page=287|subscription=yes}}</ref> the NHS decided it will pay for children with medulloblastoma to travel abroad to receive proton therapy.<ref name=nhs>{{cite news | url=http://www.nhs.uk/news/2016/02February/Pages/Proton-beam-therapy-effective-and-causes-fewer-side-effects.aspx | title=Proton beam therapy 'effective' and 'causes fewer side effects' |work=[[NHS]]|date=1 February 2016| accessdate=14 March 2017}}</ref><ref name=guardian>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/sep/05/ashya-king-prague-proton-beam-therapy-court-ruling | title=Ashya King given legal go-ahead for cancer treatment in Prague | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=5 September 2014 | accessdate=23 March 2015 | last=Boseley|first=Sarah}}</ref>
In 2018 and MRI scans, conducted in Southampton, showed Ashya to be free of cancer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/03/03/ashya-king-cleared-cancer-three-years-parents-abducted-hospital/|title=Ashya King cleared of cancer three years after his parents abducted him from hospital for treatment abroad|last=Adams|first=Joel|date=2018-03-03|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-04-29|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:King, Ashya}} [[Category:Cancer in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2014 controversies]] [[Category:Medical controversies in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Cancer survivors]] [[Category:2014 in England]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = At the End of the Day: The Sue Rodriguez Story | image = | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Sheldon Larry]] | producer = [[Laszlo Barna]] | writer = novel [[Lisa Hobbs Birnie]]
[[Sue Rodriguez]]
screenplay [[Linda Svendsen]] | narrator = | starring = [[Wendy Crewson]]
[[Carl Marotte]] | music = [[Mychael Danna]]
[[Andrew Lockington]] | cinematography = [[Albert J. Dunk]] | editing = Stephen Lawrence | studio = Atlantic Mediaworks | distributor = [[Alliance Atlantis]] Communications | released = 23 February 2007 ([[UK]]) | runtime = | country = Canada | language = English | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''At the End of the Day: The Sue Rodriguez Story''''' is a 1998 [[Television in Canada|Canadian]] [[television film]] about the life of Canadian [[right to die]] [[advocate]] [[Sue Rodriguez]]. The film was written by [[Linda Svendsen]] based on the book by [[Lisa Hobbs Birnie]], and directed by Sheldon Larry. ==Cast== {{Cast listing| * [[Wendy Crewson]] as [[Sue Rodriguez]] * [[Carl Marotte]] as David Rodriguez * [[Patrick Galligan]] as [[Svend Robinson]] * [[Walter Learning]] as Justice Allen Melvin * [[Al Waxman]] as John Hofsess * [[Miko Hughes]] as Jesse Rodriguez * [[Fiona Reid]] as Sandra Burtch }} Politician [[Svend Robinson]] was portrayed by a different actor, but also had his own cameo role in the film as the third reporter at Sue Rodriguez's first press conference. ==Awards== *In 1999 Wendy Crewson won the ''Best Performance by an Actress in a Leading Role in a Dramatic Program or Mini-Series'' at the [[Gemini Awards]] *In 1999 Linda Svendsen won the ''WGC Award'' from the [[Writers Guild of Canada]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0174475|title=At the End of the Day: The Sue Rodriguez Story}} * {{Amg movie|412808}} {{DEFAULTSORT:At The End Of The Day The Sue Rodriguez Story}} [[Category:1998 films]] [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Canadian television films]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:1990s drama films]] [[Category:Canadian drama films]] {{1990s-Canada-film-stub}} {{tv-drama-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox civil conflict | title = Belgrade anti-gay riot | partof = | image = Image:Flickr - boellstiftung - Ausschreitungen in Serbien gegen die Gay Pride.jpg | caption = Clashes between [[Gendarmery (Serbia)|Žandarmerija]] (Serbian [[Gendarmerie]]) and anti-gay rioters | date = 10 October 2010 | place = [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]] | coordinates = | causes = Attempt to hold [[Pride parade]] | goals = | methods = Rioting, assault, arson | status = | result = | side1 = '''Anti-gay pride and anti-government protesters''' *[[Supporters' groups|Football supporters]] and [[Ultras]] **[[Delije]] **[[Grobari]] **[[FK_Rad#Supporters_&_Rivalries|United Force]] ''and others'' *[[Serbian nationalism|Nationalists]] ---- '''Anti-gay pride nonviolent protesters''' * [[Serbian Orthodox Church]] | side2 = [[File:Vlada Srbije logo.png|25px]] '''[[Cabinet of Mirko Cvetković|Government of Serbia]]''' * [[Gendarmery (Serbia)|Gendarmery]] '''Gay pride protesters''' | leadfigures1 = | leadfigures2 = | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | fatalities = | injuries = 95 | arrests = 101 | detentions = | charged = | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = | sidebox = }} The '''Belgrade anti-gay riot''' was an incident of [[violence against LGBT people]] that occurred on 10 October 2010 during a [[pride parade]], organized to promote [[LGBT rights in Serbia]]. The gay pride parade has been the first in [[Belgrade]] since 2001;<ref name="Mark Lowen" /> a planned parade in 2009 was cancelled due to the threat of violence.<ref name="Mark Lowen" />
Anti-gay and anti-government protesters fought with about 5,000 armed police,<ref name="ALEKSANDAR VASOVIC">{{cite news | last= VASOVIC | first= ALEKSANDAR | url= http://www.torontosun.com/news/world/2010/10/10/15645861.html | title= Anti-gay riots rock Belgrade | publisher= [[Toronto Sun]] | date= 10 October 2010 | accessdate= }}</ref> throwing [[Molotov cocktail]]s, bricks, stones, glass bottles and [[firecracker]]s;<ref name="JOVANA GEC">{{cite news | last= GEC | first= JOVANA | url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/europe/protesters-hurl-molotov-cocktails-injure-100-at-serbian-gay-pride-march/article1751569/ | title= Protesters hurl Molotov cocktails, injure 100 at Serbian gay-pride march | publisher= [[The Globe and Mail]] | date= 10 October 2010 | accessdate= }}</ref> the police used [[tear gas]] and [[rubber bullet]]s.<ref name="Mark Lowen">{{cite news | last= Lowen | first= Mark | url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11507253 | title= Scores arrested in Belgrade after anti-gay riot | publisher= [[BBC News]] | date= 10 October 2010 | accessdate= }}</ref> There were no fatalities.<ref name="Mark Lowen" />
==Results== [[Image:Flickr - boellstiftung - Ausschreitungen in Serbien gegen die Gay Pride (6).jpg|thumb|right|280px|Clashes between [[Gendarmery (Serbia)|Žandarmerija]] (Serbian [[Gendarmerie]]) and anti-gay rioters]] Police said that 78 police officers and 17 civilians had been injured,<ref name="JOVANA GEC" /> and 101 people had been detained for violent behaviour.<ref name="JOVANA GEC" /> The garage of the building of the ruling pro-[[western countries|western]] [[Democratic Party (Serbia)|Democratic Party]] was set ablaze, and state TV building and the headquarters of other political parties were also damaged.<ref name="Dozens hurt">{{cite news | url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/oct/10/serbia-police-rioters-gay-pride | title= Serbia police clash with far-right rioters at gay pride march | publisher= [[guardian.co.uk]]/[[Associated Press]] | date= 10 October 2010 | accessdate= | location=London}}</ref> The parade was viewed as a test for the [[government of Serbia]], which has stated it will protect [[human rights in Serbia]] as it seeks to [[Accession of Serbia to the European Union|become an EU member]].<ref name="Dozens hurt" /> [[Jelko Kacin]], presiding over the [[European Union]]'s evaluation of Serbia, said that Serbia's failure to stop the riot could damage its bid to join the EU.<ref name="DUSAN STOJANOVIC" /> During a visit to Belgrade two days after the riot, US secretary of state, [[Hillary Clinton]], praised the Serbian government for protecting the human rights of the parade participants.<ref name="DUSAN STOJANOVIC">{{cite news|last=STOJANOVIC|first=DUSAN|title=Official: Anti-gay riots send wrong message to EU|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39617475/ns/world_news-europe|accessdate=19 November 2010|newspaper=MSNBC|date=11 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/10/11/AR2010101105047_2.html?sid=ST2010101105224 | work=The Washington Post | title=Clinton praises Serbia's progress, new leaders | date=12 October 2010}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|LGBT|Human rights|Serbia}} *[[LGBT rights in Serbia]] *[[2010 in LGBT rights]]
==References== {{Reflist|36em}} {{Commons category|position=left|Gay Pride in Serbia}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox company | logo = Boo-com.png | type = [[Naamloze Vennootschap|Dutch NV]]
(Disestablished in 2000) | defunct = {{end date|2000}} | key_people = Ernst Malmsten
Kajsa Leander
Patrik Hedelin | industry = [[retail]] | products = [[clothing]], [[cosmetics]] | foundation = {{start date and age|1999|3|17|df=y}}{{cite web|url=http://whois.domaintools.com/boo.com|title=Boo.com WHOIS, DNS, & Domain Info - DomainTools|work=[[WHOIS]]|date= |accessdate=2016-08-05}} | location = [[London]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom|U.K.]] | homepage = [https://web.archive.org/*/http://www.boo.com Boo.com] (Domain Now owned by Hostelworld) }} '''Boo.com''' was a short-lived, British [[Internet]] company, founded in 1998 by [[Swedes]] [[Ernst Malmsten]], [[Kajsa Leander]] and [[Patrik Hedelin]], who were regarded as sophisticated Internet entrepreneurs in Europe by the investors because they had created an online bookstore named [[Bokus.com]], the third largest book e-retailer (in 1997), before founding the new business '''Boo.com'''. {{cite book|last1=Chaffey|first1=Dave|last2=Ellis-Chadwick|first2=Fiona|title=Digital Marketing Strategy, Implementation and Practice|date=2016|publisher=Pearson Education Limited|location=Harlow|isbn=978-1-292-07761-1|page=108|edition=sixth}}{{cite web|last1=Wray|first1=Richard|title=Boo.com spent fast and died young but its legacy shaped internet retailing|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2005/may/16/media.business|website=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited or its affiliated companies|accessdate=10 March 2018}} After several highly publicized delays, Boo.com launched in the autumn of 1999 selling branded fashion apparel over the [[Internet]]. The company spent $135 million of [[venture capital]] in just 18 months,{{cite book|title=Boo Hoo: A dot.com Story from Concept to Catastrophe|last1=Malmsten|first1=Ernst|publisher=Random House Business Books|year=2001|isbn=978-0-7126-7239-9}} and it was placed into [[receivership]] on 18 May 2000 and [[liquidated]]. In June 2008, [[CNET]] hailed Boo.com as one of the greatest dot-com busts in history.{{cite web|url=http://crave.cnet.co.uk/gadgets/the-greatest-defunct-web-sites-and-dotcom-disasters-49296926/|title=The greatest defunct Web sites and dotcom disasters|publisher=[[CNET]]|date=5 June 2008|accessdate=2008-06-05}} Ernst Malmsten wrote about the experience in a book called ''Boo Hoo: A dot.com Story from Concept to Catastrophe'', published in 2001. ==Marketing plan== ===Company vision=== The vision of Boo.com was to become the first largest online sports e-retailer around the world and not just as a European brand. It planned to set up stores in both Europe and America simultaneously.{{cite book|last1=Chaffey|first1=Dave|last2=Ellis-Chadwick|first2=Fiona|title=Digital Marketing Strategy, Implementation and Practice|date=2016|publisher=Pearson Education Limited|location=Harlow|isbn=978-1-292-07761-1|page=108|edition=sixth}} ===Brand name=== The brand name was initially suggested as Bo.com, which was inspired by the actor [[Bo Derek]]. The final domain name, Boo.com, was bought for $2500 from a dealer as the domain Bo.com was already in use.{{cite book|last1=Malmsten|first1=Ernst|last2=Portanger|first2=Erik|last3=Drazin|first3=Charles|title=Boo Hoo. A Dot.Com Story from Concept of Catastrophe|date=2001|publisher=Random House|location=London}} ===Strategy=== The target customers of Boo.com were young, wealthy and fashionable people between 18 to 24 years old, who were expected to be attracted by sports and fashion brands offered by Boo.com.{{cite book|last1=Chaffey|first1=Dave|last2=Ellis-Chadwick|first2=Fiona|title=Digital Marketing Strategy, Implementation and Practice|date=2016|publisher=Pearson Education Limited|location=Harlow|isbn=978-1-292-07761-1|page=108|edition=sixth}} Boo.com created a virtual shopping assistant, Miss Boo, to assist customers with tips given at each step. Boo.com also developed technology that allowed online customers to put their chosen products onto 3D models and then inspect the result.{{cite book|last1=Chaffey|first1=Dave|last2=Ellis-Chadwick|first2=Fiona|title=Digital Marketing Strategy, Implementation and Practice|date=2016|publisher=Pearson Education Limited|location=Harlow|isbn=978-1-292-07761-1|page=109|edition=sixth}} ==Headquarters and relaunch== The company had its headquarters along [[Carnaby Street]] in [[London]] in a building which it initially shared with the ''Erotic Review Magazine''.Wray, Richard. "[https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2005/may/16/media.business Boo.com spent fast and died young but its legacy shaped internet retailing]." ''[[The Guardian]]''. 16 May 2005. Retrieved on 12 March 2012. The company initially had 40 employees.Sorkin, Andrew Ross. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2000/05/19/business/international-business-boocom-online-fashion-retailer-goes-out-of-business.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Boo.com, Online Fashion Retailer, Goes Out of Business]." ''[[The New York Times]]''. 19 May 2000. Retrieved on 12 March 2012. In October 1999, it had a total of eight offices and 400 employees in [[Amsterdam]], [[Munich]], [[New York City]], [[Paris]], and [[Stockholm]]. It relaunched in the autumn of 2000 with Kate Buggeln, an ex-[[Bloomingdale's]] salesperson and Internet consultant, appointed as president. She told ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'' that they were working to "expand beyond the portal business model into Boo products and Boo licensing."Seckler, Valerie, "Boo Names New Boss: Kate Buggelin," WWD, Mon. 17 July 2000, p.14 == Reasons for failure == ===Timing=== Although there were several months of delays prior to launch and problems with the user experience when boo.com first launched, these had been largely fixed by the time the company entered receivership. Sales had grown rapidly and were around $500,000 for the fortnight prior to the site being shut down. The fundamental problem was that the company was following an extremely aggressive growth plan, launching simultaneously in multiple European countries. This plan was founded on the assumption of the ready availability of venture capital money to see the company through the first few years of trading until sales caught up with operating expenses. Such capital ceased to be available for all practical purposes in the second quarter of 2000 following dramatic falls in the NASDAQ presaging the "dot crash" following the [[Dot-com bubble]]. Boo was one of numerous similar [[Dot-com company]] failures over the subsequent two years. One Boo.com manager acknowledges that the company's failure is that global marketing and advertising costs too much, and that managers and technology invest too little. It spent 135 million of its investment in 2 years.{{cite web|title=Boocom公司为何倒闭|url=http://www.docin.com/p-845376311.html}} ===Problems with the user experience=== [[File:Boo Homepage.jpg|thumb|right|The Boo.com Homepage as it appeared in May 2000.]] The boo.com website was widely criticized as poorly designed for its target audience, going against many [[usability]] conventions.http://www.bohmann.dk/articles/usability_reviews/boo_com.html The site relied heavily on [[JavaScript]] and [[Adobe Flash|Flash]] technology to display [[pseudo-3D]] views of wares as well as Miss Boo, a sales-assistant-style [[avatar (computing)|avatar]]. The first publicly released version of the site included many large pages; the home page, for example, was several hundred kilobytes which meant that many users had to wait minutes for the site to load, as [[broadband]] technologies were not widely available at the time. The site's front page contained the warning, "this site is designed for 56K modems and above". The complicated design required the site to be displayed in a fixed-size window, which limited the space available to display product information to the customer. Navigation techniques changed as the customer moved around the site. The site's interface was complex and included a hierarchical system that required the user to answer four or five different questions before sometimes revealing that there were no products in stock in a particular sub-section. The same basic questions then had to be answered again until results were found. ===Problems with the management=== Boo.com management team can not provide answers of the goal of the website visitors, the conversion percentage, each customer's minimum spend and their purchase cost to one of their going-to-be investor [[Pequot Capital]] before launching, and the founder planned to release it with thousands of tasks that some of them need to be done by employees who had not been recruited. ===Problems with the supply channels=== At the beginning, it was difficult to become a [[distribution channel]] of prestigious sports and leisure brands as they have already have their own distribution network with [[high street]] and small retailers. These brands also concerned that their brands values would be negatively influenced when their products were sold cheaper on Boo.com or with different price in different countries. ===Excessive expenditure on marketing activities=== $135 million of marketing investment was used by Boo.com within 18 months in order to set up a worldwide online sport and fashion brands retailer in a short amount of time. Some of the investments are shown below.{{cite web|last1=Roggio|first1=Armando|title=2 Ecommerce Blunders to Avoid in 2015|url=https://www.practicalecommerce.com/2-Ecommerce-Blunders-to-Avoid-in-2015|website=Practical Ecommerce|publisher=Practical Ecommerce|accessdate=6 March 2018}} 1. To attract consumers to shop on Boo.com, it developed a brand new [[Internet virtual technology]] with which consumers could drag their intended clothes on the virtual 3D body model and then view it from whatever angles and distance they wanted. The investment in this technology cost Boo.com over $6 million to develop and $0.5 million every month to maintain. 2. Hundreds of staff in many countries were employed and paid for local marketing in order to set up a global brand at the beginning. 3. Boo.com spent $25 million on [[advertising]] and [[public relations]] marketing before it opened and sold products. A manager of Boo.com admitted that the failure of the company is also that the global marketing and advertising expenses were too large, and the technology investment was too small. It consumed 135 million of its investment in 2 years. == Burn rate == Boo.com spent £125 million in just six months.{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F05E4DB103CF931A35755C0A9669C8B63 | work=The New York Times | title=INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Fashionmall.com Swoops In for the Boo.com Fire Sale | date=2 June 2000 | accessdate=2010-04-26}} Boo.com's sales did not match expectations, due partly to a higher-than-expected rate of product returns (a service that was offered for free, but charged for by their logistics supplier [[Deutsche Post]]). Poor management and a lack of communication between departments resulted in rapid growth in costs. The effectiveness of an expensive ad campaign was limited because the website was not ready in time, resulting in curious visitors being greeted with a holding page. Staff and contractors were recruited in large numbers, with a lack of direction and executive decision about how many people were required, resulting in high payroll costs. == Aftermath == The biggest loser among boo.com's investors was Omnia, a fund backed by members of [[Lebanon]]'s wealthy [[Rafic Hariri|Hariri family]], which put nearly £20 million into the company. Creditors, most of whom were advertising agencies, were owed around £12 million. Over 400 staff and contractors were made redundant in London and around the world, and many had not been paid for several months. In a widely circulated article,{{cite web|url=http://www.tnl.net/who/bibliography/learned-boo-com//|title=Tristan Louis (TNL.net)|website=Tristan Louis (TNL.net)}} former Interim CTO [[Tristan Louis]] broke down the problems that plagued the company, in one of the first [[Postmortem documentation|post-mortems]] of a technology company posted online. [[Fashionmall.com]], which had been operating since 1994, bought the remains of Boo.com, which included brand, Web address and advertising materials but did not include any physical assets, software or distribution channels. The deal also included the Miss Boo character. Boo's main assets, its software and technology, were sold to [[Dan_Wagner#Bright Station|Bright Station]], a British company run by [[Internet]] entrepreneur [[Dan Wagner]], for $250,000 and served as the basis for [[Venda Inc]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/02/business/international-business-fashionmallcom-swoops-in-for-the-boocom-fire-sale.html|title=INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Fashionmall.com Swoops In for the Boo.com Fire Sale|first=Andrew Ross|last=Sorkin|date=2 June 2000|publisher=|via=query.nytimes.com}} Less than $2 million was earned by selling all Boo's remaining assets.{{cite web|url=http://www.jobfairy.com/articles01/BooAndthe100OtherDumbestM.html|title=jobfairy.com - Boo! And the 100 Other Dumbest Moments in e-Business History|website=www.jobfairy.com}} In 2005 [[CNET]] called Boo.com the sixth greatest dot-com flop.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnet.com/1990-11136_1-6278387-1.html |title=Top 10 dot-com flops |accessdate=2014-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140210101028/http://www.cnet.com/1990-11136_1-6278387-1.html |archivedate=10 February 2014 |df=dmy }} == Current state of the domain == In May 2007 [[Web Reservations International]] (WRI) turned boo.com into a travel site with reviews and listings. When the new site launched, it already had more than one million user reviews which had been collected from existing WRI travel sites.{{cite web|url=http://www.utalkmarketing.com/Article.aspx?id=1895 |title=boo.com in new travel guise |work=utalkmarketing.com |date=2 May 2007 |accessdate=2007-05-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928014939/http://www.utalkmarketing.com/Article.aspx?id=1895 |archivedate=28 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} In October 2010, the new boo.com site announced that it was closing down with effect from 1 November 2010. {{As of|November 2017}} boo.com redirects to hostelworld.com. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Portal|London|Fashion|Internet|1990s}} * [https://web.archive.org/*/http://www.boo.com Boo.com] (Archive) * [http://www.useit.com/alertbox/20000528_boo.html Jakob Nielsen's mini-review of Boo.com] - A design/usability perspective * [http://tnl.net/blog/2000/05/19/boocom-goes-bust/ Boo.com Goes Bust] - An insider's perspective * [https://web.archive.org/web/20010927092825/http://boo.com/ archived version of boo.com] * [http://www.davechaffey.com/E-commerce-Internet-marketing-case-studies/Boo.com-case-study Case study on Boo.com for marketing and business students] {{DEFAULTSORT:Boo.Com}} [[Category:Online clothing retailers]] [[Category:Defunct retail companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Online companies]] [[Category:Retail companies established in 1999]] [[Category:Retail companies disestablished in 2000]] [[Category:Online retailers of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Defunct websites]] [[Category:Defunct online companies]] [[Category:Dot-com bubble]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 1999]] [[Category:Internet properties disestablished in 2000]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Update|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox music festival | name =Breakin' Up Winter | image = | caption = | location = | years_active =1994-present | founders =Nashville Old-Time String Band Association | dates = | genre = [[old-time music]] | attendance = | capacity = | website = }} '''Breakin' Up Winter''' is an old-time music 'retreat', a gathering of old-time string band musicians that began the first weekend of March, 1994. It eschews the contest approach common to the larger festivals. It brings together hundreds of old-time musicians in a state park setting where the first focus is on educational programs and presentations by scholars and icons of the old-time music worlds. And, of course, jamming. It is presented by the Nashville Old-Time String Band Association, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization that began as an offshoot of a community education class in Nashville, Tennessee.
==History== The first Breakin' Up Winter retreat was just that - an informal gathering of friends who shared an interest in and love for old-time string band music. Fresh from another small old-time gathering in Athens, Alabama, they wanted to create that same atmosphere in Middle Tennessee. The first gathering was held in the Cedar Forest Lodge of the Cedars of Lebanon State Park near Lebanon, Tennessee, about 30 miles outside Nashville. The retreat continues at Cedars of Lebanon, but now encompasses the entire state park. Legendary old-time fiddler Charlie Acuff was a guest of honor at that first event and has been a central artist through the years.
==Scholars and Artists== Charlie Acuff was the first in a long line of widely respected "heritage artists" - icons of old-time music - to headline Breakin' Up Winter. There developed a theme for the first day of the event - 'Roots of Old-Time Music' - that brings in noted researchers, authors, and performers.
Noted traditional music researcher/author/folklorist Charles Wolfe was a mainstay until his untimely death in 2006.
Each year, the event begins with scholarly presentations by researchers and authors and demonstrations by musicians with deep roots in the music.
"Participatory music like old-time music involves a great deal of gifting—passing along tunes, playing with others, learning from others, sharing, and coming together for events such as Breakin’ Up Winter to do all of this," writes Jeff Todd Titon, professor of ethnomusicology at Brown University.
In addition to Charlie Acuff and Charles Wolfe, presenters and performers have included: *[[Alan Jabbour]] *Bill Mansfield *Bruce Greene *[[Clyde Davenport]] *Dan Gellert *Don Pedi *Evan Hatch *Franklin George *Gerry Milnes *[[George Gruhn]] *J.P. Fraley *James Bryan *Jim Griffith *John Harrod *Joyce Cauthen *[[Mike Seeger]] *Kerry Blech *Paul Wells *Ralph Blizard *Ron Pen *Will Keys *Walt Haden
== The Focus: Old-time String Band Music == Some call it "mountain music" or "old-timey" or "fiddle tunes." It's the heart of this retreat and the mission of the Nashville Old-Time String Band Association: ". . . to preserve, promote, and perform old-time string band music."
A flurry of interest in "old-time" music in the 1940s, and the folk music revival of the 1960s and 70's, brought millions of new listeners to this traditional music.
But in the hills and hollows of Appalachia and many communities beyond, it didn't need reviving. It remained the music that people learned to play knee-to-knee with musicians who learned it the same way. There remain many players whose introduction to the music came (and still comes) not from radio or recordings, but through family and friends who themselves who were passing it down directly through the generations.
It is to those roots of old-time music that this retreat reaches and which is the focus of the first day of the event.
In 2008, NOTSBA began presenting its Heritage Award to musicians. The first went to Charlie Acuff, the second to Clyde Davenport, the third to Franklin George. The fourth will be presented in 2010 to Lester McCumbers.
==See also== *[[List of old-time music festivals]] *[[List of bluegrass music festivals]]
==References== {{reflist}} ==Old-time String Band Music links== *[http://www.nashvilleoldtime.org Nashville Old-Time String Band Association] *[http://www.fieldrecorder.com Field Recorders Collective] Detailed stories of many old time musicians on the notes page. *[http://www.banjofrailer.com Old-Time Banjo and music of Rural America] *[http://www.oldtimemusic.com/fiddlershof.html Old Time Fiddlers Hall of Fame] *[http://www.mustrad.org.uk/articles/appalach.htm Appalachian Traditional Music: A Short History] *[http://www.oldtimeherald.org Old-Time Herald Magazine] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090321151949/http://www.bubbaguitar.com/index.html Old-Time Music in Portland, Oregon] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110819142421/http://70.154.102.35/~mtsouth/ssblinks.htm Old Time Music Source list] *[http://www.traditionalmusic.co.uk/old-time-music/idxv11s.htm Sheet music, lyrics & midis for 200+ traditional old-time songs]
[[Category:Music festivals in Tennessee]] [[Category:Old-time music festivals]]
