The '''Brooklyn Underground Film Festival''' was an annual showcase of typically low-budget, under-distributed or [[amateur]] videos and [[metavideo]]s. The festival was initially held in DUMBO, Brooklyn and later moved to [[Park Slope, Brooklyn|Park Slope]] neighborhood of Brooklyn, New York. The festival ran from 2002-2007.
The festival also showed the work of emerging non-media artists. The first festival included a large wheat paste mural by the artist known as [[Swoon (artist)|Swoon]].
==History== The festival was founded in 2002 by graduates of [[Pratt Institute]], Josh Koury, [[Myles Kane]], Cris Moris and Gaia Cornwall. It was funded in part by a growing number of local businesses.
The festival ceased operations in 2007.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Evolution of the Underground Film Festival: Changes at NYUFF, CUFF, BUFF... |author=Benjamin Crossley-Marra |url=http://www.indiewire.com/ots/2008/04/the_evolution_o.html |agency= |work=[[IndieWire]] |publisher= |location= |date=April 1, 2008 |accessdate= |quote= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080405202115/http://www.indiewire.com/ots/2008/04/the_evolution_o.html |archivedate=2008-04-05 |deadurl=yes |ref=}}</ref>
== References ==
{{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.brooklynunderground.org/ Official website for the Brooklyn Underground Film Festival] * [http://www.independentfilm.com/festivals/videogalleryfest/2006-brooklyn-underground-film-festival-josh-koury.shtml Watch: Program Director Josh Koury on independentfilm.com]
[[Category:Park Slope]] [[Category:Film festivals in New York City]] [[Category:Underground film festivals]] [[Category:Experimental film festivals]] [[Category:Defunct film festivals]]
{{US-film-festival-stub}}

revision.comment: Dating maintenance tags: {{Use Australian English}}
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox Advertising | name = Dumb Ways to Die | image = Dumb Ways to Die.png | caption = A screenshot from the animated video during the song's final chorus presents Numpty, Hapless, Pillock, Dippy, Dummkopf, Dimwit, Stupe, Lax, Doomed, Numskull, Bungle, Mishap, Dunce, Calamity, Ninny, Botch, Doofus, Stumble, Bonehead and Putz and their resulting deaths. | agency = [[McCann Erickson|McCann Melbourne]] | client = [[Metro Trains Melbourne]] | title = | product = | product2 = | product3 = | year = 2012-present | actor = | actor2 = | actor3 = }} '''Dumb Ways to Die''' is an Australian [[public service announcement]] campaign made by [[Metro Trains Melbourne|Metro Trains]] in [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria, Australia]] to promote railway safety.{{cite video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IJNR2EpS0jw |title=Dumb Ways to Die | format=YouTube |author = DumbWays2Die |date=14 November 2012 }} - official video link The campaign video went [[viral video|viral]] through sharing and [[social media]] starting in November 2012.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/metros-tongueincheek-transport-safety-animated-video-goes-viral-on-social-media-20121118-29kbn.html|title=Metro's tongue-in-cheek transport safety animated video goes viral on social media|publisher=The Age|date=19 November 2012}} ==Campaign== The campaign was devised by advertising agency [[McCann Erickson|McCann Melbourne]]. It appeared in newspapers, local radio and outdoor advertising throughout the Metro Trains network and on [[Tumblr]].{{cite news|url=http://www.australiancreative.com.au/news/mccann-s-dumb-ways-to-die|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121119024033/http://www.australiancreative.com.au/news/mccann-s-dumb-ways-to-die|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 November 2012|title=McCann's dumb ways to die|publisher=Australian Creative|date=19 November 2012}} John Mescall, executive creative director of McCann, said "The aim of this campaign is to engage an audience that really doesn't want to hear any kind of safety message, and we think ''Dumb Ways To Die'' will." McCann estimated that within two weeks, it had generated at least [[AUD|$]]50 million worth of global media value in addition to more than 700 media stories, for "a fraction of the cost of one TV ad". According to Metro Trains, the campaign contributed to a more than 30% reduction in "near-miss" accidents, from 13.29 near-misses per million kilometres in November 2011 – January 2012, to 9.17 near-misses per million kilometres in November 2012 – January 2013.{{cite news |title=No dumb luck: Metro claims safety success|author=Stephen Cauchi |url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/no-dumb-luck-metro-claims-safety-success-20130214-2eelt.html |newspaper=The Age|date=14 February 2013 |accessdate=15 February 2013}} ===Animated video=== The video was animated by Julian Frost and produced by Cinnamon Darvall. It was uploaded to [[YouTube]] on 14 November 2012 and made public two days later. It featured "Numpty, Hapless, Pillock, Dippy, Dummkopf, Dimwit, Stupe, Lax, Clod, Doomed, Numskull, Bungle, Mishap, Dunce, Calamity, Ninny, Botch and Doofus killing themselves in increasingly stupid ways" culminating in the last three characters (Stumble, Bonehead and Putz) being killed by trains due to unsafe behavior. It was viewed 2.5 million times within 48 hours and 4.7 million times within 72 hours. Within two weeks, the video had been viewed 30 million times.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/technology/technology-news/aussie-viral-video-dumb-ways-to-die-lives-on-20121129-2ahm0.html|title=Aussie viral video, 'Dumb Ways to Die', lives on|publisher=The Age|date=29 November 2012}}{{As of|2018|11}}, the video has received over 171 million views.{{cite video|title=Dumb Ways to Die YouTube video|format=YouTube| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IJNR2EpS0jw|accessdate=2 June 2014}} McCann released an "Official [[Karaoke]] Edition" of the video on 26 November 2012.{{cite news|url=http://mumbrella.com.au/viral-hit-dumb-ways-to-die-spawns-karaoke-spin-off-127827|title=Dumb Ways to Die spawns karaoke spin off|publisher=Mumbrella|date=27 November 2012}} ===Song=== The song "Dumb Ways to Die" from the video was written by John Mescall with music by [[Ollie McGill]] from [[The Cat Empire]], who also produced it.{{cite news|url=http://www.3aw.com.au/blogs/3aw-breakfast-blog/dumb-ways-to-die-goes-viral/20121119-29kvr.html|title='Dumb ways to die' goes viral|publisher=3AW|date=19 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029202158/http://www.3aw.com.au/blogs/3aw-breakfast-blog/dumb-ways-to-die-goes-viral/20121119-29kvr.html|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} It was performed by Emily Lubitz, the lead vocalist of [[Tinpan Orange]], with McGill providing backing vocals. The band on the recording consists of Gavin Pearce on Bass, Danny Faruggia on drums and Brett Wood on guitar.{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/cute-dumb-ways-to-die-melbourne-safety-video-becomes-internet-smash/story-e6frf7jo-1226519417846|title=Cute Melbourne safety video Dumb Ways to Die becomes internet smash|publisher=Herald Sun|date=19 November 2012}} It was released on [[iTunes]], attributed to the artist "Tangerine Kitty" (a reference to [[Tinpan Orange]] and [[The Cat Empire]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1481518/australian-dumb-ways-to-die-ad-goes-viral-song-gains-sales |first = William | last = Gruger | title=Australian 'Dumb Ways to Die' Ad Goes Viral, Song Gains Sales | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=10 December 2012 }} The song, with a [[tempo]] of 128 beats per minute, is written in [[C major]] and a [[time signature]] of 4/4.{{cite news|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtd.asp?ppn=MN0127323|title=Tangerine Kitty "Dumb Ways to Die" Sheet Music in C Major (transposable) - Download & Print - SKU: MN0127323|publisher=Musicnotes|date=17 September 2017}} ;Charts {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" |- !scope="col"|Chart (2012–13) !scope="col"|Peak
position |- {{singlechart|Flanders Tip|9|artist=Tangerine Kitty|first=Dumb Ways To Die|rowheader=true|accessdate=3 December 2014}} |- {{singlechart|Dutch100|94|artist=Tangerine Kitty|first=Dumb Ways To Die|rowheader=true|accessdate=3 December 2014}} |- {{singlechart|UKindie|38|date=8 June 2013|rowheader=true|accessdate=3 December 2014}} |} ===Video game=== {{Infobox video game | title = Dumb Ways to Die | collapsible = | state = | image = | caption = | developer = Julian Frost
Samuel Baird | publisher = [[Metro Trains Melbourne]]
PopReach | series = | engine = | platforms = [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] | released = '''iOS'''{{vgrelease|WW|6 May 2013}}'''Android'''{{vgrelease|WW|17 September 2013}} | genre = [[Action game]], [[Puzzle game]] | modes = Single-player }} In May 2013, Metro released a "Dumb Ways to Die" game as an app for [[iOS]] devices.{{cite web|title=Dumb Ways to Die|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/app/dumb-ways-to-die/id639930688?mt=8|work=Apple App Store|accessdate=27 May 2013}}{{cite web|title=Dodge Piranhas and Swat Wasps in new 'Dumb Ways to Die' Game|url=http://creativity-online.com/work/metro-dumb-ways-to-die-game/31616|work=Creativity Online|accessdate=27 May 2013}} The game, developed by Julian Frost and Samuel Baird,{{cite web|last=Frost|first=Julian|title=Dumb Ways to Die Game|url=http://julianfrost.co.nz/things/|work=julianfrost.co.nz|publisher=Julian Frost|accessdate=8 October 2013}} invites players to avoid the dangerous activities engaged in by the various characters featured throughout the campaign.{{cite web|title=Dumb Ways to Die: You have to Keep Them Alive, or Die Hilariously|url=http://appchronicles.com/dumb-ways-to-die-you-have-to-keep-them-alive-or-die-hilariously/|work=App Chronicles|accessdate=27 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130607191846/http://appchronicles.com/dumb-ways-to-die-you-have-to-keep-them-alive-or-die-hilariously/|archivedate=7 June 2013|df=dmy-all}} Within the app, players can also pledge to "not do dumb stuff around trains."{{cite web|last=Nudd|first=Tim|title=Dumb Ways to Die Is Now a Video Game for the iPhone and iPad McCann Australia extends beloved train-safety ad|url=http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/dumb-ways-die-now-video-game-iphone-and-ipad-149625|work=AdWeek|accessdate=27 May 2013}}{{cite web|title=Dumb Ways To Die tops charts with new iPhone + iPad app game via McCann + Barrel Of Donkeys|url=http://www.campaignbrief.com/2013/05/dumb-ways-to-die-tops-charts-w.html|work=Campaign Brief|accessdate=27 May 2013}} The activities include things like getting toast out with a fork and poking a stick at a grizzly bear. An [[Android (operating system)|Android]] version was also eventually released in September 2013.{{cite web|title=Dumb Ways to Die|url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=air.au.com.metro.DumbWaysToDie|work=Google Play Store|accessdate=18 September 2013}} The aim of the game is to earn as many points as possible by avoiding "dying" in one of the activities. Lives can be lost by "dying" in one of the activities. The player has three chances to prevent the characters from dying. A sequel titled "Dumb Ways to Die 2: The Games" was released on November 14, 2014. In the sequel, there are a lot more varieties of challenges in each particular building, and each building has a particular theme. Before a train arrives at a building, the player plays a challenge to counter something related to trains. If successful, bonus points can be earned at the end of the game. There are 8 challenges each in every building. Like the original game, the game's characters do plenty of dangerous and unsafe activities. Lives can be lost by "dying" in one of the activities. The player has three chances to prevent the characters from dying. A second sequel titled "Dumb Ways to Die 3: World Tour" was released on December 21, 2017 and requires the player to collect coins from houses that are fixed up from being initially broken. The houses are fixed by the player playing a new minigame for each area containing those houses. {{clear}} ==Reception== Susie O'Brien in the ''[[Herald Sun]]'' in Melbourne criticised the ad for trivialising serious injuries and being about advertisers' ego rather than effective safety messages.{{cite web | url =http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/opinion/ego-trip-a-dumb-way-to-tackle-rail-safety/story-fn56aaiq-1226523387207 | title = Ego trip a dumb way to tackle rail safety | first = Susie | last = O'Brien | date = 25 November 2012 | work = [[The Herald Sun]] }} Simon Crerar of the ''Herald Sun'' wrote that the song's "catchy chorus was the most arresting hook since [[Psy (entertainer)|PSY]]'s [[Gangnam Style]]." Alice Clarke writing in the ''Herald Sun'' described the video as "adorably morbid" and wrote that Victoria's public transport "broke its long running streak of terrible ads".{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/opinion/how-weve-cornered-market-in-terrible-advertising/story-e6frfhqf-1226523822413|title=How we've cornered the market in terrible advertising|publisher=Herald Sun|date=26 November 2012}} Daisy Dumas of the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' described it as "darkly cute — and irksomely catchy" and the chorus as "instant [[earworm]] material".{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/being-dumb-is-almost-cool-with-surprise-advertising-hit-20121118-29k6z.html|title=Being dumb is almost cool with surprise advertising hit|first=Daisy |last=Dumas| work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=19 November 2012}} Michelle Starr of [[CNET]] described the campaign as the [[Darwin Awards]] meets ''[[The Gashlycrumb Tinies]]'' and the song as "a cutesy indie-pop hit in the style of [[Feist (singer)|Feist]]".{{cite news|first=Michelle | last=Starr | url=http://www.cnet.com.au/metro-trains-psa-details-dumb-ways-to-die-339342487.htm|title=Metro Trains PSA details dumb ways to die|publisher=CNET|date=19 November 2012}} Logan Booker of [[Gizmodo]] described it as "taking a page out of the ''[[Happy Tree Friends]]'' book and mixing cute with horrifying".{{cite news|first=Logan |last=Booker|url=http://www.gizmodo.com.au/2012/11/adorable-yet-horrifying-metro-trains-safety-video-quietly-becomes-a-youtube-hit/|title=Adorable, Yet Horrifying Metro Trains Safety Video Quietly Becomes A YouTube Sensation|publisher=Gizmodo|date=19 November 2012}} Karen Stocks of YouTube Australia said the video was unusual due to the high number of views from mobile devices.{{cite news|first=Karen |last=Stocks|url=http://mumbrella.com.au/dumb-ways-to-die-the-most-viral-australian-brand-video-of-all-time-126244|title=Mobile devices help ‘Dumb ways to die’ become the fastest spreading Australian viral brand video of all time|publisher=mUmBRELLA|date=19 November 2012}} Stocks attributed the success to "A snappy headline. A catchy tune that gets stuck in your head. And a message that is easy to understand and perfectly targeted." The ''[[Sunshine Coast Daily]]'' described it as "the Gangnam Style of train safety campaigns".{{cite news|url=http://www.sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/news/dumb-ways-die-video-gangam-style-train-safety/1628930/|title=Dumb ways to die video the Gangam Style of train safety|publisher=Sunshine Coast Daily|date=20 November 2012}} Arlene Paredes of the ''[[International Business Times]]'' said the video was "brilliant in getting viewers' attention" and "arguably one of the cutest [[Public service announcement|PSA]]s ever made."{{cite news|url=http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/406599/20121120/viral-video-8m-views-dumb-ways-die.htm|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130125192855/http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/406599/20121120/viral-video-8m-views-dumb-ways-die.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=25 January 2013|title=Viral Video with 8M Views: "Dumb Ways to Die" Melbourne Metro Ad - Cute, Twisted, Brilliant|publisher=International Business Times|date=5 January 2013}} ===Effectiveness and unwanted repercussions=== The campaign received some criticism on the basis that suicide is one of the most influential causes of rail trauma, and the ad reinforces deadly trains as a possible suicide method.[http://www.safetyrisk.com.au/dumb-ways-to-die-and-a-strange-sense-of-success/ Dumb Ways To Die – A Strange Sense of Success] Retrieved 16 July 2013 Writing in [[Mumbrella]] in February 2013, a former employee of Victoria's Department of Infrastructure advised [[critical thinking]] when evaluating claims made regarding improvements to safety. Reference was made specifically to the claimed 20 percent reduction in risky behavior as being "[[social media]] bullshit".{{cite news | url=http://mumbrella.com.au/dumb-ways-to-die-and-social-media-bullshit-138887 | title=Dumb Ways To Die and social media bullshit | work=Mumbrella | author = Karalee Evans | date=11 February 2013 | accessdate=9 November 2013}} ===Censorship in Russia=== In February 2013, [[Artemy Lebedev]]'s [[blog]] was censored by [[Roskomnadzor]], the Russian government agency in charge of Internet censorship, for including the video.{{cite news|url=http://www.microsofttranslator.com/bv.aspx?from=ru&to=en&a=http://lenta.ru/news/2013/02/05/dumbwaystoblacklist/|title=Post on your blog for clip on blocked Lebedeva stupid ways to commit suicide|publisher=Lenta.ru|date=5 February 2013}} Later that day, the YouTube video was also censored, with the "This content is not available in your country due to a legal complaint from the government" message. The official takedown notice sent to [[Livejournal.com]] was quoted, in part, by Lebedev in his blog.
The song's lyrics contains a description of different ways of committing suicide, such as: using drugs beyond their expiration date, standing on an edge of a platform, running across the rails, eating [[Cyanoacrylate|superglue]] and other. The animated personages demonstrate dangerous ways of suicide in attractive for children and teenagers comic format. The lines such as "hide in a [[Clothes dryer|dryer]]” and “What’s this red button do?" contain an incitement to commit those acts.
Despite this fact, the video was included into the [[ABC Show]] and was shown in more than 50 cities of Russia. ===Awards=== The campaign won seven [[Webby Award]]s in 2013 including the Best Animation Film & Video and Best Public Service & Activism (Social Content & Marketing).{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/technology/technology-news/melbourne-rail-safety-message-wins-webby-20130501-2isyl.html|title=Melbourne rail safety message wins Webby|publisher=The Age|date=1 May 2013}} It won three Siren Awards, run by [[Commercial Radio Australia]], including the Gold Siren for best advertisement of the year and Silver Sirens for the best song and best campaign.{{cite news|url=http://www.bandt.com.au/news/advertising/dumb-ways-to-die-dominates-sirens|title=Dumb Ways to Die dominates Sirens|publisher=B&T|date=10 May 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sirenawards.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1049&news_id=1375|title=Dumb Ways to Die campaign dominates best radio ads of the year|publisher=Commercial Radio Australia|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130808055344/http://www.sirenawards.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1049&news_id=1375|archivedate=8 August 2013|df=dmy-all}} The public service announcement was awarded the Grand Trophy in the 2013 New York Festivals International Advertising Awards.{{cite web |url=http://www.australiancreative.com.au/news/dumb-ways-does-it-again |title=Dumb Ways does it again |work=australiancreative.com.au |date=4 May 2013 |accessdate=10 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130710030132/http://www.australiancreative.com.au/news/dumb-ways-does-it-again |archivedate=10 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }} In June 2013, the campaign clip won the Integrated Grand Prix at the [[Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity]],{{cite web|title=Cannes Lions: Dumb Ways to Die scoops top award|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/jun/22/cannes-lions-advertising-awards?guni=Article:in%20body%20link|first=Mark |last=Sweney|publisher=The Guardian|year=2013|accessdate=9 August 2013}} and overall, won five Grand Prix awards, 18 Gold Lions, three Silver Lions, and two Bronze Lions, which was the most for the campaign in the festival's history.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/24/us-australia-advertising-die-idUSBRE95N03L20130624 |title=Quirky 'Dumb Ways to Die' campaign sweeps advertising awards |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=19 May 2014}} ==Legacy== ===Parodies=== Within two weeks, the video had spawned over 85 parodies.{{cite web|first=Asher |last=Moses |url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/aussie-viral-video-dumb-ways-to-die-lives-on-20121129-2ahm0.html |title=Aussie viral video, 'Dumb Ways to Die', lives on |work = [[Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=29 November 2012 }} Some renditions and parodies have been featured in national and international media: * "Cool Things to Find" - featuring the [[Curiosity (rover)|''Curiosity'' Mars rover]]. Cinesaurus noted that it took them six days and 250 man hours to create.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/28/cool-things-to-find-video_n_2206896.html |title='Cool Things To Find' Parodies 'Dumb Ways To Die' PSA With Spoof Starring Mars Rover (VIDEO) |work = [[Huffington Post]] | date = 28 November 2012 | first = Ryan | last = Grenoble }}{{cite web|last=Starr |first=Michelle |url=http://www.cnet.com/news/dumb-ways-to-die-parody-is-even-more-fun/ |title=Dumb Ways to Die parody is even more fun |work=CNET |date=28 November 2012 }} * "Dumb Movie Ways to Die" - from The Movie Maniacs parodies well known "dumb" movie deaths from famous films.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6vqAa95EplE |title=Dumb Movie Ways to Die - Dumb Ways to Die Parody |publisher=YouTube |date=20 March 2013 |accessdate=20 September 2016}} * "Dumb Ways to Die (In Video Games) Parody"{{cite web|url=http://www.bleedingcool.com/2013/06/25/dumb-ways-to-die-cleans-up-at-cannes-and-in-parodies/ |title=Dumb Ways To Die Cleans Up At Cannes - And In Parodies - Bleeding Cool Comic Book, Movies and TV News and Rumors |first=Rich | last = Johnston | authorlink = Rich Johnston | work=Bleedingcool.com | date = 25 June 2013 }} * "Dumb Ways to Die (Minecraft Edition)" * "Grand Theft Auto V: Dumb Ways to Die"{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/media/gta-v-meets-dumb-ways-die-youtube-parody-video/244520/ |title=GTA V Meets 'Dumb Ways to Die' in YouTube Parody Video | work = [[Advertising Age]] |first=Ann-Christine | last = Diaz | date = 2 October 2013 }}{{cite web|first=Aaron |last=Taube |url=http://www.businessinsider.in/This-Grand-Theft-Auto-V-Themed-Spoof-Of-The-Dumb-Ways-To-Die-Ad-Is-Tremendous/articleshow/23471031.cms |title=This 'Grand Theft Auto V' Themed Spoof Of The 'Dumb Ways To Die' Ad Is Tremendous | work = [[Business Insider]] | location = India | date = 3 October 2013}} *Dumb Ways to Die - [[Game of Thrones]] Edition{{cite web|last1=Nudd|first1=Tim|title=Dumb Ways to Die, Game of Thrones Edition, Chronicles Show's Notable Demises Thus Far Plenty of untimely ends|url=http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/dumb-ways-die-game-thrones-edition-chronicles-shows-notable-demises-thus-far-164041|website=AdWeek|date= 13 April 2015| accessdate=21 May 2015}} * "Dumb Ways to Die - Miami/ESPM" by [[Miami Ad School]] in [[Sao Paulo, Brazil]].{{cite web|last=Nudd |first=Tim |url=http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/creative-ideas-die-messy-deaths-ad-schools-dumb-ways-parody-157323 |title=Creative Ideas Die Messy Deaths in Ad School's 'Dumb Ways' Parody |work = [[Adweek]] | date = 28 April 2014}} (No longer available in YouTube due to copyright claim by [[Metro Trains Melbourne]]) {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZkydRlD55Sk|title=YouTube|website=www.youtube.com|access-date=26 April 2016}} * My Little Pony Dumb Ways to Die - a version featuring the ponies from ''[[My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic]]''https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7nH8yjg1CuM * "Annoying Ways to Die" from ''[[The Annoying Orange|Annoying Orange]]'', as noted by [[Mediabistro.com|Socialtimes]]{{cite web|url=http://socialtimes.com/dumb-ways-to-die-parodies_b114082 |title=6 Awesome ‘Dumb Ways To Die’ Parodies On YouTube | work=[[Mediabistro.com|SocialTimes]] |date=20 December 2012 }} * "The Walking Dead + Dumb Ways to Die Parody" - live-action parody of characters from ''[[The Walking Dead (TV series)|The Walking Dead]]'' * "Smart Ways to Live" by [[The Maccabeats]] - a cappella version as noted by [[Arutz Sheva]].{{cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/167430#.VMTi91r5u0s |title=New and Fresh from The Maccabeats: Smart Ways to Live |publisher=Israelnationalnews.com |date= |accessdate=20 September 2016}} * "Dumb Ways to Die - ''[[Happy Tree Friends]]'' Edition"{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wp4A7Y9WNI4 |title=Dumb Ways to Die - Happy Tree Friends Edition (Version 2.0) |publisher=YouTube |date=23 March 2014 |accessdate=20 September 2016}} * "Fun Ways to Die"{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hfLEChxV2fw |title=fun ways to die parody of dumb ways to die |publisher=YouTube |date=26 March 2013 |accessdate=20 September 2016}} * "Queremos Vivir en Caracas"{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4baIlhne-pU |title=Queremos Vivir en Caracas |publisher=YouTube |date=23 September 2013 |accessdate=20 September 2016}} ===Life Insurance Partnership=== Due to their success, the Dumb Ways to Die characters have been featured in a promotional campaign for [[Empire Life|Empire Life Insurance]], with their key message being, "the dumbest way to die is without life insurance."{{cite web |url=http://empirelife.ca |title=The Unexpected Happens Everyday - Empire Life Insurance | date=1 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715005456/https://www.empirelife.ca/ |archivedate=15 July 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.empire.ca/consumer/about-us/news/news-archive-2014/2014-05-29/en/ |title=The dumbest way to die is without life insurance, Empire Life launches new advertising campaign |date=29 May 2014}} However, the campaign was met with mixed reviews, with some advertising critics accusing Metro of "selling out" on a successful campaign.{{cite web|last=Nudd |first=Tim |url=http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/nothings-sacred-dumb-ways-die-now-being-used-hawk-life-insurance-158279 |title=Nothing's Sacred: Dumb Ways to Doe Now Being Used to Hawk Life Insurance |work = [[Adweek]] | date = 12 June 2014}} ===Spin-offs=== On 17 October 2014, the Dumb Ways to Die website was revamped to hint at a new installment of the campaign. Slated for release in November 2014, the games take on a more sporting, athletic, and fitness theme, and is labelled "Dumb Ways to Die 2: The Games".{{cite web |url=http://www.mumbrella.asia/2014/10/mccann-launches-new-version-dumb-ways-die-game/ |title=Mumbrella Asia - New Dumb Ways to Die Spin off game launches |date= 24 October 2014}} ===Other=== *Metro Trains was also supporting the [[Melbourne International Film Festival]] and decided to create a video to keep safe around that event.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bZmRqoCTg1Q|title=Dumb Ways to Die - Melbourne International Film Festival (official video)|publisher=Metro Trains}} Retrieved on 22 December 2014. *The song was used in the 45th episode of the seventh season of the Chinese dating show ''[[If You Are the One (game show)|If You Are The One]]'' during a contestant's introduction video.{{citation needed|reason=please, this is really funny|date=February 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://dumbwaystodie.com/}} [[Category:Public transport in Melbourne]] [[Category:Viral videos]] [[Category:Public service announcements]] [[Category:2012 songs]] [[Category:Webby Award winners]] [[Category:2013 controversies]] [[Category:2013 video games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:Internet memes introduced in 2012]] [[Category:Censorship in Russia]] [[Category:Media and entertainment controversies]] [[Category:Puzzle video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Australia]]

revision.comment: /* DVD release */ Correct title for this section
revision.text:
{{Primary sources|date=July 2015}} '''Elvis the Concert''' is a [[concert tour]] started in 1997 that features a video and the voice of [[Elvis Presley]] performing with his 1970s backup band via computer technology.
== Origins ==
In the mid-1990s, [[Elvis Presley Enterprises]] started experimenting with recordings of Elvis' live concerts, and discovered that through the use of [[Audio mixing (recorded music)|sound mixing]] they were able to eliminate virtually all of the ambient noise from the [[Multitrack recording|multitrack]] recordings, thus leaving only Elvis' voice. After some work, they conceived a special concert, to be held on August 16, 1997, the twentieth Anniversary of Elvis' death. The show featured Elvis' original 1970s back-up band ([[TCB Band]]), his back-up singers (The Stamps Quartet, [[The Imperials]], [[The Sweet Inspirations]] and [[Millie Kirkham]]) and was performed at Memphis, Tennessee's [[Mid-South Coliseum]]. During the show, Priscilla Presley introduced a video that Lisa Marie Presley made. The video was of Lisa Marie performing a duet with her father Elvis on the song "Don't Cry Daddy". It was so successful that the video was shown again.
The show was a huge success, gaining worldwide press. The massive success of the show prompted EPE to draw up plans for a special version of the show to take on the road.
== The World Tour ==
Starting in 1998, a scaled-down version of the show was taken on tour. The format of the show follows one of Elvis' 1970s live concerts, albeit somewhat differently.
The line-up of musicians involved is as follows: *[[James Burton]]{{spaced ndash}}Lead Guitar *[[Jerry Scheff]]{{spaced ndash}}Bass **After Scheff left the TCB band, he has been replaced on the more recent tours by [[Norbert Putnam]] *[[Ronnie Tutt]]{{spaced ndash}}Drums **Tutt is sometimes unable to perform with Elvis' band due to pressing worldwide commitments (which include playing drums in [[Neil Diamond]]'s band). For these shows, he is replaced by his friend and protégé [[Paul Leim]] *[[Glen D. Hardin]]{{spaced ndash}}Piano, Keyboards *[[Joe Guercio]]{{spaced ndash}}Orchestra Conductor
Backing Vocals: *[[The Sweet Inspirations]]{{spaced ndash}}Estelle Brown, Myrna Smith, Portia Brown *[[The Stamps Quartet]]<ref name=AlternatingTours/>{{spaced ndash}}Ed Enoch, Ed Hill, Royce Taylor, Butch Owens *[[The Imperials]]<ref name=AlternatingTours/>{{spaced ndash}}Terry Blackwood, Joe Moscheo, Sherman Andrus *[[Millie Kirkham]]{{spaced ndash}}Soprano
Rhythm guitarist [[John Wilkinson (guitarist)|John Wilkinson]], having suffered a stroke in 1989, was unable to join the band and was replaced by Tony Smith. (However, Wilkinson did join the group at the 25th Anniversary concert, held at the Pyramid in Memphis.)
The show was conceived by Todd Morgan, Randy Johnson. Joe Guercio and Stig Edgren.
*Produced by Elvis Presley Enterprises and Stig Edgren *Directed and staged by Randy Johnson *Musical Direction by Joe Guercio
== Show Format ==
The format of the show begins with the traditional opening theme of Elvis' concerts: "[[Also sprach Zarathustra (Strauss)|Also sprach Zarathustra]]" by [[Richard Strauss]] (better known as the theme to the movie ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]''). This segues into the song "[[See See Rider]]" from ''[[Elvis: Aloha from Hawaii]]''.
The show is divided into two different acts, each one 45 minutes to an hour, with an intermission between them. The main material used for the shows comes from ''[[Elvis: That's the Way It Is]]'', ''[[Elvis: Aloha from Hawaii]]'', and ''[[Elvis on Tour]]''. And in recent years songs from the [[Elvis_(1968_TV_program)|'68 Comeback Special]] has been added to the mix, most notably the songs "Trouble" (which usually segues into either "Hound Dog" or "That's All Right"), and "If I Can Dream" which is used to end the first act.
During the show, a large video screen hangs above the main set upon which the video of Elvis' performance is projected. Two smaller screens hang on either side, and video of the live musicians, or special video packages are shown.
The first act usually ends with a gospel music segment. If The Imperials are performing, they perform a solo version of "He Touched Me". If the Stamps are performing, they perform an a cappella rendition of "Sweet, Sweet Spirit" (after an introduction by Elvis from the movie ''[[Elvis on Tour]]''). After that song, a version of "How Great Thou Art" by Elvis is played with the band. In early shows, this proved to be problematic: since the audio was taken from the 1974 live album ''Elvis As Recorded Live on Stage in Memphis'', but there was no video footage. Thus, the screen was left black, and only the audio was played. After a few tours, a special piece of footage was made from the 1972 movie ''[[Elvis on Tour]]'' which was edited, sped up, and slowed down in a few places in order to have it match up with the 1974 audio.
The show always ends with Elvis' traditional show closer "Can't Help Falling in Love", and the traditional announcement of "Elvis has Left the Building." At the 1997 and 2002 concerts Elvis' former announcer [[Al Dvorin]] closed the show by saying "Elvis has left for Graceland".
After a domestic tour (which ended with a show at the Market Square Arena in Indianapolis, IN, the site of Elvis' final live concert on June 26, 1977), the show went to [[Europe]], [[Asia]], and [[Australia]].
=== 25th anniversary – 2002 ===
In 2002, a special 25th anniversary show commemorating the 25th anniversary of Presley's death was held in Memphis, TN at the Pyramid arena. This show was even bigger than the 20th anniversary concert, and featured three different acts. The first act served as a retrospective of Elvis' career from 1956 to 1968. Elvis' former drummer [[D.J. Fontana]] made an appearance, playing drums to footage from one of Elvis' appearances on ''The Steve Allen Show''. Saxophonist [[Boots Randolph]] made an appearance as well playing sax on "Blue Suede Shoes" and on a performance of "Return to Sender" (taken from his movie ''[[Girls! Girls! Girls!]]'') as part of a special section highlighting Elvis' career in movies.
Act Two showed the gospel side of Elvis. During a special section of gospel music, a surprise was in store for fans as J.D. Sumner's voice was multi-tracked for a performance (with Elvis and the Stamps) of "Why Me, Lord?" Lisa Marie also made an appearance singing an original song she wrote called "Nobody Noticed It (You're Still Lovely)".
Act 3 was the usual Elvis: the Concert show format and featured new songs, like "Are You Lonesome Tonight?" from ''That's The Way It Is'' outtakes. This was the only show in which John Wilkinson, who was Elvis' rhythm guitar player from 1969 to 1977, made an appearance. He is not shown on the new DVD ''Elvis Lives'', but he can be seen on the fan footage of this show.
=== 30th anniversary – 2007 ===
On August 16, 2007, Elvis: The 30th Anniversary Concert was held at the Fed-Ex Forum in Memphis and was on a bigger scale than the 20th and 25th anniversary concerts. It featured: *Joe Guercio (musical director and conductor) *the TCB Band members James Burton (lead guitar), Glen D. Hardin (piano), Jerry Scheff (bass), and Ronnie Tutt (drums) *Sweet Inspirations members Myrna Smith, and Estelle Brown *Imperials members Sherman Andrus, Terry Blackwood, Joe Moscheo, and Gus Gaches *Stamps members Bill Baize, Ed Hill, Larry Strickland, and Donnie Sumner *Jordanaires members Gordon Stoker and Ray Walker *D.J. Fontana (drums) and Millie Kirkham (soprano).
Also appearing: *The Dempseys and members of the [[Memphis Symphony Orchestra]].
The 30th Anniversary featured another duet by Elvis Presley and Lisa Marie Presley. This time singing "In The Ghetto". The video is available for download on iTunes.
Also, a new opening was done for the show which featured a space view of Earth which zoomed in on Memphis and then Graceland, right into the window which led to Elvis' bedroom. There, "Elvis" is getting ready for the show with Jerry Schilling giving him his sunglasses. They go down the stairs to the outside of Graceland where they meet up with Joe Esposito and then go into a helicopter. The group flies to the Fed-Ex Forum where audio of Elvis (from the CD ''An Afternoon in the Garden'') says "It's a big place, man". Then they land and go inside the arena, starting the show.
At the show, Priscilla announced that this would be the final show for Elvis: The Concert.
In late 2007, Elvis: The Concert opened for The White Stripes on their European tour.
==Home media== In 2007, the 2002 25th Anniversary Concert was made available in DVD form in a disc called ''Elvis Lives''. The concert was shown on [[PBS]] Stations during the annual pledge week. ''Elvis Lives'' only contains Act III (70s Concert) which was a regular Elvis: The Concert segment.
==References== {{reflist|refs=
<ref name=AlternatingTours>The two different groups alternate between tours, taking over whenever the other group is unable to perform.</ref>
}}
==External links==
*[http://www.elvis.com/concert Official site] *[http://www.elvis.com.au/presley/interview_thefrenchmeetstigedgren.shtml Interview with producer Stig Edgren] *[http://www.elvis2001.net/ricky%20strick.htm Larry Strickland Interview] on Elvis2001.net *[http://www.elvis2001.net/donnie%20sumner.htm Donnie Sumner Interview] on Elvis2001.net *[http://www.elvis2001.net/Ed%20Hill%20i.htm Ed Hill Interview] on Elvis2001.net *[http://www.elvis2001.net/Bill%20Baise.htm Bill Baise Interview] on Elvis2001.net *[http://www.elvis2001.net/ed%20enoch.htm Ed Enoch Interview] on Elvis2001.net *[http://www.elvis2001.net/shaun%20neilson.htm Shaun Neilson Interview] on Elvis2001.net
{{Elvis Presley}}
[[Category:Concert tours]] [[Category:Elvis Presley]]

[[File:Enric Marco Batlle (2001).jpg|thumb|Enric Marco receiving the [[Creu de Sant Jordi Award]] in 2001.]] '''Enric Marco''' (born 1921 in [[Barcelona]]) is an [[impostor]] who claimed to have been a [[prison]]er in [[Nazi Germany|Nazi German]] [[concentration camp]]s [[Mauthausen-Gusen concentration camp|Mauthausen]] and [[Flossenbürg concentration camp|Flossenbürg]] in [[World War II]]. He was awarded the [[Creu de Sant Jordi]] by the [[Catalonia|Catalan]] government in 2001 and wrote a book on his experiences. In 2005 he admitted his claims were false and returned his medal, after his deception was revealed by university researcher [[Benito Bermejo]].
Marco told [[TV3 (Catalonia)|Catalan TV]]: "''I wasn't in a concentration camp. I was held in captivity and the Nazis did impose penalties on me. But that does not exonerate me from being an impostor."'' He said he was released after being mistreated for several weeks and returned to [[Spain]] in 1943. Marco claimed he had volunteered in 1941 to work in [[Kiel]] for the Nazi war industry. In his made-up story called ''Memoir of Hell'' Marco wrote he had been involved in the [[French resistance]] and captured by the [[Gestapo]] in southern France.<ref name="news.bbc">{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4539461.stm | title=Spanish Nazi camp 'survivor' lied | publisher=[[BBC]] | work=A leading representative of Holocaust survivors in Spain has admitted to being "an impostor" | date=12 May 2005 |}}</ref>
After 2001 Marco represented an association of survivors of the thousands of [[Spanish people|Spaniards]] who had truly been deported to Nazi concentration camps.
In the period 1978–1979 Marco, a metal worker, had been the General Secretary of the Spanish [[Anarchism|anarchist]] Union CNT ([[Confederación Nacional del Trabajo]]), from which he was expelled in 1980.
==Bibliography== * ''Memorias del infierno'',<ref name="autobiografias">{{cite web | url=http://www.autobiografias.net/ficha-autobiografia.php?id=29348 | title=''Memorias del infierno'' | publisher=Autobiografías | work=FALSAS memorias Holocausto | date=2012 | accessdate=15 June 2015 | author=Pere Riera Obiol}}</ref> (''Memories'' or ''Memoir of Hell'') by Enric Marco, 1978. Spanish.<ref name="theguardian">{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/may/12/secondworldwar.spain | title=Spain's concentration camp hero is exposed as a fraud | publisher=The Guardian. World News | date=12 May 2005 | accessdate=15 June 2015 | author=Giles Tremlett in Madrid}}</ref> * ''L'impostor'' by [[Javier Cercas]] - (2014, Penguin Random House Grupo Editorial, Spain)
==See also== * [[Misha Defonseca]] * [[Martin Gray (Holocaust survivor)|Martin Grey]] * [[Herman Rosenblat]] * [[Rosemarie Pence]] * [[Binjamin Wilkomirski]] * [[Javier Cercas]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * The Times, 14 May 2005. * [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,3-1608303,00.html Times online.] <sup>''[Forced redirect]''</sup> * [https://www.theguardian.com/secondworldwar/story/0,14058,1481811,00.html The Guardian: Spain's concentration camp hero is exposed as a fraud]
"Ich bin Enric Marco" directed by Santiago Fillol and Lucas Vermal, produced by Corte y Confección de películas {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marco, Enric}} [[Category:Impostors]] [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hoaxes in Spain]] [[Category:Catalan_people]]

[[File:Erik den helige och biskop Henrik.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Eric IX of Sweden]] and [[Henry (bishop of Finland)|Bishop Henry]] en route to Finland. Late mediaeval depiction from Uppland.]] {{Crusade}} {{Christianization of Finland}} The '''First Swedish Crusade''' was a mythical military expedition in 1150s to [[Southwest Finland]] by Swedish [[Monarchy of Sweden|King]] [[Eric IX of Sweden|Eric IX]] and English Bishop [[Henry (bishop of Finland)|Henry]] of [[Uppsala]].
Earliest written sources of the crusade are from the end of 13th Century. The main sources of the crusade, the legend of [[Eric IX of Sweden|Saint Erik]] and the legend of [[Henry (bishop of Finland)|Saint Henry]], describes that the reason for the crusade were the multiple raids that pagan Finns made to Sweden.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Pyhän Henrikin Legenda|last=Heikkilä|first=Tuomas|publisher=Suomalaisen kirjallisuuden seuran toimituksia 1039|year=2006|isbn=|location=Helsinki|pages=138-139}}</ref>
The crusade has traditionally been seen as the first attempt of [[Catholic Church]] and [[Sweden]] to convert pagan [[Finns]] to [[Christianity]]. However, the [[Christianisation]] of the South-western part of Finland is known to have already started in 10th century, and in the 12th century, the area was probably almost entirely Christian.<ref name=":0" /> According to legends, after the crusade [[Bishop Henry]] was killed at lake [[Köyliönjärvi]] by [[Lalli]]. He later became a central figure of the Catholic Church in Finland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://193.184.161.234/DF/detail.php?id=1109|title=Eric's crusade to Finland|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927051320/http://193.184.161.234/DF/detail.php?id=1109|archivedate=2007-09-27}}. Original medieval legend in Latin.</ref>
== Veracity of the crusade == Academics debate whether this crusade actually took place. No archaeological data give any support for it and earliest written sources are from much later date. No surviving written source describes Swedish influence in Finland before the end of the 13th Century. Furthermore, the diocese and bishop of Finland are not listed among their Swedish counterparts before the 1250s. Also, the [[Christianisation]] of the South-western part of Finland is known to have already started in 10th century, and in the 12th century, the area was probably almost entirely Christian.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Muinaisuutemme jäljet|last=Georg Haggren, Petri Halinen, Mika Lavento, Sami Raninen ja Anna Wessman|first=|publisher=Gaudeamus|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=343|via=}}</ref>
The Swedish bishop normally involved in the eastern campaigns was the [[Bishop of Linköping]], not the Bishop of Uppsala.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}}
The mid-12th century was a very violent time in the northern Baltic sea, with Finnish tribes such as [[Tavastians]] and [[Karelia (historical province of Finland)|Karelians]] as well as Swedes in frequent conflicts with [[Republic of Novgorod|Novgorod]] and with each other.<ref>See articles [[Swedish-Novgorodian Wars]] and [[Prehistoric Finnish wars]].</ref> The [[First Novgorod Chronicle]] tells that in 1142 a Swedish "prince" and bishop accompanied by a fleet of 60 ships plundered just three Novgorodian merchant vessels somewhere "on the other side of the sea", obviously being after something more important.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://193.184.161.234/DF/detail.php?id=15|title=First Novgorod Chronicle entry on the attack in 1142|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927051331/http://193.184.161.234/DF/detail.php?id=15|archivedate=2007-09-27}}. In Swedish.</ref>
== Timing of the crusade == Almost all years of the 1150`s have been suggested as the year that the crusade possibly took place. Most widely supported years have been years 1150, 1155, 1157 and 1158. Other candidates have been years 1153, 1154 and1156.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Pyhän Henrikin legenda|last=Heikkilä|first=Tuomas|publisher=Suomalaisen kirjallisuuden seuran toimituksia 1039 (2.painos)|year=2006|isbn=|location=Helsinki|pages=55-56}}</ref>
At the time, leading the ''[[leiðangr]]'' was the responsibility of the [[Jarl in Sweden|jarl]]. This gave rise to a theory that Eric conducted the expedition before he became king or pretender to the throne.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} Legends give no year for the expedition, and attempts to date it to an exact year in the 1150s are all much later speculations. All that is known about King Eric and Bishop Henry is that they most probably held important positions in Sweden some time in the mid-12th century.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}}
== See also ==
* [[Second Swedish Crusade]] * [[Third Swedish Crusade]] * [[Northern Crusades]] * [[Bishop Fulco]]
==References ==
{{reflist}} {{Catholic Church in Sweden}}
[[Category:12th century in Sweden]] [[Category:Sweden–Finland]] [[Category:Northern Crusades]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict = Four Four Bravo ambush |partof = [[Sri Lankan Civil War]] |image = |caption = |date = July 23, 1983 |place = [[Thirunelveli (Sri Lanka)|Thirunelveli]], [[Jaffna Peninsula]] |coordinates= |territory = |result = Successful LTTE ambush |combatant1 =[[LTTE]] |combatant2 = {{flagicon|Sri Lanka}} [[Sri Lanka Army]] * {{flagicon|Sri Lanka}} [[Sri Lanka Light Infantry]] |commander1 =[[Velupillai Prabhakaran]]
Sellakili{{KIA}} |commander2 = {{flagicon|Sri Lanka}} 2nd Lt [[A.P.N.C. De S. Vaas Gunawardene|Vaas Gunawardene]]{{KIA}} |strength1 = 25 |strength2 = 15 |strength3 = |casualties1= 1 (Sellakili) |casualties2= 1 officer & 12 soldiers died, 2 injured |casualties3= |notes = }} '''Four Four Bravo''' was the [[call sign]] of a fifteen-man [[Sri Lankan Army]] patrol, deployed in the [[Jaffna Peninsula]] on July 23, 1983. The patrol was ambushed and thirteen of its members were killed by the [[LTTE]]. This incident sparked the [[Black July|Black July riots]] and is considered to be the start of the [[Sri Lankan Civil War]].[http://sundaytimes.lk/080727/Plus/sundaytimesplus_08.html That massacre upon massacre] ==Background== By July 1983 tension was rising in the Jaffna Peninsula and throughout the country, the [[TULF]] had decided that their Members of Parliament resign their seats and on July 21, 1983 in Parliament, V.N. Navaratnam delivered an emotional farewell address. On the July 23 was a quiet day in Jaffna, even though there were political activity in Mannar. That day at the Army Camp at [[Gurunagar]] under the command of Brigadier J.G. Balthazar, the army was preparing an ambush for a LTTE leader ''Sellakili'', who had been engaged in terrorist activities. It was to be carried out by a group of [[Commandos]] with the call sign ''Four Four Charlie'', at Kondavil. Patrol Four Four Bravo was scheduled to leave Gurunagar (code name ''Four Four'') at 2200 hours as a routine patrol from the C Company of the First Battalion of the [[Sri Lanka Light Infantry]] based at Madagal about 20 miles away. The patrol arrived at 2147 hours. It consisted of a detachment of 15 soldiers led by Second Lieutenant A.P.N.C. De S. Vaas Gunawardene. The instructions of the Brigadier were that the patrol should be back in Madagal before 2359 hours, if necessary shortening the prescribed route: Gurunagar - Jaffna - Naga Vihara - Nallur - Kopay - Urumpirai - Kondavil - Kokuvil - [[Jaffna]]- Kaliyan - kadu - Madagal. 2nd Lt. Gunawardene received the instructions from Major De Silva who further emphasized that the patrol must be in Madagal Camp by midnight. Four Four Bravo left Gurunagar at 2206 hours and was in radio contact every five minutes all reports indicated that Jaffna was quiet. ==Ambush== During this time ''Sellakili'' was planning on getting revenge for the death of [[Charles Lucas Anthony]] aka Seelan[http://www.atimes.com/ind-pak/DC02Df02.html Chapter 29 - Prisoners massacred ] and had observed the army patrols. That night a group of 25 LTTE men, including [[Velupillai Prabhakaran]], [[Kittu (Tamil militant)|Kittu]], Iyer, Victor, Pulendran, Shellakili, Santhosam and Appiah gathered at Tinneveli on the Palali - Jaffna road at a point where the road was dug up to install new telecommunication equipment. Near one such excavation four mines were placed and a plunger stolen from the Kankesanturai Cement Factory was placed on the balcony of a nearby house. A machine gun nests were placed near the exploder and across the road. The force was split in two and placed on both sides of the road with Sellakili present. At 2328 hours the patrol reported that it was leaving Urumpirai junction and everything was quiet. The patrol was made up of a jeep with 2nd Lt. Vaas Gunawardene, Private N.A.S. Manutange driving and Corporal G.D. Perera and Private S.S. Amarasinghe, Private S.P.G. Rajatillake and Private K.P. Karunaratne in the rear and a Tata Benz half truck with the rest of the patrol with Sergent S.I. Thelakaratne in the front seat with Corporal G.R. Perera at the wheel and Private A.J.R. Fernando between them. Five minutes of leaving Urumpirai the Jeep was slowing down near Tinneveli because of the obstruction on the road due to the installation of telecommunication equipment. As it was passing the excavation on the road, the exploder set off the mines, followed by a hail of machine gun fire on the Jeep and the half-truck. The explosion of the mines wounded many of the men in the jeep including 2nd Lt. Vaas Gunawardene who leapt out of the Jeep and pulled out a hand grenade, but was mowed down by machine gun fire. The rest in the jeep scrambled out attacked the enemy with hand grenades before being killed. Cpl. G.D. Perera charged at the enemy firing his SLR, his body was found a short distance from the jeep. On witnessing the explosion the half truck stopped and it too came under fire from both parties of the LTTE. The fire killed Cpl. Perera in the driver's seat, Private Robert, Sunil and Wijesiri in the rear and wounded Private Manapitiya. Sgt. Thelakaratne and Private Fernando who were both wounded scrambled out, took cover from the vehicle and opened fire, however Fernando was soon killed. Thilakaratne kept firing until home-made grenade blew off one hand and all but blew off one foot. Cpl. R. A. U. Perera and Cpl. Sumathipala kept on firing and the latter in addition lobbed his grenade. In his dying moments Private Manapitiya gave his grenade to the Cpl. Sumathipala who changed their magazines and kept on the pressure on the enemy. At one stage they alighted from the vehicle and kept on firing at the enemy in two different directions thus pinning them down. At 2340 hours a message was sent to Brigadier Balthazar that radio contact with the patrol was lost and that a sentry had heard gunfire and explosions in the distance. The Army camps in Palali, Madagal, Thondamanar and Velvettiturai were alerted and the ambush prepared for Four Four Charlie was canceled by the Brigadier. It was sent in search of Four Four Bravo. Four Four Charlie located the destroyed vehicles at 0009 hours and reported in. Cpl. R. A. U. Perera also telephoned from the Kondavil CTB Depot about that time. He had fired till he ran out ammunition and thereafter had retreated, wounded in both legs. He gave the location of Cpl. Sumathipala, who had also fired till his ammunition was almost expended, and thereafter had retreated and was lying wounded. Brigadier Balthazar himself reached the location, and found Sgt. Thelakaratne in critical condition and sent him to the hospital. He died on the way.[http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2003/08/24/fea06.html Actual story of the attack that sparked the riots] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605231830/http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2003/08/24/fea06.html |date=2011-06-05 }} ==Patrol members== * [[Second Lieutenant]] [[A.P.N.C. De S. Vaas Gunawardene]] - Patrol Commander * [[Sergeant]] S.I. Thelakaratne - Patrol [[Second-in-Command]] * [[Corporal]] G.R. Perera * [[Corporal]] R.A.U. Perera - Survived the attack with injuries * [[Lance Corporal]] Sumathipala - Survived the attack with injuries * [[Lance Corporal]] G.D. Perera *[[Private (rank)|Private]] A.J.R. Fernando *[[Private (rank)|Private]] M.B. Sunil *[[Private (rank)|Private]] D.N.A.D. Manapitiya *[[Private (rank)|Private]] G. Robert *[[Private (rank)|Private]] A.J. Wijesiri *[[Private (rank)|Private]] N.A.S. Manutange *[[Private (rank)|Private]] S.S. Amarasinghe *[[Private (rank)|Private]] S.P.G. Rajatillake *[[Private (rank)|Private]] K.P. Karunaratne ==Equipment== The members of the Four Four Bravo were armed with [[FN FAL|SLR rifles]], except 2nd Lt. Gunawardene who was armed with a sub machine gun and grenades. The [[LTTE]] used sub machine guns, repeater shot guns stolen from the Chavakachcheri Police Station. They had with them [[Type 56 assault rifle|T56 assault rifle]] and a SLR rifle. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Sri Lankan Civil War graphical timeline}} [[Category:Origins of the Sri Lankan Civil War]] [[Category:Sri Lanka Army]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = Gaudeamus | founded = 1945 | location = Loevenhoutsedijk 301 [[Utrecht (stad)|Utrecht]], | website = [http://www.muziekweek.nl/index.php] }}
The '''Gaudeamus Foundation''' and Contemporary Music Center organizes and promotes [[contemporary music]]al activities and concerts in the [[Netherlands]] and abroad. It focuses on supporting the career development of young composers and musicians, particularly Dutch, through its library facilities, contacts with international organizations, and its own activities. Gaudeamus was founded at Bilthoven, the Netherlands, in 1945 by Walter A. F. Maas, a [[Jewish]] immigrant from [[Mainz]]. It was originally headquartered in the Huize Gaudeamus, a villa built in the shape of a grand piano by the composer [[Julius Röntgen]], also an immigrant from Germany but two generations older. Although in 2008 the Gaudeamus Foundation was incorporated into the [[Muziek Centrum Nederland]], as from 2011 it continues to operate independently.{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}
==Activities== *[[Gaudeamus International Composers Award]], focuses on music by young composers and includes composers' competition. *[[Gaudeamus International Interpreters Award|International Gaudeamus Interpreters Competition]], for performers of contemporary music. *Concerts and festivals *Library and documentation center for contemporary music *''Gaudeamus Information'', newsletter *Co-producer of the [[Output Festival]], edition 2007
==See also== * [[Donemus]]
==References== *Anon. 2001. "Gaudeamus Foundation". ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'', second edition, edited by [[Stanley Sadie]] and [[John Tyrrell (professor of music)|John Tyrrell]]. London: Macmillan Publishers.
==Further reading== * Peters, Peter. 1996. ''Eeuwige jeugd. Een halve eeuw Stichting Gaudeamus''. Amsterdam: Donemus.
== External links == *[http://www.muziekcentrumnederland.nl/ Muziek Centrum Nederland] *[http://www.ecpnm.com/ European Conference of Promoters of New Music (ECPNM)]
[[Category:Music organisations based in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Gaudeamus Foundation| ]] [[Category:1945 establishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Contemporary classical music festivals]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1945]]

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "20th/21st-century American theatre company" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|20th/21st-century American theatre company}} [[File:Georgia Shakespeare Festival's production of Macbeth.jpg|thumb|220px|Joanna Mitchell and Jason Loughlin in Georgia Shakespeare's 2007 production of Macbeth]] '''Georgia Shakespeare''' (formerly ''Georgia Shakespeare Festival'') was a professional, [[not-for-profit]] [[theatre]] company located in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], in the [[United States]] on the campus of [[Oglethorpe University]] from 1985-2014. Georgia Shakespeare produced plays annually, primarily between June and November. At its peak, it welcomed 60,000 patrons annually to its performances.
== History == Georgia Shakespeare was founded in 1985 by Lane Anderson, Richard Garner, and Robert Watson under the name ''Georgia Shakespeare Festival''. The company produced two plays each year, with its first offering being productions of ''[[The Taming of the Shrew]]'' and ''[[King Lear (play)|King Lear]]'' in rotating repertory starting July 10, 1986.
The rising theatre company went through several locations in its first years. Its first season was on the Oglethorpe University front athletic field in a rectangular, white 60' X 90' tent with a [[seating capacity]] of 300. The theatre changed tents for its second season and was housed in a circular tent with a 90' diameter. This new tent increased the [[seating capacity]] by 50. For the theatre's fifth season, it moved into a 110' diameter circular tent that seated 400.
In 1991, Georgia Shakespeare expanded to three plays annually, and performed an adaptation of ''[[The Three Musketeers]]'' as its first work not written by [[William Shakespeare]]. In later years, the company has performed between three and seven plays per season.
In 1997, Georgia Shakespeare opened its season in the $5.7 million John A. and Miriam H. Conant Performing Arts Center with ''[[The Tempest]]''. The Conant Center has a 509-seat modified thrust stage and it was this move that allowed the addition of a fall performance to the season schedule.
In 2001, Georgia Shakespeare became a member of the League of Resident Theaters. At the time, it was one of only two theatres in the state of Georgia to be a part of this league.
In 2011, mired in debt, the theatre launched a 'Save Georgia Shakespeare' campaign which was successful in raising over $500,000.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://clatl.com/freshloaf/archives/2011/09/23/georgia-shake-meets-money-goal-wont-shatter-glass |title= Georgia Shake meets money goal, won't shatter 'Glass' |accessdate=July 21, 2015 |work=Creative Loafing |first=Curt |last=Holman |date=September 23, 2011}}</ref>
In 2014, the theatre company closed for good in the middle of its 29th season, unable to stay open due to its high debts.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://artsculture.blog.ajc.com/2014/10/08/stifled-by-debt-georgia-shakespeare-calls-it-curtains-after-29-years |title= Stifled by debt, Georgia Shakespeare calls it curtains after 29 years |accessdate=July 21, 2015 |work=Atlanta Journal-Constitution|first=Howard |last=Pousner |date=October 8, 2014}}</ref>
=== Listing of past productions === 1986 * ''[[The Taming of the Shrew]]'' * ''[[King Lear (play)|King Lear]]'' 1987 * ''[[Much Ado About Nothing]]'' * ''[[Romeo and Juliet (play)|Romeo & Juliet]]'' 1988 * ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' * ''[[The Winter's Tale]]'' 1989 * ''[[Twelfth Night (play)|Twelfth Night]]'' * ''[[The Comedy of Errors]]'' 1990 * ''[[Macbeth (play)|Macbeth]]'' * ''[[As You Like It]]'' 1991 * ''[[The Three Musketeers]]'' * ''[[Richard III (play)|Richard III]]'' * ''[[Two Gentlemen of Verona]]'' 1992 * ''[[Love's Labour's Lost]]'' * ''[[The Tempest (play)|The Tempest]]'' * ''Hamlet: Godfather Of Brooklyn'' 1993 * ''[[Cyrano de Bergerac (play)|Cyrano de Bergerac]]'' * ''SHREW: The Musical'' * ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]'' 1994 * ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' * ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]'' * ''[[The Imaginary Invalid]]'' 1995 * ''Much Ado About Nothing'' * ''[[The Country Wife]]'' * ''Booth, Brother Booth'' * ''[[King Lear (play)|King Lear]]'' 1996 * ''Twelfth Night: A New Musical'' * ''[[The Bourgeois Gentleman]]'' * ''[[Troilus and Cressida]]'' * ''Booth, Brother Booth'' 1997 * ''The Tempest'' * ''[[The School for Scandal]]'' * ''[[Othello (play)|Othello]]'' 1998 * ''[[Henry IV, Part I]]'' * ''[[The Miser]]'' * ''[[Measure for Measure]]'' * ''Macbeth'' 1999 * ''Hamlet'' * ''The Comedy of Errors'' * ''[[Saint Joan (play)|St. Joan]]'' * ''Romeo & Juliet'' * ''SHREW: The Holiday Musical'' 2000 * ''Twelfth Night'' * ''[[Tartuffe]]'' * ''[[Richard II (play)|Richard II]]'' * ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' * Readings: ''[[Epicoene]]'' ([[Ben Jonson]]), ''The Changeling'' ([[Thomas Middleton]]/[[William Rowley]]), ''[[The History of King Lear]]'' (Nathum Tate) 2001 * ''[[Amadeus (play)|Amadeus]]'' * ''As You Like It'' * ''The Winter's Tale'' * ''[[Julius Caesar (play)|Julius Caesar]]'' * Readings: ''The Inland Sea'' ([[Naomi Wallace]]), ''[[Thyestes]]'' ([[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]]), ''[[Mandragola]]'' ([[Machiavelli]]), ''[[A Mad World, My Masters|A Mad World My Masters]]'' (Thomas Middleton), ''[[The Revenger's Tragedy]]'' (Thomas Middleton), ''[[The Widow (play)|The Widow]]'' (Thomas Middleton) 2002 * ''The Two Gentlemen of Verona'' * ''[[Death of a Salesman]]'' * ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]'' * ''The Taming of the Shrew'' * ''[[The Gospel of John]]'' * ''Booth, Brother Booth'' * Readings: ''[[The Tamer Tamed]]'' (Fletcher) 2003 * ''Much Ado About Nothing'' * ''[[The School for Wives]]'' * ''The Tale of Cymbeline'' * ''The Tempest'' 2004 * Shake at the Lake: ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' * ''Cyrano de Bergerac'' * ''[[What the Butler Saw (play)|What the Butler Saw]]'' * ''[[Coriolanus (play)|Coriolanus]]'' * ''Macbeth'' 2005 * Shake at the Lake: ''Macbeth'' * ''The Comedy of Errors'' * ''[[A Streetcar Named Desire (play)|A Streetcar Named Desire]]'' * ''[[The Cherry Orchard]]'' * ''The Gospel of John'' * ''Romeo & Juliet'' 2006 * Shake at the Lake: ''The Comedy of Errors'' * ''Hamlet'' * ''Twelfth Night'' * ''[[Treasure Island]]'' * ''[[Metamorphoses (play)|Metamorphoses]]'' * ''Othello'' 2007 * Shake at the Lake: ''Twelfth Night'' * ''Metamorphoses'' * ''[[The Servant of Two Masters]]'' * ''Pericles'' * ''[[Robin Hood]]'' * ''[[Loot (play)|Loot]]'' * ''Richard III'' 2008 * Shake at the Lake: ''The Servant of Two Masters'' * ''As You Like It'' * ''The Merchant of Venice'' * ''All's Well That Ends Well'' * ''Tom Thumb the Great'' * ''[[Antigone (Sophocles)|Antigone]]'' 2009 * ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' * ''[[Cat on a Hot Tin Roof]]'' * ''[[Titus Andronicus]]'' * ''[[Alice in Wonderland]]'' * ''Julius Caesar'' 2010 * Shake at the Lake: ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' * ''Shrew: The Musical'' * ''[[Love's Labour's Lost]]'' * ''[[King Lear (play)|King Lear]]'' * ''The Legend of the Sword in the Stone'' * ''The Odyssey: a Journey Home'' * ''[[A Christmas Story]]'' * ''The Gospel of John'' * ''Prophets'' 2011 * ''The Tempest'' * ''Antony & Cleopatra'' * ''[[Noises Off]]'' * ''The Jungle Book'' * ''[[The Glass Menagerie]]'' * ''Paul Robeson'' 2012 * Shakespeare in the Park: ''[[The Tempest]]'' * ''Ilyria: A Twelfth Night Musical'' * ''Much Ado About Nothing'' * ''[[The Importance of Being Earnest]]'' * ''The Emperor and the Nightingale'' * ''Macbeth'' 2013 * Shakespeare in the Park: ''Much Ado About Nothing'' * ''Metamorphoses'' * ''Mighty Myths & Legends'' * ''Hamlet'' 2014 (Final Season) * Shakespeare in the Park: ''As You Like It'' * ''One Man, Two Guvnors'' * ''The Frog Prince''
== Education programs == Twelve educational programs were developed in the history of Georgia Shakespeare. These programs included "The High School Tour", a "High School Acting Competition", "Camp Shakespeare", a "High School Conservatory", a "No Fear Shakespeare" training program for educators, after school residencies, school tours, student matinees, classes for professionals, and in-school workshops.
== Picnicking == When Georgia Shakespeare was still performing under a tent, patrons of the theatre started bringing pre-show picnics. This became a tradition and when the Conant Performing Arts Center was built, a covered area with tables and chairs was set aside for picnics. In 2014, the grounds underwent a renovation funded through several Atlanta-area Private Foundations.
==Leadership== *Richard Garner, Producing Artistic Director, 1985-2014 *Jennifer Bauer-Lyons, Managing Director, 2013-2014
==Associate artists== Georgia Shakespeare had a core group of artists who, in 2014, had been with them between six and twenty-nine years and help define the theatre's identity. At the time of closing, <ref>http://gashakespeare.org/associate_artists</ref> those artists were: *Hudson Adams *Janice Akers *Rochelle Barker *Clay Benning *Elisa Carlson *Rob Cleveland *Kat Conley *Tim Conley *Carolyn Cook *Jonathan Davis *Chris Ensweiler *Sabin Epstein *Bruce Evers *Drew Fracher *Neal A. Ghant *Andrew Hartley *Chris Kayser *Megan Kier *Tess Malis Kincaid *Klimchak *Joe Knezevich *Douglas Koertge *Park Krausen *Margo Kuhne *Liz Lee *Scot Mann *Karen Martin Dillard *Daniel Thomas May *Karen S. Martin *Katie McCreary *Tim McDonough *Megan McFarland *Katy Munroe *Allen O'Reilly *Saxon Palmer *Courtney Patterson *Mike Post *Karen Robinson *Robert Schultz *Brad Sherrill *Kendall Simpson *Christine Turbitt
== References == <references />
== External links == [http://library.oglethorpe.edu/MS37-GeorgiaShakespeareFestivalCollection.html Georgia Shakespeare Festival Collection, MS 37, Archives, Philip Weltner Library, Oglethorpe University, Atlanta, Georgia.]

revision.comment: Removing links to current page
revision.text:
[[File:Gnaoua (Gnawa) musicians performing during the 2010 Gnaoua festival in the city of Essaouira, Morocco.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.5|Gnaoua ([[Gnawa]]) musicians performing during the 2010 Gnaoua World Music Festival in the city of [[Essaouira]], Morocco]] The '''Gnaoua World Music Festival''' is a [[Gnawa music]] festival held annually in [[Essaouira]], [[Morocco]].
The festival provides a platform for a meeting point of music and dialogue between foreign artists and the mystical [[Gnaoua]] (also [[Gnawa]]) musicians. In this melting-pot of musical fusion, the [[Gnaoua]] masters invite players of [[jazz]], [[Pop music|pop]], [[Rock music|rock]] and contemporary [[World music]] to explore new avenues. The festivals see up to 500,000 visitors every year over four days; many of the performances can be viewed for free, which complicates comparison with other festivals.<ref>[https://www.cnbc.com/id/42150834/page/21 "The Worlds's Biggest Music Festivals"] [sic], CNBC.</ref>
== Transport ==
The city of Essaouira is located on the Atlantic coast of Morocco, 350 km from Casablanca, 175 km from Marrakech and 190 km from Agadir.
During the weekend of Gnaoua Festival, transportation to Essaouira becomes very rare and expensive, so it is recommended to book your transport as soon as possible if you plan to participate in the event
Below the means of transport available:
By Bus / Coach: Essaouira is served by several bus companies from several Moroccan cities, to book your ticket you can go to the bus station Nevertheless, it is highly recommended to book your coach bus online on the website '' 'marKoub.ma' '' , to avoid any unpleasant experience when buying the ticket:
[http://www.marKoub.ma marKoub.ma]
By train: The Moroccan rail network stops in Marrakech, but there are some bus connections to Essaouira
By plane: The airport is located 18 km from the city and is served by several airlines, including the national airline Royal Air Maroc [http://www.royalairmaroc.com/].
== References == <references />
==External links== *[http://www.map.ma/eng/sections/box3/paris_hosts_photogra/view Paris Holds Exhibition of Moroccan Gnaoua] * {{fr icon}} [http://www.wikimusique.net/index.php?title=Festival_des_Gnaouas&oldid=28567 Gnaoua World Music Festival by the authors of Wiki Musique] *[http://www.maghrebarts.ma/musique/gnaoua.html "Gnaoua & Musique du Monde".]
{{coord|31|30|41|N|9|46|20|W|type:landmark_source:kolossus-frwiki|display=title}}
[[Category:Music festivals in Morocco]] [[Category:World music festivals]]
