The tour would continue during the first half of 2017.<ref name="auto1">{{Cite web|title = Steve Vai: "Modern Primitive" album in 2016 + "Passion And Warfare" 25th anniversary edition and Tour|url = http://www.metallus.it/news/steve-vai-modern-primitive-album-in-2016-passion-and-warfare-25th-anniversary-edition-and-tour/|website = Metallus.it|accessdate = 2015-12-28|language = it-IT|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105123104/http://www.metallus.it/news/steve-vai-modern-primitive-album-in-2016-passion-and-warfare-25th-anniversary-edition-and-tour/|archivedate = January 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
In 2016, Vai played an uncredited guitar solo on the track "[[Go! (M83 song)|Go!]]," from the album "[[Junk (M83 album)|Junk]]" by French electronic band [[M83 (band)|M83]]. In April an May of the same year, Vai took part in the [[Generation Axe]] tour, alongside [[Tosin Abasi]], [[Nuno Bettencourt]], [[Yngwie Malmsteen]], and [[Zakk Wylde]]. Starting in June, Vai embarked on the ''[[Passion and Warfare]]'' 25th Anniversary World Tour, where he played the album in its entirety for the first time.<ref>{{cite web|last1 = Fanelli|first1 = Damian|title = Steve Vai Announces 'Passion and Warfare' 25th Anniversary World Tour|website = Guitar World|url = http://www.guitarworld.com/artist-news/steve-vai-announces-passion-and-warfare-25th-anniversary-world-tour/29004|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160805135745/http://www.guitarworld.com/artist-news/steve-vai-announces-passion-and-warfare-25th-anniversary-world-tour/29004|archivedate = August 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
==Media appearances== ===Video games=== "Juice", from ''Alien Love Secrets'', was featured on the 1996 video game ''[[Formula 1 (video game)|Formula One]]'' for the [[PlayStation]]. Vai's guitar work also appeared in the 2002 video game ''[[Grand Theft Auto: Vice City]]''. David Lee Roth's "[[Yankee Rose (song)|Yankee Rose]]" was featured on ''Vice City'''s soundtrack, as well as "God Blessed Video" by Alcatrazz, as part of the [[Lazlow Jones|Lazlow]]-led, 1980s rock/[[heavy metal music|metal]] radio station "V-Rock." In 2004, Vai was featured on the soundtrack to the [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] video game ''[[Halo 2]]'', performing a heavy rock guitar rendition of the "[[Halo Original Soundtrack|Halo theme]]", known as "Halo Theme (MJOLNIR Mix)". He also performed on the track "Never Surrender". He later featured in the second volume of the soundtrack, where he performed on the track "Reclaimer". Vai returned to re-record his ''Halo'' work for the ''[[Halo: The Master Chief Collection|Halo 2 Anniversary Original Soundtrack]]'', which was released in 2014 and included as part of the anniversary edition of ''Halo 2''.
In 2008, Vai's song "[[For the Love of God (instrumental)|For the Love of God]]" and "Halo Theme (MJOLNIR Mix)" were featured as downloadable tracks for the game ''[[Guitar Hero 3]]''. A live version of "For the Love of God" was also available on the [[Rock Band Network]] service, as well as the song "Get the Hell Out of Here" from his 2002 compilation album ''[[The Elusive Light and Sound, Vol. 1]]'' on March 4, 2010. "The Attitude Song" and a live version of "The Crying Machine" were both also added to the Rock Band Network. A re-recording of "Speeding" is featured in the 2010 video game ''[[Guitar Hero: Warriors of Rock]]'' for [[Xbox 360]], [[Wii]] and [[PlayStation 3]].
===Films=== In 1986, Vai was cast in the [[blockbuster (entertainment)|blockbuster]] film ''[[Crossroads (1986 film)|Crossroads]]'' as the Devil's guitar player "Jack Butler." In the "cutting heads" scene between Vai's Jack Butler and [[Ralph Macchio]]'s Eugene "Lightning" Martone, Vai wrote and performed all guitar parts with the exception of the slide guitar (which was performed by [[Ry Cooder]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url =https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090888/|title =Crossroads (1986)-IMDb|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =|last =|first =|deadurl =no|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160105123103/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090888/|archivedate =January 5, 2016|df =mdy-all}}</ref> The main body of the final piece performed in the duel scene (the fast-paced [[neoclassical metal|neoclassical]] track "Eugene's Trick Bag") was based heavily on [[Niccolò Paganini]]'s [[Caprice No. 5 (Paganini)|Capriccio number 5]]. The ''Crossroads'' duel appeared on the 2002 album ''The Elusive Light and Sound, Vol. 1''.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Album – The Elusive Light And Sound - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/album-the-elusive-light-and-sound/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105123103/http://www.vai.com/album-the-elusive-light-and-sound/|archivedate = January 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
In 1987, Vai performed "Amazing Grace" in the film [[Dudes (film)|''Dudes'']]. In 1991, Vai performed on the film ''[[Bill & Ted's Bogus Journey]]'', as well as on 1992's ''[[Encino Man]],'' ''[[PCU (film)|PCU]]'' (1994), and [[John Carpenter]]'s ''Ghosts of Mars'' (where he played on the tracks "Ghosts of Mars" and "Ghost Poppin'").
In 2010, Vai's record label Favored Nations produced and released the award-winning original motion picture ''Crazy''. An independent film, ''Crazy'' was inspired by the life and music of the guitarist [[Hank Garland]].<ref>{{Cite web|url =https://www.guitar.com/articles/favored-nations-release-crazy|title =Favored Nations- Crazy|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =|last =|first =|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160105170853/https://www.guitar.com/articles/favored-nations-release-crazy|archivedate =January 5, 2016|df =mdy-all}}</ref>
==Style and influence== At the age of thirteen, after having purchased his first guitar and begun taking his first lessons with fellow New York native [[Joe Satriani]], Vai became obsessed with the discipline of practice. Vai's practice routine, consisting of a rigid and structured regiment of ten-to-fifteen hour-a-day practice schedules, became the basis of his work ethic for the rest of his career.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Play Like Steve Vai|url = http://www.guitarplayer.com/artists/1026/10-things-you-gotta-do-to-play-like-steve-vai/21995|website = www.guitarplayer.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151222090709/http://www.guitarplayer.com/artists/1026/10-things-you-gotta-do-to-play-like-steve-vai/21995|archivedate = December 22, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref> During his employment by Frank Zappa, Vai transcribed and played very rhythmically complex music, believing that if started slow and perfected, any piece of music could be played.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Tempo Mental - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/tempo-mental/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151227045132/http://www.vai.com/tempo-mental/|archivedate = December 27, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
Vai's first solo album, ''Flex-able'', began his career as a solo artist in 1984. During the period of time that the album was recorded, Vai was heavily influenced by his previous tenure in Frank Zappa's band.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Album – Flex-Able - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/album-flex-able/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151225151341/http://www.vai.com/album-flex-able/|archivedate = December 25, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref> Originally not intended for release, ''Flex-able'' expressed a certain creative "quirky" and "angular" freedom in the eclectic nature of Vai's writing style.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Flex-Able - Steve Vai {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits {{!}} AllMusic|url = http://www.allmusic.com/album/flex-able-mw0000196197|website = AllMusic|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160124042303/http://www.allmusic.com/album/flex-able-mw0000196197|archivedate = January 24, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref> ''Passion and Warfare'', Vai's second solo album, expressed a more mature and evolved "signature" style but retained a certain freedom of unfettered inspiration that would continue to influence Vai's future releases.<ref name="auto1"/> In speaking of his inspiration, Vai has said that it comes to him in many forms (even from the flowers pushed up against a fence outside of his studio, which he transcribed and used in the ninth track "Weeping China Doll", from ''The Story of Light'').<ref>{{Cite web|title = Vai.com > Naked Tracks > Volumes VI & VII (Naked Tracks)|url = http://www.vai.com/minisites/nakedtracks/nakedtracks_vol67.html|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151028224906/http://www.vai.com/minisites/nakedtracks/nakedtracks_vol67.html|archivedate = October 28, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref> While expressing that he is not continuously inspired, Vai uses a concept he calls "musical meditation" to enter a state of consciousness that he calls "The Ultra Zone".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Part Two - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/part-two/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105123103/http://www.vai.com/part-two/|archivedate = January 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref> When inside this un-critical frame of mind, Vai is able to achieve inspiration in the form of musical ideas (often in forms of melody or rhythm).<ref>{{Cite web|title = Martian Love Secrets - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/martian-love-secrets/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151227045543/http://www.vai.com/martian-love-secrets/|archivedate = December 27, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref> For these moments of inspiration, Vai created what he calls the "Infinity Shelf", a drive of thousands of snippets of song ideas that he has collected over his entire career.<ref name="auto"/><ref>{{Cite web|title = Steve Vai Opens His Vaults for VaiTunes Series|url = http://www.guitarworld.com/steve-vai-opens-his-vaults-vaitunes-series|website = Guitar World|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105103715/http://www.guitarworld.com/steve-vai-opens-his-vaults-vaitunes-series|archivedate = January 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref> These esoteric principles are taught by Vai during his Alien Guitar Secrets masterclasses, among a host of other information.
Vai's playing style utilizes specialized guitar techniques (such as [[tapping#Two-handed tapping|two-handed tapping]], [[alternate picking]], [[legato]], [[hybrid picking]], [[sweep picking]], whammy bar acrobatics, and circular [[finger vibrato|vibrato]]) in his music, as well as a wide range of recording techniques.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 8 Essential Steve Vai Licks|url = http://www.premierguitar.com/articles/8_Essential_Steve_Vai_Licks|website = www.premierguitar.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151222023118/http://www.premierguitar.com/articles/8_Essential_Steve_Vai_Licks|archivedate = December 22, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Guitar Lessons You Can Learn From Steve Vai|url = http://tomhess.net/SteveVaiGuitarLesson.aspx|website = tomhess.net|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105123103/http://tomhess.net/SteveVaiGuitarLesson.aspx|archivedate = January 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
==Notable contributions== ===Work with Frank Zappa=== As a transcriptionist for Frank Zappa, Vai transcribed some of Zappa's most rhythmically complex music, using a range of conceptualizations for the notation of rhythmic music. Vai says "While transcribing the material, I was often confronted with situations that led me to reach into the intuitional areas of my imagination to come up with various notational devices and constructions that I had never seen before. I soon discovered that many contemporary composers were then (and are still) using these notations". These concepts can be seen throughout the "Frank Zappa Guitar Book", which were composed of Vai's guitar and drum transcriptions from various Zappa albums. Vai toured with Zappa from 1980 to 1983, performing selections of this technically demanding music with Zappa's band at the time.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Tempo Mental - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/tempo-mental/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2016-01-08|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105123103/http://www.vai.com/tempo-mental/|archivedate = January 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
===JEM and Universe guitars=== Vai designed the [[Ibanez JEM]] guitar, a unique instrument that incorporated a series of groundbreaking designs that have since become staples in feature throughout the guitar industry, in 1985. In speaking of the development of the guitar, Vai says, "[[Fender Stratocaster|Stratocasters]] had [[Vibrato systems for guitar|whammy bars]]—which were fantastic—but they were very limited, were always going out of tune, and had [[Single coil guitar pickup|single-coil pickups]]. [[Gibson Les Paul|Les Pauls]] had [[humbucker]]s—which gave you that real scream in the bridge position—but no whammy bar, and I didn't like the way they sat. Neither guitar had twenty-four [[fret]]s. So I went to a guitar shop in Hollywood, where I had these elements implemented into a guitar (what would have been considered a [[Superstrat]] at the time). The guitar was designed with a sharper body shape, a large cutaway around the neck, twenty-four frets, a fully floating tremolo system, a specially wired five-way pickup selector switch, and an output jack angled on the side of the body (so that when you step on the cable, it doesn't pull out of your guitar). I knew of course that these features would eventually be taken and used in other guitars, so I did something completely preposterous: I said, 'Put a handle in it!' That way, during videos and photoshoots I could swing the guitar around."<ref name="guitarworld.com"/>
Vai had several custom prototypes of these guitars built (which were used on the ''Eat 'Em and Smile'' tour) by Joe "Jem" Despagni, a custom guitar luthier and friend of Vai's. Due to Vai's highly coveted position in Roth's band, many guitar companies were eager to propose endorsement opportunities. In response to these offers, Vai sent out the specifications of the JEM guitar, detailing that the company that returned the best guitar would be given the endorsement. Dissatisfied with the guitars returned and unwilling to compromise, Vai held out on a guitar endorsement until [[Ibanez]] approached him, sending him an instrument superior to that of the other companies and willing to follow his instructions. After the pre-production prototypes were perfected, the first production Ibanez JEM 777 guitars were unveiled at the [[NAMM Show]] in 1987. Since its original 1987 release, the JEM has become one of the longest-running and most successful signature series guitars in history, with its sister guitar, the [[Ibanez RG]], being the second highest-selling guitar (behind the Fender Stratocaster) on the market.
Another design by Vai was the [[Ibanez Universe]], the first production [[seven-string guitar]], which was released in 1989. The Universe incorporated many of the aspects that made the JEM a unique instrument (24 frets, full floating tremolo, special pickup configuration, angled output jack, and deeper body cutaway), with an added low 'B' string, allowing for new low-range sonic possibilities. Used by Vai on much of ''Passion and Warfare'' and all of Whitesnake's ''Slip of the Tongue'', the Universe was a large stepping stone for the burgeoning [[Nu metal|Nu-metal]] genre (with bands such as [[Korn]] having adopted the instrument and incorporating it into their signature sound).
===Alien Guitar Secrets masterclasses=== Having always enjoyed the aspect of teaching and sharing his experiences in life and in the music business, Vai began a series of "Alien Guitar Secrets" masterclasses in 2006- a touring masterclass in which Vai holds open forum discussion about his own experiences in the music industry, explains the key principles to understanding success, plays to backing tracks (often inviting class attendees to jam with him), answers questions, articulates key points of guitar technique, and more importantly goes beyond the technique and into the more profound esoteric principles at play. Vai details certain concepts he has discovered that have helped him in all areas of his life and career, both in playing guitar/ musically as well as spiritually. Vai accessibly shares these concepts with masterclass participants using examples from his own experiences, delving into the ongoing process of identifying the self-critical nature of one’s own thoughts. Vai explains the techniques and exercises he uses to circumnavigate one’s own insecurities and thoughts of self-doubt, and encourages masterclass participants to use these tools in their own lives. Often embarking on masterclass tours through Europe, South America, and Russia, Vai considers this ongoing series of classes as one of his most important contributions.<ref>{{Cite web|title = - Alien Guitar Secrets|url = http://www.alienguitarsecrets.com|website = www.alienguitarsecrets.com|accessdate = 2016-01-08|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160107105640/http://www.alienguitarsecrets.com/|archivedate = January 7, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Steve Talks about the new DVD and more|url = http://www.vai.com/minisites/wtwta/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2016-01-09|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052241/http://www.vai.com/minisites/wtwta/|archivedate = March 4, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
===Eventide H3000 Ultra-Harmonizer=== Guitar effects manufacturer [[Eventide, Inc|Eventide]] approached Vai in the mid-1980s to contribute unique ideas for their H3000 effects unit. Vai suggested many specific concepts, such as diatonic pitch change and multi-voice harmony, that were used in the unit and have since become standard algorithms in guitar effects processors.<ref>{{Cite web|title = H3000 Factory {{!}} Eventide|url = https://www.eventideaudio.com/products/plugins/pitch-delay-modulation-filtering/h3000-factory|website = www.eventideaudio.com|accessdate = 2016-01-07|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160208063159/https://www.eventideaudio.com/products/plugins/pitch-delay-modulation-filtering/h3000-factory|archivedate = February 8, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
===DiMarzio pickups=== In 1993, Vai's signature series high-output "Evolution" humbucker pickup set was released by DiMarzio. The Evolution pickups use DiMarzio's patented "Dual-Resonance" design.<ref>{{Citation|title = United States Patent: 4501185 - Transducer for stringer musical instrument|url = http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PALL&p=1&u=%252Fnetahtml%252FPTO%252Fsrchnum.htm&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=4501185.PN.&OS=PN/4501185&RS=PN/4501185|accessdate = 2016-01-07|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180501200736/http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PALL&p=1&u=%252Fnetahtml%252FPTO%252Fsrchnum.htm&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=4501185.PN.&OS=PN%2F4501185&RS=PN%2F4501185|archivedate = May 1, 2018|df = mdy-all}}</ref> The "EVO 2" humbucker, a lower output model, was released in 2004.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Evo 2™ Bridge {{!}} DiMarzio|url = http://www.dimarzio.com/pickups/humbuckers/high-power/evo-2-bridge|website = www.dimarzio.com|accessdate = 2016-01-07|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151212174230/http://www.dimarzio.com/pickups/humbuckers/high-power/evo-2-bridge|archivedate = December 12, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
===Carvin Legacy amplifier=== In 1997, Vai had begun working with the [[Carvin Corporation]] to design a signature series of Legacy amplifiers, which were used on his 1999 Epic Records release ''[[The Ultra Zone]]''.<ref name="musicradar.com" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Album – The Ultra Zone - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/album-the-ultra-zone/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-24|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151225042332/http://www.vai.com/album-the-ultra-zone/|archivedate = December 25, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref> The original Legacy I model was released in 1999, with the most recent Legacy III being released in 2012.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|title = Steve Vai Legacy Tube Amplifier Series|url = http://www.carvinaudio.com/collections/steve-vai-legacy-tube-amplifier-series|website = Carvin Audio|accessdate = 2015-12-24|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151225031635/http://www.carvinaudio.com/collections/steve-vai-legacy-tube-amplifier-series|archivedate = December 25, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
===Touring=== In the 1990s, Vai began touring in European and Asian countries (such as Russia and China) as well as South America, often having been the first American rock act in history to have performed in these areas. In 2014, Vai performed on the Chinese television station BTV's ''Spring Festival Global Gala,'' a program broadcast to over two billion viewers. With the broadcasting of this event on January 26, 2014, Vai became the first rock artist ever broadcast on a Chinese television program.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Spring Gala Event 2014, China - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/spring-gala-event-2014-china/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2016-01-07|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052629/http://www.vai.com/spring-gala-event-2014-china/|archivedate = March 4, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = BTV Spring Festival Global Gala 2014 (TV Movie 2014)|url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3501138/|website = IMDb|accessdate = 2016-01-07|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160208063159/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt3501138/|archivedate = February 8, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
==Equipment== [[File:SteveVaiFLO.jpg|thumb|Vai's FLO guitar in 2014]] Vai's personal studio, ''The Harmony Hut'', is a large edifice located in his backyard equipped with a full control room and performance room.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vai.com/Machines/studios.html|title=The Studios|publisher=Vai.com|accessdate=2014-07-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060314233659/http://www.vai.com/Machines/studios.html|archivedate=March 14, 2006|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The studio, built in 2011, is where Vai currently produces, records, and [[audio mixing (recorded music)|mixes]] his new material. Vai has two main signature series Ibanez JEM six-string guitars (dubbed "EVO"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vai.com/wp-content/gallery/ibanez-electric/steve-vai-316.jpg |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160723011401/http://www.vai.com/wp-content/gallery/ibanez-electric/steve-vai-316.jpg |archivedate=July 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and "FLO III"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vai.com/wp-content/gallery/ibanez-electric/steve-vai-319.jpg |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160723011459/http://www.vai.com/wp-content/gallery/ibanez-electric/steve-vai-319.jpg |archivedate=July 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>) that he uses for a majority of his live and studio work. "EVO", a prototype Ibanez JEM 7VWH, was received in 1993 while developing Vai's signature [[DiMarzio]] Evolution pickups (hence the name of the guitar), and "FLO III" is a basswood Ibanez Los Angeles Custom Shop JEM 7VWH equipped with a [[Fernandes Guitars|Fernandes Sustainer]] system and a DiMarzio [[PAF (pickup)|PAF]] Pro pickup in bridge position.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Meet Steve Vai’s Ibanez JEM "Evo" Guitar|url = http://www.guitarworld.com/guitar-gallery-steve-vai-s-ibanez-jem|website = Guitar World|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105123103/http://www.guitarworld.com/guitar-gallery-steve-vai-s-ibanez-jem|archivedate = January 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Vai.com - All About Flo|url = http://www.vai.com/all-about-flo-history/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151227044114/http://www.vai.com/all-about-flo-history/|archivedate = December 27, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
His other favourite guitars include "BO",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vai.com/wp-content/gallery/ibanez-electric/gtr113lrg.jpg |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160723011357/http://www.vai.com/wp-content/gallery/ibanez-electric/gtr113lrg.jpg |archivedate=July 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> a JEM77BRMR prototype, also equipped with Fernandes Sustainer system and blue LED dot inlays, which was stolen in 2015, but recovered after; the original "FLO"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vai.com/wp-content/gallery/ibanez-electric/steve-vai-193.jpg |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160723011223/http://www.vai.com/wp-content/gallery/ibanez-electric/steve-vai-193.jpg |archivedate=July 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> guitar, a transformed original 77FP JEM to 7VWH specifications, also equipped with Fernandes Sustainer System and EVO 2 bridge pickup; and "Bruno" aka "For the Love of God"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vai.com/wp-content/gallery/ibanez-electric/steve-vai-387.jpg |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160723011335/http://www.vai.com/wp-content/gallery/ibanez-electric/steve-vai-387.jpg |archivedate=July 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Ibanez Universe UV77MC seven-string guitar with burnt finish and mirror pickguard (this guitar was used in the ''For the Love of God'' music video). Vai uses his signature Carvin Legacy amplifier, as well as [[Morley Pedals]], with whom he has his signature Bad Horsie and Bad Horsie II wah pedals, and Little Alligator volume pedal.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Morley Pedals - Bad Horsie Wah|url = http://www.morleypedals.com/dvai-1.html|website = www.morleypedals.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052917/http://www.morleypedals.com/dvai-1.html|archivedate = March 4, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Morley Pedals - Steve Vai Little Alligator Volume|url = http://www.morleypedals.com/dpla.html|website = www.morleypedals.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160115203040/http://www.morleypedals.com/dpla.html|archivedate = January 15, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref> Vai uses the Ibanez Jemini distortion pedal, a signature twin distortion pedal with separate overdrive and distortion sections.<ref>{{Cite web|title = REVIEW: Ibanez Jemini Steve Vai signature distortion pedal|url = http://iheartguitarblog.com/2011/04/review-ibanez-jemini-steve-vai-signature-distortion-pedal.html#sthash.I4uyKfdr.dpbs|website = I Heart Guitar|accessdate = 2015-12-28|language = en-US|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105020121/http://iheartguitarblog.com/2011/04/review-ibanez-jemini-steve-vai-signature-distortion-pedal.html#sthash.I4uyKfdr.dpbs|archivedate = January 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
Before his endorsement with Ibanez, Vai was endorsed by [[Charvel]] guitars, most notably using a green and black San Dimas model. In addition, over the course of his career, Vai has used guitars made by various other companies, including [[Jackson Guitars|Jackson]], [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation|Fender]], and Gavtone.
===Guitar rig and signal flow=== Vai's 2016 live guitar rig utilizes his signature Carvin Legacy amplifier (now on its third version), the Fractal Audio Axe-Fx II XL, and an MFC-101 foot controller.
Depending on the location and venue, Vai will use either his Legacy I or Legacy III heads, and Carvin Legacy 4x12 speaker cabinets loaded with Celestion Vintage 30 speakers. Vai uses EL-34 tubes by Groove Tubes in his Legacy amps.
Vai uses the Fractal Audio Axe-Fx II XL as the only modulation effects unit in his guitar rig. Generally for live use he utilizes the unit for stereo effects such as [[delay (audio effect)|delay]], [[chorus effect|chorus]], and [[phaser (effect)|phase]], with a separate preset for the parameters of each different song in his setlist. The Axe-Fx MFC-101 foot controller is set up in conjunction with the unit, allowing Vai to switch effects on and off in a fashion reminiscent to that of standard stompboxes.
Vai's pedalboard consists of a [[wah-wah pedal]] (either his Morley Bad Horsie signature pedal, or a [[Dunlop Cry Baby]] 95q), an Ibanez Jemini twin [[distortion (music)|distortion]] pedal, and [[DigiTech Whammy]] DT pitch shifting pedal. The centerpiece of the pedalboard is the Axe-Fx MFC-101 foot controller for the Axe-Fx II XL, which, as previously mentioned, controls the effects in a manner similar to switching on and off stompboxes. There are two expression pedals used for the Axe-Fx, one to act as a [[expression pedal|volume pedal]], and the other to control the [[pitch shift|harmonizer]] built into the Axe-Fx unit.
The signal from the guitar (usually one of the main guitars "EVO" or "FLO III") goes into either the Morley Bad Horsie or Dunlop 95q wah pedal. From there, it goes directly into the Ibanez Jemini twin distortion pedal, and then to the Digitech Whammy DT. From the output of the Whammy, the signal heads into the input of the Carvin Legacy amplifier head. Out of the effects loop of the Legacy, the signal heads directly into the Axe-Fx II XL, where it is split into stereo and the effects are applied (and controlled via the MFC-101 foot controller). Out of the output of the Axe-Fx, one signal is sent back to the original Legacy head return, and a second is sent to a second Carvin Legacy head return, bypassing the [[preamplifier|preamp]] stage completely and acting as a slave [[audio power amplifier|power amp]]. Vai utilizes his stereo setup on effects like delay, where he sets up two separate delay times (one slower and one faster) and allows them to alternate back and forth. The signal is then sent from the amp to the 4x12 Carvin Legacy speaker cabinets loaded with Celestion Vintage 30 speakers. Vai uses [[AKG Acoustics|AKG]] microphones to mic his amps, and uses a separate Carvin power amp to power a direct guitar monitor cabinet instead of relying on the [[public address system|PA]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Rig Rundown - Steve Vai|url=http://www.premierguitar.com/articles/Rig_Rundown_Steve_Vai|website=Premier Guitar|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150722172306/http://www.premierguitar.com/articles/Rig_Rundown_Steve_Vai|archivedate=July 22, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 1997, Vai began working with the [[Carvin Corporation]] to design a signature series of Legacy amplifiers, which were used on his 1999 album ''[[The Ultra Zone]]''.<ref name="musicradar.com" /><ref name=":3"/> The original Legacy I model was released in 1999, with the most recent Legacy III model being released in 2012.<ref name=":4"/>
Detailed gear diagrams of both Vai's 1999<ref>Cooper, Adam (1999). [http://www.guitargeek.com/steve-vai-guitar-rig-and-gear-setup-1999/ "Steve Vai's 1999 Guitar Rig"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019141526/http://www.guitargeek.com/steve-vai-guitar-rig-and-gear-setup-1999/ |date=October 19, 2013 }}. GuitarGeek.Com.</ref> and 2007 guitar rigs<ref>Cooper, Adam (2007). [http://www.guitargeek.com/steve-vai-guitar-rig-and-gear-setup-2007/ "Steve Vai's 2007 Guitar Rig"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103100327/http://www.guitargeek.com/steve-vai-guitar-rig-and-gear-setup-2007/ |date=November 3, 2013 }}. GuitarGeek.Com.</ref> are well-documented.
==Personal life== [[File:SteveVai 2.jpg|thumb|Vai in 2007]] Since the late 1990s, Vai has resided in [[Encino, Los Angeles]] with his family. Vai is married to [[Pia Maiocco]], former bassist of the band [[Vixen (band)|Vixen]] (who can be seen in the 1984 film ''[[Hardbodies]]''), with whom he has two children, Julian and Fire Vai.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Vaiography - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/vaiography/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-30|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151227031927/http://www.vai.com/vaiography/|archivedate = December 27, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Pia Maiocco|url = https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0583921/|website = IMDb|accessdate = 2015-12-30|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105123103/http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0583921/|archivedate = January 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref> Vai is also a [[vegetarian]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.richardhallebeek.com/interviews/vai.php|first=Richard|last=Hallebeek|authorlink=Richard Hallebeek|title=Interview to Steve Vai|magazine=Guitar Magazine|location=Hilversum, Netherlands|date=May 21, 2004|publicationdate=2005|accessdate=June 26, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617120703/http://www.richardhallebeek.com/interviews/vai.php|archivedate=June 17, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and a [[beekeeper]], regularly tending to the beehives kept on his Encino property.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Update from the hive - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/update-from-the-hive/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-30|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151225151227/http://www.vai.com/update-from-the-hive/|archivedate = December 25, 2015|df = mdy-all}}</ref>
An avid reader of spiritual and religious literature, Vai is also a practitioner of [[meditation]], at times in his life meditating up to two-and-a-half hours per day.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Part Two - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/part-two/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-30|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105123103/http://www.vai.com/part-two/|archivedate = January 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref> Inspired by the teachings of Abraham Hicks, [[Jiddu Krishnamurti]], [[Marianne Williamson]]'s ''[[A Course in Miracles]]'', the teachings of [[Christ]], [[Siddhartha Gautama]], and [[Madame Blavatsky]], Vai cites the teachings of [[Eckhart Tolle]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Interview for Italian Press 2013 - vai.com – The Official Steve Vai Website|url = http://www.vai.com/interview-for-italian-press-2013/|website = www.vai.com|accessdate = 2015-12-30|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105123103/http://www.vai.com/interview-for-italian-press-2013/|archivedate = January 5, 2016|df = mdy-all}}</ref> as "the most powerful pointers that have ever been written regarding the one true spiritual dimension of consciousness and infinite potentiality that is within us all"{{Citation needed|date = January 2016}}.
==Band history== Not including guest appearances.<ref>[http://www.vai.com/AllAboutSteve/bands.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060417211123/http://www.vai.com/AllAboutSteve/bands.html |date=April 17, 2006 }}</ref>
'''Early bands''' * The Ohio Express (1971–1972) * Circus (circa 1973 to 1976) * Ravge (circa 1973 to 1976) * Bold As Love (1977)
'''Berklee bands''' * Axis (1978–1979) * Morning Thunder (1979)
'''Professional bands''' * [[Frank Zappa]] (1980–1982) * The Out Band (Circa 1983) * [[The Classified]] (1984) * 777 (1984) * [[Alcatrazz]] (1984–1986) * [[David Lee Roth]] (1985–1989) * [[Whitesnake]] (1989–1991)
'''Solo band (1992–94)'''
'''''Sex & Religion'' album''' *Vocals: [[Devin Townsend]] *Guitar: Steve Vai *Bass: [[TM Stevens]] *Drums: [[Terry Bozzio]]
'''"Sex & Religion" tour''' *Vocals: [[Devin Townsend]] *Guitar: Steve Vai *Bass: [[Scott Thunes]] *Keys: [[Will Riley]] *Drums: [[Abe Laboriel, Jr.]], then [[Toss Panos]]
'''1995''' *Guitar: Steve Vai *Bass: [[Tony Pimental]], then [[Scott Thunes]] *Keys: [[Will Riley]] *Drums: [[Chris Frazier]] <small>''This band toured Russia twice, South America and the US (opening for Bon Jovi).''</small>
'''1996–99''' * Guitar, Vocals: Steve Vai * Guitar, Vocals and Keys: [[Mike Keneally]] * Fretted & Fretless Bass, Vocals: [[Philip Bynoe]] * Drums: [[Mike Mangini]]
'''2000''' *Guitar, Vocals: Steve Vai *Guitar, Vocals and Keys: [[Mike Keneally]] *Guitar: [[Dave Weiner]] *Fretted & Fretless Bass, Vocals: [[Philip Bynoe]] *Drums: [[Mike Mangini]] *Keyboards (South American Tour): Eric Goldberg *Drums (South American Tour): [[Chris Frazier]]
'''2001–02''' – "The Breed" *Guitar, Vocals: Steve Vai *Bass, Vocals: [[Billy Sheehan]] *Guitar, Vocals and Keys: [[Mike Keneally]], then [[Tony MacAlpine]] *Acoustic & Electric Guitars, Sitar: [[Dave Weiner]] *Drums: [[Virgil Donati]]
'''2003–05''' – "The Breed" *Guitar, Vocals: Steve Vai *Bass, Vocals: [[Billy Sheehan]] *Guitar, Vocals and Keys: [[Tony MacAlpine]] *Acoustic & Electric Guitars, Sitar: [[Dave Weiner]] *Acoustic & Electronic Drums & Percussion: [[Jeremy Colson]]
'''2007''' – "String Theories" *Guitar, Vocals: Steve Vai *Fretted & Fretless Bass: [[Bryan Beller]] ''(Philip Bynoe on the South American leg)'' *Violin and Keys: [[Ann Marie Calhoun]] *Violin and Keys: [[Alex DePue]] *Acoustic & Electric Guitars, Sitar: [[Dave Weiner]] *Acoustic & Electronic Drums & Percussion: [[Jeremy Colson]]
'''2012''' – "The Story of Light Band" *Guitar, Vocals: Steve Vai *Fretted & Fretless Bass, Vocals: [[Philip Bynoe]] *Acoustic & Electric Harp: [[Deborah Henson-Conant]] *Acoustic & Electric Guitars, Sitar: [[Dave Weiner]] *Acoustic & Electronic Drums & Percussion: [[Jeremy Colson]]
'''2013''' – "The Story of Light Band, Australia, New Zealand and Asian Leg" <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaureview.com/interviews/the-au-interview-steve-vai-new-york|title=the AU interview: Steve Vai (New York) - the AU review|website=the AU review|accessdate=July 14, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310174355/http://www.theaureview.com/interviews/the-au-interview-steve-vai-new-york|archivedate=March 10, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *Guitar, Vocals: Steve Vai *Fretted & Fretless Bass, Vocals: [[Philip Bynoe]] *Acoustic & Electric Guitars: [[Dave Weiner]] *Acoustic & Electronic Drums & Percussion: [[Jeremy Colson]] *Keyboards: [[Michael Arrom]]
'''2015''' – "Stillness in Motion: Live DVD Band" <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLSa9fRW4JO9LfTJNrZPfujKnhVfhu_JAl|title=Stillness in Motion - YouTube|website=YouTube|accessdate=July 14, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915011402/https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLSa9fRW4JO9LfTJNrZPfujKnhVfhu_JAl|archivedate=September 15, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *Guitar, Vocals: Steve Vai *Fretted & Fretless Bass, Vocals: [[Philip Bynoe]] *Acoustic & Electric Guitars: [[Dave Weiner]] *Acoustic & Electronic Drums & Percussion: [[Jeremy Colson]] *Sitar: [[Fire Vai]]
==Discography== {{Main article|Steve Vai discography}} Vai started his recording career in 1980 with Frank Zappa, and has since recorded with a plethora of artists and bands. In 1983, Vai began his career as a solo artist with his release of ''Flex-Able'', and solidified his place as a virtuoso rock guitarist with his acclaimed 1990 release of ''Passion and Warfare''. His discography consists of eight studio albums, two [[extended play|EPs]], two special albums, eight live albums, twelve soundtracks, twenty [[compilation album]]s, and six DVD releases.
'''Studio albums:''' *''[[Flex-Able]]'' (1984) *''[[Passion and Warfare]]'' (1990) *''[[Sex & Religion]]'' (1993) *''[[Fire Garden]]'' (1996) *''[[Flex-Able Leftovers (album)|Flex-Able Leftovers]]'' (1998) *''[[The Ultra Zone]]'' (1999) *''[[Real Illusions: Reflections]]'' (2005) *''[[The Story of Light (Steve Vai album)|The Story of Light]]'' (2012) *''Modern Primitive'' (2016)
==Grammy awards== These are the three wins from Vai's 15 solo or collaborative nominations:
*[[36th Annual Grammy Awards|1993]]: Steve Vai - [[Grammy Award for Best Rock Instrumental Performance|Best Rock Instrumental Performance]] for "[[Sofa (Frank Zappa song)|Sofa]]" from ''[[Zappa's Universe]]'' *[[44th Annual Grammy Awards|2002]]: Steve Vai ''et al'' - [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Instrumental Album|Best Pop Instrumental Album]] for ''[[No Substitutions: Live in Osaka]]'' *[[51st Annual Grammy Awards|2008]]: Steve Vai ''et al'' - Best Rock Instrumental Performance for "[[Peaches en Regalia]]" single from a [[Zappa Plays Zappa]] tour
==See also== * [[List of rock instrumentals]] * [[Steve Vai songs]]

revision.text:
{{Underlinked|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox medical condition | name = Sudden unexplained death in childhood | synonyms = | image = | alt = | caption = | pronounce = | field = | ICD10 = <!--{{ICD10|Xxx.x}}--> | ICD9 = <!--{{ICD9|xxx}}--> | ICDO = | OMIM = | DiseasesDB = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeSH = | GeneReviewsNBK = | GeneReviewsName = | Orphanet = }}
'''Sudden unexplained death in childhood''' ('''SUDC''') is the death of a child over the age of 12 months which remains unexplained after a thorough investigation and autopsy. There has not been enough research to identify risk factors, common characteristics, or prevention strategies for SUDC.
SUDC is similar in concept to [[sudden infant death syndrome]] (SIDS). Like SIDS, SUDC is a diagnosis of exclusion, the concrete symptom of both being death. However, SIDS is a diagnosis specifically for infants under the age of 12 months while SUDC is a diagnosis for children 12 months and older. As the causes of both are still unknown, it is not yet possible to determine whether or not they are caused by the same factors.
== Hypotheses ==
Researchers are exploring a possible connection between sudden unexplained death in toddlers, febrile seizures, and hippocampal anomalies.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Holm|first=Ingrid A.|author2=Poduri, Annapurna |author3=Crandall, Laura |author4=Haas, Elisabeth |author5=Grafe, Marjorie R. |author6=Kinney, Hannah C. |author7= Krous, Henry F. |title=Inheritance of Febrile Seizures in Sudden Unexplained Death in Toddlers|journal=Pediatric Neurology|date=1 April 2012|volume=46|issue=4|pages=235–239|doi=10.1016/j.pediatrneurol.2012.02.007|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed?term=holm%20febrile%20seizures%20toddlers|accessdate=27 February 2013|pmid=22490769 |pmc=4009678}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Kinney|first=Hannah C.|author2=Chadwick, Amy E. |author3=Crandall, Laura A. |author4=Grafe, Marjorie |author5=Armstrong, Dawna L. |author6=Kupsky, William J. |author7=Trachtenberg, Felicia L. |author8= Krous, Henry F. |title=Sudden Death, Febrile Seizures, and Hippocampal and Temporal Lobe Maldevelopment in Toddlers: A New Entity|journal=Pediatric and Developmental Pathology|date=1 December 2009|volume=12|issue=6|pages=455–463|doi=10.2350/08-09-0542.1|pmid=19606910|pmc=3286023}}</ref>
== Epidemiology ==
SUDC is rare, with a reported incidence in the United States of 1.2 deaths per 100,000 children, compared to 54 deaths per 100,000 live births for SIDS.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fact Sheet - Sudden Unexplained Death In Childhood (SUDC)|url=http://www.sudc.org/Advocacy/MediaEducation/FactSheet.aspx|accessdate=27 February 2013}}</ref>
SUDC deaths have occurred at the following sites:<ref>{{cite web|title=Sudden Unexplained Death in Childhood|url=http://children.webmd.com/sudden-unexplained-death-in-childhood|accessdate=27 February 2013}}</ref>
* Death at home, history provided: 79% * [[Infant bed|Crib]] or bassinet: 54% * Adult bed: 36%
The placed and found positions were as follows:
* Placed [[supine]], side, prone*: 10%, 2%, 3% * Found [[Prone position|prone]]: 89% * Found face position: down, side: 10%, 8% * [[Co-sleeping]], sweating when found: 3%, 1%
<sub>*applies only to youngest children</sub>
==History== At the SIDS Alliance national convention in Atlanta, GA in 1999 Dr. Henry Krous gave a presentation titled "Post-Infancy SIDS: Is it on the rise?" This led to the beginning of the San Diego SUDC Research Project. The first definition of SUDC was published in 2005 in Pediatric and Developmental Pathology.<ref>{{cite web|title=History - Sudden Unexplained Death in Childhood|url=http://www.sudc.org/AboutUs/History.aspx|accessdate=27 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Krous|first=Henry F.|author2=Chadwick, Amy E. |author3=Crandall, Laura |author4= Nadeau-Manning, Julie M. |title=Sudden Unexpected Death in Childhood:A Report of 50 Cases|journal=Pediatric and Developmental Pathology|date=14 July 2005|volume=8|issue=3|pages=307–319|doi=10.1007/s10024-005-1155-8|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10024-005-1155-8|accessdate=27 February 2013|pmid=16010494}}</ref>
== References ==
{{reflist}}
[[Category:Causes of death]] [[Category:Ailments of unknown cause]] [[Category:Pediatrics]] [[Category:Death of children]]

(2019) | next = [[Super Bowl LIV halftime show|LIV]]
(2020) }} The '''Super Bowl LIII''' Halftime Show (officially known as the '''[[Pepsi]] Super Bowl LIII Halftime Show''') will take place on Sunday February 3, 2019 at [[Mercedes-Benz Stadium]] in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. Though an official announcement has not been made, several publications including ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', and ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' have reported that [[Maroon 5]] will be the headline act as part of [[Super Bowl LIII]], televised nationally on [[NFL on CBS|CBS]] with [[Cardi B]] and [[Travis Scott]] being the rumored guests.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/music/news/maroon-5-to-perform-at-super-bowl-halftime-1202947983/|title=Maroon 5 to Perform at Super Bowl Halftime|last=Halperin|first=Jem Aswad, Shirley|date=2018-09-19|work=Variety|access-date=2018-09-19|language=en-US}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/maroon-5-super-bowl-halftime-show-2019-726376/ |title=Maroon 5 to Play Super Bowl LIII Halftime Show in 2019 |last=Kreps |first=Daniel |date=September 19, 2018 |work=Rolling Stone |accessdate=September 19, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/super-bowl/8478972/behati-prinsloo-maroon-5-super-bowl-report-interview|title=Behati Prinsloo Addresses Maroon 5 Super Bowl Reports On 'WWHL': Watch|first=Nicole|last=Engelman|date=October 9, 2018|work=Billboard|accessdate=October 20, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/19/arts/music/maroon-5-super-bowl-halftime.html|title=Maroon 5 to Headline Super Bowl Halftime Show|first=Joe|last=Coscarelli|date=September 19, 2018|work=The New York Times|accessdate=October 20, 2018}} On Tuesday, November 27th, Israel Colunga created a petition on [[Change.org]] to have the song [[Sweet Victory|''Sweet Victory'']] from the [[Nickelodeon]] show [[SpongeBob SquarePants|''Spongebob Squarepants'']] be played at the 2019 Super Bowl in honor of the show's late creator, [[Stephen Hillenburg|Steven Hillenburg]]. The petition gained over 450,000 signatures in only five days.{{Cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/ustv/news/a871790/spongebob-squarepants-fans-petition-stephen-hillenburg-super-bowl/|title=SpongeBob fans petition for Super Bowl creator tribute|date=2018-12-01|work=Digital Spy|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en}} Producer [[Bob Kulick]], who worked on the song, retweeted the petition on December 1st, 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/BobKulickMusic/status/1069092728703569920|title=Bob Kulick on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en}} ==See also== *[[2019 in American television]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Super Bowl halftime shows}} {{Portal bar|Georgia (U.S. state)|National Football League}} [[Category:2019 in American music]] [[Category:2019 in American television]] [[Category:2019 in sports in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:February 2019 events in the United States]] [[Category:Super Bowl halftime shows|053]] [[Category:Scheduled events]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{dablink| This article is about the 2002 Italian film. "The Bankers of God" redirects here. For the "banker of god", see [[Roberto Calvi]]. For the bank of that banker, see [[Banco Ambrosiano]]. }} {{Infobox film | name =The Bankers of God: The Calvi Affair | image = The-bankers-of-god-the-calvi-affair-movie-poster-2002.jpg | caption = | director = [[Giuseppe Ferrara]] | writer = | starring = [[Omero Antonutti]]
[[Giancarlo Giannini]]
[[Alessandro Gassman]]
[[Rutger Hauer]] | music = [[Pino Donaggio]] | cinematography = Federico Del Zoppo | editing = Adriano Tagliavia | producer = | distributor = | released = 8 March 2002 | runtime = | awards = | country = | language = | budget = }} '''''The Bankers of God: The Calvi Affair''''' ({{lang-it|'''I banchieri di Dio'''}} also known as ''The God's Bankers'') is an [[Italy|Italian]] [[drama film]] directed in 2002 by [[Giuseppe Ferrara]]. == Plot == The film tells the story of the scandal of [[Banco Ambrosiano]], mainly related to the figure of [[Roberto Calvi]]. The [[Clearstream scandal]] exploded as a case full of intricate affairs involving the [[financial]] world, the [[Holy See|Vatican]], the [[Masonic Lodge]] [[P2 lodge|P2]], the [[Secret service|Italian Secret Service]], the [[Secret Intelligence Service]], the Italian [[Political corruption|politics]], [[the Mafia]] and the [[Banda della Magliana]]. The movie narrates in detail all these connections, trying to reconstruct events and plots. The film ends with the death of Calvi under the [[Blackfriars Bridge]], in [[London]], openly supporting the murder-hypothesis. == Cast == * [[Omero Antonutti]]: [[Roberto Calvi]] * [[Giancarlo Giannini]]: [[Flavio Carboni]] * [[Alessandro Gassman]]: [[Francesco Pazienza]] * [[Rutger Hauer]]: Bishop [[Paul Marcinkus]] * [[Pamela Villoresi]]: Clara Calvi * [[Vincenzo Peluso]]: Silvano Vittor * [[Pier Paolo Capponi]]: Roberto Rosone * [[Franco Diogene]]: Luigi Mennini * [[Camillo Milli]]: [[Licio Gelli]] * [[Franco Olivero]]: [[Michele Sindona]] == Production == The film had a very long and troubled gestation. According to the director Giuseppe Ferrara, he started the project in 1986, soon after''[[The Moro Affair]]'', and wanted [[Gian Maria Volontè]] in the main role of [[Roberto Calvi]].{{cite web|title=Calvi, in un film l'Italia dei misteri|url=http://www.centraldocinema.it/Recensioni/16/a/banchieri%20di%20dio.htm|publisher=Central do Cinema|accessdate=24 November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140420022603/http://www.centraldocinema.it/recensioni/16/a/banchieri%20di%20dio.htm|archivedate=20 April 2014|df=dmy-all}} After a final rejection of the project in 1991 by producers [[Silvio Berlusconi]] and [[Vittorio Cecchi Gori]], and with Ferrara's intention of throwing in the towel, the interest of [[Rai Cinema]] finally made the project possible 15 years later, in 2001.{{cite web|last=Giuliano Gallo|title=I misteri del caso Calvi, la mia ossessione|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2002/febbraio/26/misteri_del_caso_Calvi_mia_co_0_0202264716.shtml|publisher=[[Corriere della Sera]]|accessdate=24 November 2011|date=26 February 2002}} == See also == * [[Banco Ambrosiano]] * [[Roberto Calvi]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0212797}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bankers Of God}} [[Category:Italian films]] [[Category:2002 films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:Biographical films about mobsters]] [[Category:2000s business films]] [[Category:Films about the Sicilian Mafia]] [[Category:Films directed by Giuseppe Ferrara]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films set in Vatican City]] [[Category:Political thriller films]] [[Category:Films scored by Pino Donaggio]] {{2000s-Italy-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox television |show_name = The Bee Gees Special |image = |caption = |genre = |writer = [[Stuart Birnbaum]]
[[Kenneth Ehrlich|Ken Ehrlich]] |director = [[Louis J. Horvitz]] |starring = [[Bee Gees|The Bee Gees]]
[[David Frost]]
[[Andy Gibb]]
[[Willie Nelson]]
[[Glen Campbell]] |country = United States |language = English |producer = [[Ken Ehrlich]] |runtime = 90 minutes |channel = [[NBC]] |picture_format = [[4:3]] [[SDTV]] |audio_format = mono |first_aired = {{Start date|1979|11|15}} |followed_by = }} '''''The Bee Gees Special''''' is a 90-minute [[television special]] featuring [[Bee Gees|The Bee Gees]] and broadcast by [[NBC]] on November 15, 1979. The program featured footage from the Bee Gees' July 10, 1979 concert at [[Oracle Arena|Oakland Coliseum Arena]] in [[Oakland, California]] captured by a film crew that accompanied them during their [[Spirits Having Flown Tour]]. It also included footage from an appearance with [[Willie Nelson]] and [[Glen Campbell]], interviews by [[David Frost]] with the Bee Gees and their parents, and a behind-the-scenes look at recording and tour planning with [[Robert Stigwood]] and the band's crew. ==Interviews/Songs== * Interview with David Frost * In the studio rehearsing "[[Tragedy (Bee Gees song)|Tragedy]]" * Opening night of tour - "[[Stayin' Alive]]" * Australian TV clip of "[[Spicks and Specks (song)|Spicks and Specks]]" * Interview with Robert Stigwood * Concert footage: "[[New York Mining Disaster 1941]]", "[[How Can You Mend a Broken Heart]]" * Video montage - "[[How Deep Is Your Love (Bee Gees song)|How Deep Is Your Love]]" * Tour planning * 1967 U.K. TV clip - "[[Massachusetts (Bee Gees song)|Massachusetts]]" * Concert footage: "Wind Of Change" * Creating the explosion for the song "Tragedy" * Concert footage: "[[I Started a Joke]]" * Jam session with Willie Nelson and Glen Campbell: "[[Bye Bye Love (The Everly Brothers song)|Bye Bye Love]]", "[[All I Have to Do Is Dream]]", "[[Party Doll]]", "[[I Can't Stop Loving You]]", "[[To Love Somebody (song)|To Love Somebody]]" * In the studio recording "Tragedy" * Interview with Barbara and Hugh Gibb * Concert footage: "[[Nights on Broadway]]", "[[Words (Bee Gees song)|Words]]", "[[Jive Talkin']]" * Andy Gibb joins his brothers on stage for an extended version "[[You Should Be Dancing]]" * Closing credits over "[[I've Gotta Get a Message to You]]" {{Bee Gees}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bee Gees Special, The}} [[Category:1970s American television specials]] [[Category:Music television specials]] [[Category:NBC television specials]] [[Category:1979 television specials]]

[[German language|German]] intertitles | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Captain from Koepenick''''' (German: '''''Der Hauptmann von Köpenick''''') is a 1926 German [[silent film]] directed by [[Siegfried Dessauer]] and starring [[Hermann Picha]], [[Fritz Kampers]] and [[Gerhard Ritterband]].Kapczynski & Richardson p.150 It is based on the case of [[Wilhelm Voigt]]. The film's sets were designed by the [[art director]] [[Fritz Kraenke]]. ==Cast== * [[Hermann Picha]] * [[Fritz Kampers]] * [[Gerhard Ritterband]] * [[Rosa Valetti]] * [[Hanni Reinwald]] * [[Valeska Stock]] * [[Clementine Plessner]] * [[Henry Bender]] * [[Alice Torning]] * [[Karl Harbacher]] * [[Hugo Fischer-Köppe]] * [[Ellen Plessow]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Jennifer M. Kapczynski & Michael D. Richardson. ''A New History of German Cinema''. ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0244530}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Captain from Koepenick}} [[Category:1926 films]] [[Category:German films]] [[Category:Films of the Weimar Republic]] [[Category:German silent feature films]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films about con artists]] [[Category:Films set in 1906]] [[Category:Films set in Berlin]] [[Category:German black-and-white films]] {{Germany-silent-film-stub}}

{{multiple issues| {{Notability|date=May 2009}} {{Refimprove|date=May 2009}} }}
'''The Great Music Experience''' was a concert starring Japanese and international musicians staged at the eighth century Buddhist temple of [[Tōdai-ji#Cultural references|Tōdai-ji]], in [[Nara, Japan]] in May 1994. The concert, held over three nights (May 20 - May 22) and partly backed by [[UNESCO]], took place in front of the world's largest wooden building, housing the largest Buddha statue in the world.
UNESCO hoped that the event would be the first of seven annual concerts that would take place at some of the world's architectural treasures - the sites it had in mind included the [[Pyramids of Egypt|Pyramids]], China's [[Forbidden City]] and the [[Taj Mahal]] <ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/21/arts/under-buddha-s-gaze-fellowship-harmony-and-rock-and-roll.html |title=Andrew Pollack, "Under Buddha's Gaze, Fellowship, harmony and Rock-and-Roll", ''New York Times'', May 21, 1994 |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1994-05-21 |accessdate=2010-10-15}}</ref> - but nothing came of the idea. A concert earmarked for a Mexican pyramid was called off because of the collapse of the peso.<ref>The Business of Rock, BBC2, August 28, 1996, profiling concert producer Hollingsworth and showing clips of the Tōdai-ji concert.</ref>
==Description== The Tōdai-ji concert brought together Japanese and Western musicians playing music showing the influences of both cultures. The musicians included [[Bob Dylan]], [[Jon Bon Jovi]], [[Joni Mitchell]] and [[INXS]]. Dylan played in front of the Tokyo New Philharmonic orchestra, the first time he had played with an orchestra.
The priests of Tōdai-ji agreed to stage the concert only after talks lasting several months with British producer [[Tony Hollingsworth]]. Shinkai Shindō, the head priest, said that Buddhism aimed to make people happy and that the concert would make the religion more appealing to young people.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> UNESCO said that it would not have gone ahead if it was not convinced that the site would be respected in a physical, cultural and religious sense.
UNESCO hoped that a series of concerts would be able to use the appeal of rock musicians to widen the audience for the world's cultural heritage. The Tōdai-ji concert would also help to promote traditional Japanese music. It was important for traditional musicians to stand on the same stage with Dylan and Bon Jovi.
Hollingsworth said that his aim was to create a "roller coaster of musical cultures", with Japanese and Western artists playing together after a week of rehearsals.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> The final night's concert on May 22 was broadcast to 50 countries but, with a breakdown of equipment, a tape recording of the second night was interwoven with the live concert for some of the time. Two documentaries were also broadcast, showing western artists watching Japanese cultural events and rehearsing with Japanese musicians.
The star of the show turned out to be Dylan who said as soon as he came off-stage that he had not sung so well for 15 years. Dylan opened with ''[[A Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall]]'' which ''Q'' magazine <ref>''Q'' magazine, August 1994, p60</ref> said was "no ordinary version...[he] really opens his lungs and heart and sings, like he's not done for many a year...The only word for it majestic."
Hollingsworth's original idea for the concert was to help overcome western hostility towards Japan caused by the highly successful Japanese economy. The economic bubble, however, had burst by the time the concert took place.
Rights in the event are held by [[Tribute Inspirations|Tribute Inspirations Limited]].
==Artists appearing at the event== * [[Bob Dylan]] * Cara Butler * Hasedera Temple Shomyo * Hiroshi Hori * [[INXS]] * Ishida * [[Jon Bon Jovi]] * [[Joni Mitchell]] * [[Koji Tamaki]] * Leonard Eto and His Drummers * [[Richie Sambora]] * [[Roger Meddows-Taylor|Roger Taylor]] * [[Ry Cooder]] * Ryu Hongjun and Tempyo Gafu * [[Shoukichi Kina]] * [[The Chieftains]] * Tōdai-ji Shōmyō * Tokyo New Philharmonic Orchestra * [[Tomoyasu Hotei]] * [[Toshinori Kondo]] * [[Wayne Shorter]] * [[X Japan]] * [[Yoshiki (musician)|Yoshiki]]
===Backing musicians=== * [[Ray Cooper]] * [[Ed Shearmur]] * [[Jim Keltner]] * [[Phil Palmer]] * [[Pino Palladino]] * [[Wix Wickens]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *The Great Music Experience - https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1055285/ *{{IMDb name|0995629|Tony Hollingsworth}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Great Music Experience}} [[Category:1994 in Japanese music]] [[Category:Concerts]] [[Category:Nara, Nara]] [[Category:Rock music]] [[Category:May 1994 events]]

Qureshi]] | successor =[[Mian Muhammad Azhar|Muhammad Azhar]] | prior_term = | order2 =[[National Security Advisor (Pakistan)|National Security Advisor]] | office2 = | term_start2 =1 March 1976 | term_end2 =4 July 1977 | alongside2 = | monarch2 = | president2 =[[Fazal Ilahi Chaudhry]] | governor_general2 = | primeminister2 =[[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] | chancellor2 = | taoiseach2 = | governor2 = | vicepresident2 = | viceprimeminister2 = | deputy2 = | lieutenant2 = | succeeding2 = | predecessor2 =Ghulam Omar | successor2 =[[Rao Farman Ali]] | constituency2 = | majority2 = | prior_term2 = | order3 =[[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|1st Chief of Army Staff]] | term_start3 =3 March 1972 | term_end3 =1 March 1976 | president3 = | predecessor3 =[[Lieutenant-General|Lt-Gen.]] [[Gul Hassan Khan|Gul Hassan]]
