[[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|Zia-ul-Haq]] | order4 =[[East Pakistan#Governors|Governor of East Pakistan]] | term_start4 = 6 April 1971 | term_end4 = 31 August 1971 | president4 =[[Yahya Khan]] | predecessor4 =Lt-Gen. [[Sahabzada Yaqub Khan|Yaqub Ali Khan]] | successor4 = Dr. [[Abdul Motaleb Malik]] | pronunciation = | birth_name =Tikka Khan | birth_date = {{Birth date |df=yes|1915|02|10}}{{cite sign |title=General Tikka Khan's Headstone |year=2011 |type=Headstone in graveyard |publisher= |location=Army Graveyard, Rawalpindi, Pakistan}} | birth_place = [[Kallar Syedan]], [[Rawalpindi District]], [[Punjab (British India)|Punjab]], [[British Indian Empire|British India]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2002|03|28|1915|02|10}} | death_place =[[Rawalpindi]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], Pakistan | resting_place =[[Westridge, Rawalpindi|Westridge cemetery]] | resting_place_coordinates = | citizenship =[[British_Raj|British India]] {{small|(1915–1947)}}
[[Pakistan]] {{small|(1947–2002)}} | nationality = | party =[[Pakistan Peoples Party]] {{small|(1976–1990)}} | otherparty = | height = | spouse = | partner = | relations = | children = | parents = | mother = | father = | relatives = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | known_for = | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | religion = | awards =[[File:Yellow Crescent, Symbol of Islam.png|15px]] [[Civil decorations of Pakistan|Hilal-i-Quaid-e-Azam]]
[[File:Order of Pakistan.png|25px]] [[Sitara-e-Pakistan]]
[[File:Nishan-e-Imtiaz Ribbon.png|25px]] [[Hilal-i-Imtiaz]] | blank1 = | data1 = | blank2 = | data2 = | blank3 = | data3 = | blank4 = | data4 = | blank5 = | data5 = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | nickname =''Touka'{{cite news|title=Gen. Tikka Khan, 87; 'Butcher of Bengal' Led Pakistani Army|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/mar/30/local/me-passings30.1|accessdate=5 January 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|date=30 March 2002}} | allegiance = | branch ={{army|British India}} {{small|(1935–1947)}}
{{army|PAK}} {{small|(1947–1976)}} | serviceyears =1935–1976 | rank =[[File:OF-9 Pakistan Army.svg|10px]] [[File:US-O10 insignia.svg|30px]][[Four star general|General]] | unit =[[Pakistan Army Regiment of Artillery|2nd Field Regiment]], [[Pakistan Army Regiment of Artillery|Regiment of Artillery]] | commands =[[Evolution of Pakistan Eastern Command plan|Eastern Command]]
[[IV Corps (Pakistan)|IV Corps]]
[[II Corps (Pakistan)|II ''Strike'' Corps]]
[[Structure of the Pakistan Army|8th Infantry Division]], [[Rann of Kutch]]
[[Structure of the Pakistan Army|15th Infantry Division]], [[Sialkot]] | battles =[[World War II]]
[[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965]] * [[Battle of Rann of Kutch]] * [[Battle of Chawinda]] [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971]] * [[Bangladesh Liberation War]] * [[Operation Searchlight]] | mawards =[[File:Hilal-Jurat Ribbon.gif|25px]] [[Hilal-i-Jurat]] (HJ) | military_blank1 =[[Service number]] | military_data1 =[[Pakistan Army|PA]] – 124 | military_blank2 = | military_data2 = | military_blank3 = | military_data3 = | military_blank4 = | military_data4 = | military_blank5 = | military_data5 = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | footnotes = }} [[General officer|General]] '''Tikka Khan''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|'''ٹِکّا خان '''}}}}), (February 1915 – 28 March 2002) {{small|[[Hilal-i-Jurat|HJ]]}}, {{small|[[Sitara-e-Pakistan|S.Pk]]}}, was a [[Four-star rank|four-star]] rank army general in the [[Pakistan Army]] who served as the first [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|chief of army staff]] from 3 March 1972 till retiring on 1 March 1976.{{cite web|title=General Tikka Khan|url=https://www.pakistanarmy.gov.pk/AWPReview/TextContent.aspx?pId=149|website=www.pakistanarmy.gov.pk|publisher=Pakistan Army|accessdate=19 August 2016}} Gaining [[Commission (document)|commission]] as an [[Regiment of Artillery (India)|artillery officer]] in the [[British Indian Army]] to participate in [[World War II]] in 1940, his military career commanded the [[infantry]] [[Division (military)|divisions]] in the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965|war]] with [[India]] in 1965. In 1969, he was posted to command the [[IV Corps (Pakistan)|IV Corps]] while acting as [[martial law administrator]] in [[West Pakistan]] under President [[Yahya Khan]]. In 1971, he took over the command of unified [[Pakistan Eastern Command|Eastern Command]] in [[East Pakistan]] and appointed as [[East Pakistan#Governors|Governor of East Pakistan]] where he oversaw the planning and the military deployments to execute the [[Operation Searchlight|military operations]] to quell the [[Bangladesh Liberation War|liberation war efforts]] by [[Awami League]].{{cite news |author=Hamid Mir |date=26 March 2010 |title=Apology Day for Pakistanis |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=131584 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=25 May 2013}} His tough rhetoric to deal with political enemies earned him the notoriety and a nickname of "''Touka''",{{cite book |last1=Sinha |first1=Siddharth S. |title=SATYA: A Novel |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X6MpCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT115 |publisher=[[Author Solutions|Partridge Publishing]] |page=115 |isbn=978-1-4828-4903-5}}{{self-published source|date=November 2016}}{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/mar/30/local/me-passings30.1|title=Gen. Tikka Khan, 87; 'Butcher of Bengal' Led Pakistani Army |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=30 March 2002 |issn=0458-3035 |access-date=27 March 2016}} and was soon relieved of his command by President Yahya Khan. After commanding the [[II Corps (Pakistan)|II Corps]] in the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|war]] with India in 1971, Tikka Khan was promoted to four-star rank and appointed as the first chief of army staff of the Pakistan Army in 1972. As an army chief, he provided his support to the [[Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program|clandestine nuclear weapons programme]] alongside with [[Ghulam Ishaq Khan]]— a [[bureaucrat]].{{cite web|title=RANDOM THOUGHTS : Unsung Heroes (Part XXII)- By: Dr. A.Q. Khan – South Asian Pulse|url=http://www.sapulse.com/new_comments.php?id=A9732_0_1_0_M|website=www.sapulse.com|publisher=A.Q. Khan memoirs|accessdate=19 August 2016}} Upon retirement from the [[Pakistan Military|military]] in 1976, he was subsequently appointed as [[National Security Advisor (Pakistan)|National Security Advisor]] by Prime Minister [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]], only to removed in 1977 as a result of enforced [[1977 Pakistani coup d'état|martial law]]. In the 1980s, he remained active as a political worker of the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP) and emerged as its leader when appointed as [[Governor of Punjab, Pakistan|Governor]] of [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]] after the [[Pakistani general elections, 1988|general elections]] held in 1988. After Prime Minister [[Benazir Bhutto]] was [[Eighth Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan|dismissed]] by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan in 1990, his tenure was terminated and was succeeded by [[Mian Muhammad Azhar]]. He retired from the [[Politics of Pakistan|politics]] in 1990. He died on 28 March 2002 and was buried with full [[State funeral|military honours]] in [[Westridge, Rawalpindi|Westridge cemetery]] in [[Rawalpindi]], Punjab, Pakistan. == Biography == === Early life and World War II === Tikka Khan was born on 10 February 1915 into a Rajput Punjabi family{{cite book |last1=Burki |first1=Shahid Javed |author-link=Shahid Javed Burki |title=Pakistan Under Bhutto, 1971–1977 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LX6xCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA207 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-1-349-19529-9 |accessdate=19 August 2016}} in Jochha Mamdot village of [[Kahuta Tehsil]], near [[Rawalpindi]], [[British Punjab|Punjab]], [[British Indian Empire]].{{cite book |last1=Tripathi |first1=Salil |year=2016 |title=The Colonel Who Would Not Repent: The Bangladesh War and Its Unquiet Legacy |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bcffCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA127 |publisher=Yale University Press |page=127 |isbn=978-0-300-22102-2}} Tikka Khan never received any university education nor he joined the [[Indian Military Academy]] at [[Dehradun]].{{cite book |last1=Sagar |first1=Krishna Chandra |title=The War of the Twins |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XM5oZYYvEmYC&pg=PA57 |publisher=Northern Book Centre |page=57 |isbn=978-81-7211-082-6 |accessdate=19 August 2016}} After educating in Rawalpindi, he joined the [[Army Cadet College]] in [[Nowgong, Chhatarpur|Nowgong]], Madhya Pradesh in 1933 and joined the [[British Indian Army]] as a [[Non-commissioned officer|NCO]] in 1935; he gained commissioned in the army on 22 December 1940. He participated in [[World War II]] and fought with the 2nd Field Regiment, [[Regiment of Artillery (India)|Regiment of Artillery]] in Libya against the [[Afrika Korps]] led by German Field Marshal [[Erwin Rommel]] in 1940. He was captured by the German troops and held as [[Prisoner of War|POW]] in Libya for more than year. After making his successful escape, he saw military action in [[Burma Campaign 1944–45|Burma front]] against [[Imperial Japan|Japan]] in 1945 where he was wounded and hospitalised for sometime. In 1946, he was posted in different parts of [[India]] such as [[Deolali]], [[Mathura]], and [[Kalyan]] as an army officer. During the same time, he served as an infantry instructor at the Indian Military Academy at Dehradun. His [[British Army|British superiors]] had sneak suspicion that [[Captain (land)|Captain]] Tikka Khan who was in the Academy not by merit but by favouritism.{{cite book|last1=Bhāduṛī|first1=Taruṇakumāra|title=Off the record|publisher=Vikas Pub. House|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3AC2AAAAIAAJ}} At the [[GHQ India (British)|GHQ India]], Tikka Khan was often subjected to jokes by his British officers. === Career in Pakistan === After the [[Partition of India|partition]] that followed the [[Independence of Pakistan|independence]] of [[Pakistan]], Tikka Khan opted for Pakistan and joined the [[Pakistan Army]] as a Major where he was the only [[Regiment of Artillery|artillery officer]] in the Pakistan Army's [[Pakistan Army Regiment of Artillery|Regiment of Artillery]] in 1947. His military career progressed well and got accelerated promotions in the army. In 1949, he was promoted as [[Lieutenant-Colonel]] and commander of his unit. He worked hard to raised the Medium Regiment in the new army and commanded the first post of the artillery regiment. In 1950–54, he was promoted as [[Colonel]] and became the deputy director (Dy Director) at the Regiment of Artillery. In 1955, his promotion was approved for [[one-star rank]] and was promoted as [[Brigadier]] to command the Medium Regiment. In 1962, Tikka Khan was promoted as [[Major-General]] and posted at the [[GHQ (Pakistan Army)|GHQ]] in Rawalpindi. === Between the wars:1965–1971 === {{Main article|Indo-Pakistani war of 1965|Battle of Chawinda|Battle of Rann of Kutch|Indo-Pakistani war of 1971}} In 1965, Major-General Tikka Khan was the [[General officer commanding|GOC]] of the 8th Infantry Division that was positioned in [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], Pakistan. At that time, the 8th Infantry Division was consisted of 51 [[Paratrooper]] [[Brigade]] and 52 Infantry Brigade;{{cite book |last1=Cloughley |first1=Brian |title=A History of the Pakistan Army: Wars and Insurrections |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JE1kCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT84 |publisher=[[Skyhorse Publishing]] |page=84 |isbn=978-1-63144-039-7 |accessdate=19 August 2016}} in April 1965, the 8th Infantry Division intruded into the [[Rann of Kutch]] from Southern Command.{{cite book |last1=Khanna |first1=K. K. |title=Art of Generalship |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uAmqCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA176 |publisher=Vij Books India Pvt Ltd |page=176 |isbn=978-93-82652-93-9}} Hostilities broke out in [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1965|1965]] between India and Pakistan and Tikka Khan's [[Structure of the Pakistan Army|8th Infantry Division]] engaged in the battle with the [[Indian Army]].{{cite book |last1=Bajwa |first1=Farooq |title=From Kutch to Tashkent: The Indo-Pakistan War of 1965 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5a0NAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA71 |publisher=[[Hurst Publishers]] |page=71 |isbn=978-1-84904-230-7 |accessdate=19 August 2016}} He witnessed the [[Battle of Chawinda|tank battle]] in [[Chawinda, Punjab|Chawinda]], Punjab that is remembered as one of the largest tank battles in history since the [[Battle of Kursk]] in World War II.{{cite book |last1=Haskew |first1=Michael E. |title=Tank: 100 Years of the World's Most Important Armored Military Vehicle |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O8JQCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA201 |publisher=Motorbooks International |page=201 |isbn=978-0-7603-4963-2 |accessdate=19 August 2016}} During the 1965 war, Tikka Khan earned reputation as a victor of Rann of Kutch and credited widely by the [[Pakistani press|print media]] over the victories he gained over the Indian Army. He made a bold stand against the Indian Army's encirclement in the Sialkot sector in 1965. In addition, he also led the 15th Infantry Division, also in the 1965 war. After President [[Ayub Khan (President of Pakistan)|Ayub Khan]] handed over the [[Pakistani presidency|presidency]] to his army chief General [[Yahya Khan]] in 1969, Tikka Khan was promoted to [[Three-star rank|three-star]] assignment and made [[Lieutenant-General]] to command the [[IV Corps (Pakistan)|IV Corps]], stationed in [[Lahore]]. He was the [[martial law administrator]] of Punjab under President Yahya Khan who appointed him after replacing with [[Attiqur Rahman]]. His personality was well known in Pakistan as being tough and ruthless. In March 1971, Tikka Khan was sent to [[Dacca]] and left the post to Lt Gen Bahadur Sher in March 1971. == Bangladesh Liberation and 1971 war == === Governorship and 1971 war === {{Main article|1971 Bangladesh genocide|Operation Searchlight|1971 Dhaka University massacre|Indo-Pakistani war of 1971}} The situation was very complex in both [[West Pakistan|West]] and [[East Pakistan]] after the [[Pakistani general election, 1970|general elections]] held in 1970 where the [[Bengali nationalism|Bengali nationalist]] [[Awami League]] won 167 of the 169 seats in East Pakistan, whereas the [[Socialism in Pakistan|leftist-socialist]] [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP) won 81 seats out of 138 in West Pakistan. By constitution, [[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman]] of Awami League was supposed to be the candidate for the post of [[Prime Minister of Pakistan]] but [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] of Pakistan Peoples Party was not ready to accept his role as [[Leader of the Opposition (Pakistan)|Leader of the Opposition]] and refused to sit in the [[National Assembly of Pakistan|National Assembly]] as opposition party. Under pressure by Zulfikar Ali Bhutto and the Pakistan Peoples Party, President Yahya Khan postponed the National Assembly session despite meeting and inviting Awami League to form the government on 7 March. As a reaction, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman addressed the mass rally and called upon the [[Bengali people]] to launch the [[Bangladesh Liberation War|armed liberation movement]] against Pakistan. Responding to this, President Yahya Khan accepted the resignation of Lieutenant-General [[Sahabzada Yaqub Khan|Yaqub Khan]] and appointed Tikka Khan as the governor of East Pakistan. In March 1971, Lieutenant-General Tikka Khan arrived in Dacca took over the governorship of East Pakistan and to command the unified [[Pakistan Eastern Command|Eastern Command]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.thestatesman.com/news/opinion/unfinished-agenda-of-1971/132671.html|title=Unfinished agenda of 1971|website=www.thestatesman.com|access-date=27 March 2016}} He has faced accusations of killing thousands of civilians.{{cite web |url=http://storyofpakistan.com/fall-of-dhaka-1971 |title=Fall of Dhaka 1971 |date=4 June 2002 |website=Story of Pakistan |accessdate=19 August 2016}}{{user-generated source|date=November 2016}}{{Cite news |last=Chowdhury |first=Prabir Barua |date=26 March 2016 |title=A friend in need |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/friend-need-1199776 |newspaper=The Daily Star |access-date=27 March 2016}} He succeeded [[Air Commodore]] [[Mitty Masud]], and assumed the command of [[Evolution of Pakistan Eastern Command plan|Eastern Military High Command]] on 26 March 1971. Acting on the instructions provided by President Yahya Khan's administration, Tikka Khan began preparations of "direct-wise military operation" against the Awami League on the evening of 25 March 1971.{{cite book |last1=Dixit |first1=J. N. |author-link=Jyotindra Nath Dixit |title=India-Pakistan in War and Peace |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mdWCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA169 |publisher=Routledge |page=169 |isbn=978-1-134-40758-3 |accessdate=19 August 2016}} He ordered the arrest of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman and outlawed the Awami League and ordered the [[1971 Dhaka University massacre|attack]] on the [[University of Dhaka]] at midnight.{{cite book |last1=Bhutto |first1=Fatima |author-link=Fatima Bhutto |title=Songs of Blood and Sword: A Daughter's Memoir |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pkstnjPZkuQC&pg=PA100 |publisher=Nation Books |page=100 |isbn=1-56858-712-0 |accessdate=19 August 2016}} Lieutenant-General Tikka Khan was the architect and top planner of [[Operation Searchlight]]. Thousands were killed in this operation, including the academia and members of civil society the country was plunged into a bloody civil war. Tikka Khan followed the classical "[[Seek and destroy]] and [[Infiltration tactics|Infiltration]]" method and captured all radio stations in the East Pakistan at the price of systematic killings of Bengali people. In Pakistan alone, he became to known as "soldier known for his eager use of force"; he also earned the notoriety and was nicknamed as "Butcher of Bengal"{{cite book |last1=Ahmed |first1=Salahuddin |title=Bangladesh: Past and Present |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Szfqq7ruqWgC&pg=PA174 |publisher=APH Publishing |page=174 |isbn=978-81-7648-469-5 |accessdate=19 August 2016}} In West Pakistan, the homegrown criticism grew much farther and Tikka Khan's action was widely disapproved that led to the President Yahya Khan replacing him with the populist civilian [[Form of government|set-up]].{{cite book |last1=Shehabuddin |first1=Elora |title=Reshaping the Holy: Democracy, Development, and Muslim Women in Bangladesh |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ovbVLZ2G6pMC&pg=PA66 |publisher=Columbia University Press |page=66 |isbn=978-0-231-51255-8 |accessdate=19 August 2016}} He was immediately called back to Pakistan, and relinquished the unified Eastern Command to Lieutenant-General [[Amir Abdullah Khan Niazi|Amir Khan Niazi]].{{cite book |last1=Kathpalia |first1=Pran Nath |title=Mission with a Difference: The Exploits of 71 Mountain Brigade |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PZ62tP_5a2AC&pg=PA53 |publisher=Lancer Publishers |page=53 |accessdate=19 August 2016}} He was given the command of [[II Corps (Pakistan)|II Strike Corps]] based on [[Multan]], Punjab.{{cite book |last1=Palit |first1=Maj Gen DK |title=The Lightning Campaign: The Indo-Pakistan War, 1971 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PKvmgfHewHcC&pg=PA83 |publisher=Lancer Publishers |page=83 |isbn=978-1-897829-37-0 |accessdate=19 August 2016}} The II Strike Corps was based on two infantry brigades and an armoured regiment and commanded the II Strike Corps during the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1971|war with]] India in 1971. During the 1971 war, Tikka Khan's II Strike Corps casualties were very high: around ~3,000 soldiers were killed and nearly 50 tanks were destroyed by Indian Army. By the time, the [[Instrument of Surrender (1971)|ceasefire and surrendered]] was called, Tikka Khan had earned notoriety among his men and subordinates. == Chief of Army staff == {{Main article|Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|1970s Baloch Insurgency and Rahimuddin's Provincial Stabilization}} In 1972, President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto had disposed Lieutenant-General [[Gul Hassan Khan|Gul Hassan]] as an army commander over the recommendations by [[Judge Advocate General Branch|Military JAG]].{{cite book |last1=Jaffrelot |first1=Christophe |author-link=Christophe Jaffrelot |title=The Pakistan Paradox: Instability and Resilience |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i5GMCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA226 |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=226 |isbn=978-0-19-023518-5 |accessdate=20 August 2016}} Under a reformed set-up, President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto approved the promotion papers of Tikka Khan to [[Four-star rank|four-star]] rank and appointed him as [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Army Staff]] (COAS) in 1972.{{cite book |last1=Kalia |first1=Ravi |title=Pakistan: From the Rhetoric of Democracy to the Rise of Militancy |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8pUHFgtuwtoC&pg=PA142 |publisher=Routledge |page=142 |isbn=978-0-415-67040-1|accessdate=20 August 2016}} Tikka Khan was highly unpopular choice in [[Military of Pakistan|military circles]] for the chief of army staff because it was felt strongly that he did not have any clue about his new assignment.{{cite book |last1=Abbas |first1=Hassan |author-link=Hassan Abbas (academic) |title=Pakistan's Drift into Extremism: Allah, the Army, and America's War on Terror: Allah, the Army, and America's War on Terror |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N3GsBwAAQBAJ&pg=PT102 |publisher=Routledge |page=102 |isbn=978-1-317-46327-6 |accessdate=20 August 2016}} The promotion was highly political and had political motives as Tikka Khan was known for his loyalty bestowed to President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. In 1972, he supported the [[militarisation]] of [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission]] by supporting [[Munir Ahmad Khan]] to take over its chairmanship and directorship of clandestine [[Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program|atomic bomb programme]].{{cite book |last1=Israeli |first1=Raphael |author-link=Raphael Israeli |title=Years of Upheaval: Axial Changes in Islam Since 1989 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_jX_CQAAQBAJ&pg=PT84 |publisher=Transaction Publishers |page=84 |isbn=978-1-4128-6190-8}} His role was implicated in the [[Hamoodur Rahman Commission]] but the responsibility issues concerning Tikka Khan were [[Classified information|Classified]]. In 1974, he planned out the [[1970s Baloch Insurgency and Rahimuddin's Provincial Stabilization|military operations]] in [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]].{{cite news|url= https://www.thenews.com.pk/archive/print/424827-killings-of-zehris-and-history-of-balochistan’s-plight|title= Killings of Zehris and history of Balochistan’s plight|accessdate=17 April 2013|publisher=The News}} In 1976, he provided his support to [[Ghulam Ishaq Khan]] and Bhutto to expand and support the clandestine programme. In 1976, Tikka Khan was set to retire from the military and send the proposals for his possible eight successors. Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto asked for his opinion on Lieutenant-General [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|Zia-ul-Haq]]'s military career which Tikka Khan did not recommend supporting him as chief of army staff. Tikka Khan reportedly marked to Bhutto as: I thought, he was dull. In any case, he was the most junior of all eight serving [[lieutenant-general]]s."{{cite book |last1=Elliott |first1=John |last2=Imhasly |first2=Bernard |last3=Denyer |first3=Simon |title=Foreign Correspondent: Fifty Years of Reporting South Asia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GlM7e_1dCjoC&pg=PA129 |publisher=Penguin Books India |page=129 |isbn=978-0-670-08204-9|accessdate=20 August 2016}} However, Bhutto by-passed his recommendations and approved Lieutenant-General Zia-ul-Haq to four-star rank and appointed him as army chief. Upon retirement from army, Khan joined the Pakistan Peoples Party and was appointed as [[National Security Advisor (Pakistan)|National Security Advisor]] in Bhutto's cabinet.{{cite news|last1=International|title=Tikka Khan dead|url=http://www.thehindu.com/2002/03/30/stories/2002033001831200.htm|accessdate=20 August 2016|work=www.thehindu.com|publisher=The Hindu 2002|date=29 March 2002}} == Political career == === National security advisor and governor of Punjab === Tikka Khan was appointed and elevated as National Security Advisor in 1976 with a status of federal minister by Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. However, his tenure was short and terminated when the [[1977 Pakistani coup d'état|martial law]] was imposed by army chief General [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq]] in 1977. General Zia ordered the [[Pakistan Army Corps of Military Police|military police]] to arrest both Bhutto and General Tikka Khan and placed them under house arrest.{{Cite web|url=http://nation.com.pk/columns/25-Mar-2016/an-unwell-commando|title=An unwell commando|website=The Nation|access-date=27 March 2016}} Bhutto was executed in 1979, after which General Tikka Khan emerged as one of the leaders of the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP), becoming its [[Secretary General]], during a time when many party stalwarts abandoned it.{{cite book |last1=Burki |first1=Shahid Javed |author-link=Shahid Javed Burki |title=Historical Dictionary of Pakistan |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rk-sBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA544 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |page=544 |isbn=978-1-4422-4148-0 |accessdate=20 August 2016}} In 1980–88, Tikka Khan faced imprisonment numerous times for his political activities until President Zia-ul-Haq [[Death and state funeral of Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|died]] in August 1988 in an aircraft explosion over [[Bahawalpur]]. Despite Tikka's political inclinations, many of Tikka's army protégés such as [[Sawar Khan]], [[Iqbal Khan (general)|Iqbal Khan]] and [[Rahimuddin Khan]] were promoted to four-star rank and remained on deferential terms with him. Tikka Khan participated well in the [[Pakistani general election, 1988|general elections]] held in 1988 from [[Constituencies of Pakistan|Rawalpindi constituency]]. He was appointed as the [[Governor of Punjab, Pakistan|Governor]] of Punjab by Prime Minister [[Benazir Bhutto]] in December 1988. His governorship was terminated by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan after [[Eighth Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan|dismissing the government]] of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto in August 1990, after which he retired from active politics. == Later life and death == [[File:Gen Tikka Khan (Deathstone).jpg|thumb|200px|Tikka Khan's grave at Army graveyard, Rawalpindi]] Tikka Khan retired from politics and lived a very quiet life in Rawalpindi, Punjab. Throughout the 1990s, he battled with his illness and hospitalised in [[Combined Military Hospital Rawalpindi|CMH Rawalpindi]] for several years. He refused many television interviews on the course of [[1971 war of independence|1971 episodes]] and died on 28 March 2002.{{cite news|last1=Singh|first1=Khushwant|title=This Above All|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2002/20020413/windows/above.htm|accessdate=15 October 2016|work=www.tribuneindia.com|agency=Tribune India|publisher=Tribune India, 2002|date=13 April 2002}}{{cite news|last1=Publisher|title=Tikka Khan passes away|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/27758/tikka-khan-passes-away|accessdate=20 August 2016|publisher=Dawn 2002|date=29 March 2002}} He was laid to rest with [[State funeral|military honours]] in the [[Westridge, Rawalpindi|Westridge cemetery]] in Rawalpindi. In his funeral attendance were the [[Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee|Chairman joint chiefs]] [[Aziz Khan (general)|Aziz Khan]], [[Army Chief of Staff (Pakistan)|army chief]], [[Chief of Air Staff (Pakistan)|air chief]], [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|naval chief]] and other senior military and civil officials. Benazir Bhutto paid him a rich tribute in the television and directed a message to Tikka Khan's son, Colonel Khalid Khan, where Benazir Bhutto noted that: "Tikka Khan, who had spent many years campaigning with the General [Tikka Khan]", remembered him as a person who, "rose to the highest offices of this country due to his hard work and respect for the rule of law." == See also == * [[Archer Blood|The Blood telegram]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * Zaheer, Hasan: ''The separation of East Pakistan : The rise and realisation of Bengali Muslim nationalism,'' Oxford University Press, 1994. * Sisson, Richard & Rose, Leo: ''War and secession : Pakistan, India, and the creation of Bangladesh'', University of California Press (Berkeley), 1990. * Matinuddin, General Kamal: ''Tragedy of Errors : East Pakistan Crisis, 1968–1971'', Wajidalis, Lahore, Pakistan, 1994. * Salik, Siddiq: ''Witness to surrender'', Oxford University Press, Karachi, Pakistan, 1977. == External links == * [http://pakistanarmy.gov.pk/AWPReview/TextContent.aspx?pId=149 Official profile at Pakistan Army website] * [http://www.dawn.com/2002/03/29/top12.htm Tikka Khan Passes Away—DAWN] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20010823065553/http://pakistanlink.com/Letters/2001/Mar/30/06.html Article rebutting General A.A.K. Niazi's accusations against General Tikka Khan, by Nasir M. Khan, Pakistan Link, 30 March 2001] * [http://www.dawn.com/2003/09/14/op.htm Article mentioning General Tikka Khan's tenure as Chief of Army Staff (1972–1976), A.R. Siddiqui, Dawn, 14 September 2003.] * [http://www.dawn.com/report/hrc/hrsp3c6.htm Hamood-ur-Rehman Commission Report, The Report of the Commission of Inquiry – 1971 War as Declassified by The Government of Pakistan, Volume-I: Supplementary Report – Top secret, PART III – MILITARY ASPECT, CHAPTER VI.] * [http://www.dawn.com/report/hrc/hrsp5c2.htm Hamood-ur-Rehman Commission Report, The Report of the Commission of Inquiry – 1971 War as Declassified by The Government of Pakistan, Volume-I: Supplementary Report – Top secret, PART IV – SURRENDER IN EAST PAKISTAN, CHAPTER II – Alleged atrocities by the Pakistan Army.] * [http://www.dawn.com/report/hrc/hrmp4c3.htm Hamood-ur-Rehman Commission Report, The Report of the Commission of Inquiry – 1971 War as Declassified by The Government of Pakistan, PART IV – MILITARY ASPECT, Chapter III, The formulation of defence plans.] * [http://www.dawn.com/report/hrc/hrsp5c1.htm Hamood-ur-Rehman Commission Report, The Report of the Commission of Inquiry – 1971 War as Declassified by The Government of Pakistan, Volume-I: Supplementary Report – Top secret, PART IV – SURRENDER IN EAST PAKISTAN, CHAPTER I – The moral aspect.] * [http://www.dawn.com/report/hrc/hrmp5c6.htm Hamood-ur-Rehman Commission Report, The Report of the Commission of Inquiry – 1971 War as Declassified by The Government of Pakistan, PART V: MISCELLANEOUS, CHAPTER VI: Summary and recommendations.] * [http://www.dawn.com/2002/04/05/nat1.htm Amin Fahim pays rich tributes to General Tikka Khan, Dawn, 5 April 2002.] * [http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=story_3-7-2005_pg1_2 General Yahya Khan agreed to withdraw forces, India did not, by Khalid Hasan, Daily Times, 3 July 2005.] {{S-start}} {{S-off}} [[West Pakistan]]|years=1969}} {{s-aft|after=[[Nur Khan]]}} |- {{s-bef|rows=2|before=[[Sahabzada Yaqub Khan]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Martial Law Administrator of Zone B, ([[East Pakistan]]) |years=1971}} {{s-aft|after=[[Amir Abdullah Khan Niazi]]}} |- {{s-ttl|title=Governor of [[East Pakistan]] |years=1971}} {{s-aft|after=[[Abdul Motaleb Malik]]}} {{Succession box| title=[[Governor of Punjab (Pakistan)|Governor of Punjab]]| before=[[Makhdoom Sajjad Hussain Qureshi]]| after=[[Mian Muhammad Azhar]]|years=1988–1990}} |- {{S-mil}} {{s-bef|before=[[Air Commodore|Air Cdre.]] [[Mitty Masud]]}} Shariff]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Lieutenant-General|LGen]] [[Gul Hassan Khan]]|as=Army Commander-in-Chief, Pakistan Army}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Army Staff]] revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Multiple issues| {{update|date=September 2015}} {{refimprove|date=March 2013}} }}
A '''transcontinental flight''' commonly refers to a [[Non-stop flight|non-stop]] passenger flight between an airport in the [[West Coast of the United States]] and an airport in the [[East Coast of the United States]].
==History== The first transcontinental flight across the United States{{clarify|date=March 2013}} was made by [[Calbraith Perry Rodgers]] in an attempt to win the [[Hearst prize]] offered by publisher [[William Randolph Hearst]]. Hearst offered a [[$US]] 50,000 prize to the first aviator to fly coast to coast, in either direction, in less than 30 days from start to finish. Previous attempts by [[James J. Ward]] and [[Henry Atwood]] had been unsuccessful.
Rodgers persuaded [[J. Ogden Armour]], of [[Armour and Company]], to sponsor the flight, and in return he named the plane after Armour's grape soft drink "Vin Fiz". Rodgers left from Sheepshead Bay, New York, on September 17, 1911, at 4:30 pm, carrying the first transcontinental mail pouch. He crossed the Rocky Mountains on November 5, 1911, and landed at Tournament Park in Pasadena, California, at 4:04 pm, in front of a crowd of 20,000 people. He had missed the prize deadline by 19 days. He was accompanied on the ground by a support crew that repaired and rebuilt the plane after each crash landing. The trip required 70 stops.
On December 10, 1911, he flew to Long Beach, California, and symbolically taxied his plane into the Pacific Ocean.
==Timeline== *1911 [[James J. Ward]], failed attempt<ref>{{cite news |title=Flier, Seeking to Reach San Francisco, Lands at Calicoon Late in the Afternoon |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1911/09/15/archives/ward-138-miles-nearer-pacific-flier-seeking-to-reach-san-francisco.html |quote=James J. Ward, who left New York for San Francisco Wednesday, flying for the W.R. Hearst $50,000 prize for a transcontinental flight, reached Callicoon, N.Y., a few miles from here, at 4:35 o'clock this afternoon. He covered 59 1–10 miles in 57 minutes, having left Middletown, N.Y., at 3:38 o'clock. |work=[[New York Times]] |date= September 15, 1911|accessdate=2010-11-25 }}</ref> *1911 [[Henry Atwood]], failed attempt *1911 [[Calbraith Perry Rodgers]] start: September 17, 1911, at 4:30 pm; finish: November 5, 1911 <ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title=C. P. Rodgers' Aero Plunges into Surf at Long Beach. Hundreds See Tragedy. Hero of First Transcontinental Flight Victim of His Own Daring. When Lifted From Wrecked Machine His Neck Is Found to Be Broken. Birdman's Home in Havre de Grace, Maryland. Cousin of Lieut. Rodgers in Navy's Aerial Corps. Victim Author of Theory of 'Etherial Asphyxia.' |quote=[[Long Beach, California]], April 3, 1912. Calbraith P. Rodgers, the first man to cross the American continent in an aeroplane, was killed here almost instantly late today, when his biplane, in which he had been soaring over the ocean, fell from a height of 200 feet and buried him in the wreck. His neck was broken and his body mangled by the engine of his machine. |publisher=[[Washington Post]] |date=April 4, 1912 }}</ref><ref name=pattillo>{{cite book|last1=Pattillo|first1=Donald M.|title=Pushing the Envelope: The American Aircraft Industry|date=February 28, 2001|publisher=[[The University of Michigan Press]]|location=[[Ann Arbor]]|isbn=9780472086719|page=14|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=shwtKbTbEuEC&pg=PA14|accessdate=November 21, 2014}}</ref> *1912 (circa) [[Robert George Fowler]] *1923 First non-stop flight from [[Long Island, New York]] to [[Rockwell Field]], [[San Diego]] by [[John A. Macready|Lt. John Macready]] and [[Oakley G. Kelly|Lt. Oakley Kelly]] in a [[Fokker F.IV|Fokker T-2]]<ref name="NASM Fokker T-2">{{cite web |url=http://airandspace.si.edu/collections/artifact.cfm?object=nasm_A19240003000 |title=Fokker T-2 |work=Collections |publisher=[[National Air and Space Museum]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311234850/http://airandspace.si.edu/collections/artifact.cfm?object=nasm_A19240003000 |archivedate=March 11, 2016 |accessdate=2016-03-11 }}</ref> *1929 The [[Buhl Airsedan]] "Spokane Sun-God" was the first aircraft to make a non-stop US transcontinental round-trip flight on August 15, 1929 ([[Nick Mamer]] and [[Art Walker (aviator)|Art Walker]] flew it from Spokane, Washington, to New York City and back between August 15 and 21, 1929, taking 120 hours 1 minute 40 seconds<ref name="Aerofiles">{{cite web |url=http://www.aerofiles.com/sungod.html |title=The Flight of the Spokane Sun-God |last=Meister |first=Richard L., Jr. |publisher=Aerofiles |date=2000 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160312002106/http://www.aerofiles.com/sungod.html |archivedate=March 12, 2016 |accessdate=2016-03-12 }}</ref>). *1930 [[Frank Hawks#Record breaking flights|Frank Hawks]] flew from San Diego to New York in a towed [[Glider (aircraft)|glider]] leaving San Diego March 30, 1930 and arriving in New York eight days later.<ref name="PM 1930">{{cite news |url=https://books.google.dk/books?id=q-MDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA883 |title=Glider is Towed by Plane Across the Nation |work=[[Popular Mechanics]] |date=1930 |accessdate=2016-03-11 }}</ref> *1933 Transcontinental passenger flights in as little as 20 hours on the [[Boeing 247]].<ref name="Boeing 2003">{{cite web |url=http://www.boeing.com/news/frontiers/archive/2003/may/i_history.html |title=From mail-sack seats to sleeping berths and above-cloud routes |last=Merritt |first=Larry |work=Boeing Frontiers |publisher=[[Boeing]] |date=2003 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160312001750/http://www.boeing.com/news/frontiers/archive/2003/may/i_history.html |archivedate=March 12, 2016 |accessdate=2016-03-12 }}</ref> *1934 First three-stop airline flights (TWA DC-2s) *1946 First one-stop airline flights (United DC-4s and [[TWA]] [[Lockheed Constellation|Constellations]])<ref>{{cite book |last=Proctor |first1=Jon |last2=Machat |first2=Mike |last3=Kodera |first3=Craig |url=https://books.google.dk/books?id=iDegBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA26 |title=From Props to Jets: Commercial Aviation's Transition to the Jet Age 1952–1962 |chapter=The Jet Age Begins, Or Does It? (1949–1952) |location=[[North Branch, Minnesota]] |publisher=[[Specialty Press]] |year=2010 |page=26 |isbn=978-1580071994 |accessdate=2016-03-12 }}</ref> *1953 First sustained nonstop airline flights (TWA may have flown some LA-NY nonstops in 1947) *1957 First transcontinental flight to average supersonic speed. [[John Glenn]] flew from [[Naval Air Station Los Alamitos]], California to [[Floyd Bennett Field]], New York in 3 hours and 23 minutes.<ref name="NASA JG Bio">{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/centers/glenn/about/bios/glennbio.html |title=Biography of John H. Glenn |work=History |publisher=[[NASA]] |date=November 12, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160312004257/https://www.nasa.gov/centers/glenn/about/bios/glennbio.html |archivedate=March 12, 2016 |accessdate=2016-03-12 }}</ref>
==Transcontinental air speed record== In-flight and on-ground time are counted after the earliest flights {{Expand list|date=August 2008}} {| class=wikitable |- ! Year ! Date ! Time ! Direction ! Pilot ! Aircraft ! Notes and reference |- | 1911 || September 17, 1911 || 3 days, 10 hours, 14 minutes || East to West || [[Calbraith Perry Rodgers]] || [[Vin Fiz Flyer]] || The first transcontinental flight. It took fifty days (3 days, 10 hours, 14 minutes actual flying time). Rodgers made it in some seventy hops, flying a Wright biplane which was damaged and repaired so many times en route that nothing remained of the original machine at the finish but the drip pan and the vertical rudder. |- |1919 || October 11, 1919 || 3 days, 3 hours, 5 minutes [http://www.newsobserver.com/543/story/267370.html]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} || East to West || [[Belvin W. Maynard]] || [[DH-4]] || On the first leg of the "Transcontinental Air Race of 1919" which saw 33 planes cross the U.S. with 8 completing the round-trip (out of 67 which began the trip). Nine deaths occurred during what was officially the U.S. Army's "Transcontinental Reliability and Endurance Test" |- |1922 || September 4, 1922 || 21 hours, 19 minutes || East to West || [[Jimmy Doolittle]] || DH-4 || [[Pablo Beach, Florida]], to [[San Diego, California]], with only one refueling stop [https://web.archive.org/web/20070208220946/http://www.centennialofflight.gov/essay/Explorers_Record_Setters_and_Daredevils/doolittle/EX18.htm] |- | 1923 || May 2–3, 1923 || 26 hours, 50 minutes, 38.4 seconds || East to West || Lt [[John A. Macready]] and Lt [[Oakley G. Kelly]] || [[Fokker F.IV|Fokker T-2]] || First nonstop transcontinental flight: Roosevelt Field, Long Island to Rockwell Field, North Island, San Diego. Longest straight-line distance covered nonstop until then<ref>http://www.nasm.si.edu/collections/artifact.cfm?id=A19240003000 NASM site</ref> |- | 1924 || June 23, 1924 || 20 hours, 48 minutes || East to West || [[Russell Maughan]] || [[Curtiss P-1 Hawk]] || First transcontinental flight "during hours of daylight". See also: [[Dawn-to-dusk transcontinental flight across the United States]], [[New York City]] to [[San Francisco]], average speed 128 miles per hour |- | 1929 || February 4, 1929 || 18 hours, 22 minutes || West to East || [[Frank Hawks]] || [[Lockheed Air Express]] || [[Los Angeles]] to New York City with mechanic Oscar Grubb |- | 1929 ||June 27, 1929 || 19 hours, 10 minutes || East to West || Frank Hawks || Lockheed Air Express<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.historynet.com/frank-hawks-the-story-of-the-legendary-speed-flying-king.htm|title=Frank Hawks: The Story of the Legendary Speed Flying King » HistoryNet|accessdate=2009-01-21 {{Verify credibility|date=February 2014}}|publisher= Aviation History|date= }}</ref> || New York City to Los Angeles<ref>Kinert 1967, p. 57</ref> |- | 1929 ||June 28, 1929 || 17 hours, 36 minutes || West to East || Frank Hawks || Lockheed Air Express || Los Angeles to New York City |- | 1929 ||August 15, 1929 || 120 hours, 1 minutes 40 seconds<ref>[http://www.aerofiles.com/sungod.html The Flight of the Buhl Airsedan Spokane Sun-God first airplane to make a non-stop transcontinental round-trip flight]</ref>|| West to East and East to West ||[[Nick Mamer]] and [[Art Walker (aviator)|Art Walker]]|| [[Buhl Airsedan]] "Spokane Sun-God" || First non-stop transcontinental round-trip flight from Spokane, Washington to New York City and back |- | 1930 ||April 20, 1930 || 14 hours, 45 minutes || West to East || [[Charles A. Lindbergh]] || [[Lockheed Model 8 Sirius|Lockheed Sirius]] || Los Angeles to New York City.<ref>[http://airandspace.si.edu/collections/artifact.cfm?id=A19600014000 Lockheed Sirius "Tingmissartoq", Charles A. Lindbergh] National Air and Space Museum</ref> |- | 1930 || May 27, 1930 || 18 hours, 43 minutes || East to West || [[Roscoe Turner]] || Lockheed Air Express || New York City to Los Angeles with 3 passengers.<ref>Kinert 1967, p. 70</ref> |- | 1930 ||Aug 13, 1930 || 12 hours, 25 minutes || West to East || Frank Hawks || [[Travel Air Type R Mystery Ship|Travel Air "Mystery S"]] || Los Angeles to New York City.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aviation-history.com/travelair/mystery.html|title=Travel Air (Model R) "Mystery S" - USA|accessdate=2009-01-21 |publisher= The Aviation History On-Line Museum|date= }}</ref><ref>"Behind the name of Captain Frank M. Hawks, in aviation's record book today is set down the time of 12 hours, 25 minutes, 3 seconds for an eastward transcontinental flight, the fastest ever flown by man over the distance of 2,500 miles." Newark Advocate, [[Newark, Ohio]], August 15, 1930; [[Valley Stream, New York]]; August 14, 1930 ([[Associated Press]])</ref> |- | 1931 ||September 4, 1931 || 11 hours, 16 minutes, 10 seconds || West to East || [[Jimmy Doolittle]] || 1931 [[Laird Super Solution]] || Completed for a bonus prize after winning the inaugural [[Bendix Trophy]] race, Los Angeles to [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]], averaged 217 miles per hour [http://www.airventuremuseum.org/collection/aircraft/Laird%20Super%20Solution%20Replica.asp] |- | 1932 || August 29, 1932 || 10 hours, 19 minutes || West to East || [[Jimmy Haizlip]] || [[Wedell-Williams Model 44]] || Completed after winning the 2nd annual Bendix Trophy race.<ref>Glines 1995, p. 154</ref> |- | 1932 || November 14, 1932 || 12 hours, 33 minutes || East to West || Roscoe Turner || Wedell-Williams Model 44 || New York City to [[Burbank, California]]<ref>Glines 1995, p. 155</ref> |- | 1933 || July 1, 1933 || 11 hours, 30 minutes || East to West || Roscoe Turner || Wedell-Williams Model 44 || New York to Burbank, California<ref>Glines 1995, p. 159</ref> |- | 1933 || September 2, 1934 || 10 hours, 2 minutes, 39 seconds || West to East || Roscoe Turner || Wedell-Williams Model 44 || Burbank, California to New York<ref>Glines 1995, p. 166</ref> |- | 1936 || January 13, 1936 || 9 hours, 27 minutes || West to East || [[Howard Hughes]] ||[[Northrop Gamma]] <ref>{{cite news |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb3101/is_3_54/ai_n29372923/pg_5|title=A visionary ahead of his time: Howard Hughes and the U.S. Air Force—Part I: The Air Corps Design Competition | work= Air Power History |accessdate=2009-01-11 |publisher= CBS Interactive Inc.|year=2007 | first=Thomas | last=Wildenberg}}</ref> || Burbank, California to Newark, New Jersey. Hughes took off from Burbank, California, on January 13, 1936, en route to Newark, New Jersey, and a new cross-country record. He made the flight in 9 hours, 27 minutes, 10 seconds, and bettered Roscoe Turner's previous mark by 36 minutes. [https://web.archive.org/web/20061207022428/http://www.centennialofflight.gov/essay/Explorers_Record_Setters_and_Daredevils/Hughes/EX28.htm] |- | 1937 || January 19, 1937 || 7 hours, 28 minutes, 25 seconds || West to East || Howard Hughes || [[Hughes H-1 Racer]] || nonstop Burbank, California to overhead Newark Airport, New Jersey |- hi | 1939 || February 11, 1939 || 7 hours, ? minutes || West to East || [[Benjamin S. Kelsey]] ||X[[P-38]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,760764,00.html| title=Sleek, Fast and Luckless|accessdate=2009-01-11 |publisher= Time Inc.|date=1939-02-20}}</ref> || 7 hr 43 min [[March Field]], [[California]] to overhead [[Mitchel Field, New York]] including 41 min on ground at Amarillo and Dayton |- | 1945 || January 9, 1945 || 6 hours, 4 minutes || West to East || [[Curtin L. Reinhardt]] || [[C-97 Stratofreighter]] || [[Seattle]] to [[Washington, D.C.]], average speed 0 mph [https://www.lonestarflight.org/najeeb-elias-halaby] |- | 1945 || May 1, 1945 || 5 hours, 40 minutes || West to East || [[Najeeb Halaby]] || [[ ]] || [[Muroc AFB]] to [[Patuxent River NAS]], average speed 000 mph [https://www.lonestarflight.org/najeeb-elias-halaby] |- | 1945 || December 1945 || 5 hours, 17 minutes || West to East || [[Glen Edwards (pilot)|Glen Edwards]] and Lt. Col. Henry E. Warden || [[XB-42 Mixmaster]] || In December 1945, Captain Glen Edwards and Lt. Col. Henry E. Warden set a new transcontinental speed record when they flew the XB-42 from Long Beach, California to Bolling Air Force Base in Washington DC (c. 2,300 miles) and in just 5 hours, 17 minutes, the XB-42 set a speed record of 433.6 mph (697.8 km/h). |- | 1945 || December 1945 || 5 hours, 27 minutes, 8 seconds || West to East || Col C. S. Irvine || [[Boeing B-29 Superfortress|Boeing B-29]] || Burbank, California to overhead Floyd Bennett Field, New York; average 450 miles/hour |- | 1946 || January 26, 1946 || 4 hours, 13 minutes, 26 seconds || West to East || Col W. H. Councill || [[Lockheed P-80 Shooting Star|Lockheed P-80]] || Long Beach, California to overhead La Guardia Airport, New York; nonstop, unrefuelled |- | 1949 || February 8, 1949 || 3 hours, 46 minutes ||West to East || || [[B-47 Stratojet]] || Larson AFB, Moses Lake, Washington to Andrews AFB near Washington DC, 607.8 mph average [https://web.archive.org/web/20070203203000/http://www.boeing.com/history/chronology/chron07.html] |- | 1954 || January 2, 1954 || 4 hours, 8 minutes, 5 seconds || West to East || Col Willard Millikan || [[North American F-86 Sabre|North American F-86F]] || Los Angeles LAX to overhead New York Floyd Bennett; time includes stop for fuel at Offutt AFB |- | 1954 || March 30, 1954 || 4 hours, 24 minutes, 17 seconds || West to East || Joe DeBona || [[North American P-51 Mustang|North American P-51C]] || Los Angeles LAX nonstop to New York Idlewild—still the prop record (560 mph) |- | 1955 || March 9, 1955 || 3 hours, 46 minutes, 33.6 seconds || West to East || Lt Col Robert Scott || [[Republic F-84 Thunderjet|Republic F-84F]] || Los Angeles LAX to overhead New York Floyd Bennett; two aerial refuelings |- | 1957 || March 23, 1957 || 3 hours, 39 minutes, 24 seconds || West to East || || Douglas A3D? || Burbank CA to overhead Miami MCAS, FL |- | 1957 || May 19, 1957 || 3 hours, 38 minutes || West to East || || [[North American F-100 Super Sabre|N American F-100F]] || Palmdale CA to McGuire AFB, NJ |- |1957 || July 16, 1957 || 3 hours, 23 minutes, 8.4 seconds || West to East || [[Major]] [[John Glenn|John H. Glenn, Jr.]], [[United States Marine Corps|USMC]]|| [[F-8 Crusader|Vought F8U-1P Crusader]] || "Project Bullet" non-stop from [[Los Alamitos Army Airfield|NAS Los Alamitos, California]] to Floyd Bennett Field, New York at an average of [[Mach number|Mach]] 1.1, despite three [[Aerial refueling|refuelings]] from AJ tankers during which speed dropped below 300 mph. Glenn's on-board [[Aerial reconnaissance|reconnaissance]] camera recorded the first continuous [[Panoramic photography|panoramic photograph]] of the United States. |- |1957 || November 27, 1957 || 3 hours, 7 minutes || West to East || [[Lieutenant]] Gustav Klatt<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=1866 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-06-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503120108/http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=1866 |archivedate=May 3, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>|| [[F-101 Voodoo]] || "Operation Sun Run" with 4 RF-101Cs each refuelled four times by KC-135s; Ontario, California to overhead Floyd Bennett Field, New York, 781.7 mph West to East leg, 721.8 mph roundtrip average [https://web.archive.org/web/20070206050047/http://www.boeing.com/history/chronology/chron09.html][http://www.globalsecurity.org/intell/systems/rf-101.htm] |- | 1961 || May 24, 1961 || 2 hours, 47 minutes, 18 seconds || West to East || || [[McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II|McDonnell F4H]] || Ontario, California to overhead Floyd Bennett Field, New York; three aerial refuellings |- |1962 || March 5, 1962 || 2 hours, 1 minute, 39 seconds || West to East ||Robert G. Sowers || [[Convair B-58 Hustler|Convair B-58]] || overhead Los Angeles to overhead New York; one aerial refuelling |- |1990 || March 6, 1990 || 64 minutes || West to East || Ed {{sic|hide=y|Yielding}} and Joseph T. Vida || [[SR-71 Blackbird]] || Flying to museum at retirement of the aircraft, Los Angeles to Virginia's coast, average speed 2,124 mph (3,418 km/h)[http://www.sr-71.org/blackbird/records.php] |- | 2003 || November 5, 2003 || 3 hours, 55 minutes, 12 seconds || East to West || Mike Bannister and Les Broadie || [[Concorde]] G-BOAG || Flying to museum at retirement of the aircraft, New York to Seattle [http://www.museumofflight.org/aircraft/concorde] [http://www.seattlepi.com/local/article/Thousands-welcome-Concorde-to-Seattle-1128999.php] |- |}
==Junior transcontinental air speed record== For the junior record only in-flight time is counted at a certain speed
{| class=wikitable |- ! Year ! Date ! Time ! Pilot ! Aircraft ! Reference |- | 1928 || || || [[Richard James (aviator)]] || [[Travel Air]] || Previous "record" of 48 hours, set last year by 18-year-old Richard James, was spread over a month elapsed time.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,752559,00.html] |- | 1930 || October 4, 1930 || East to West in 23 hours, 47 minutes || [[Robert Nietzel Buck]] || [[Pitcairn Mailwing|Pitcairn PA-6 Mailwing]] || On October 4, 1930 Robert beat the junior transcontinental air speed record of Eddie August Schneider in his PA-6 Pitcairn Mailwing he named "Yankee Clipper". His time was 23 hours, 47 minutes of elapsed flying time. Robert said on February 6, 2005: "I was the youngest to fly coast to coast and that record still stands. I had my license at 16 and after that, they raised the minimum age to 17. With that change, no one could break my record." |- | 1930 || August 18, 1930 || East to West in 29 hours, 55 minutes || [[Eddie August Schneider]] || [[Cessna]] || Leaving from [[Westfield, New Jersey]] on August 14, 1930 to [[Los Angeles, California]] in 4 days with a combined flying time of 29 hours and 55 minutes. He lowered the East to West record by 4 hours and 22 minutes. He then made the return trip from Los Angeles to [[Roosevelt Field, New York]] in 27 hours, 19 minutes, lowering the West to East record by 1 hour and 36 minutes. His total elapsed time for the round trip was 57 hours, 14 minutes. |- | 1930 || || East to West in 32 hours ? minutes || [[Frank Goldsborough]] || || Combined East to West and West to East in 62 hours and 58 minutes. [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,752559,00.html] |- |}
==Women's transcontinental air speed record== For the women's record, only in-flight time is counted {| class=wikitable |- ! Year ! Pilot ! Time |- |1930 || [[Ruth Nichols]] || 13 hours, 21 minutes |- |1933 || [[Amelia Earhart]] || 13 hours, 7 minutes, 30 seconds |- |1934 || [[Laura Ingalls (aviator)|Laura Ingalls]] || 10 hours, 5 minutes |- |}
==See also== *[[World record]] *[[Dawn-to-dusk transcontinental flight across the United States]] *[[Flight altitude record]] *[[Transcontinental railroad]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *Glines, Carroll V. 1995. ''Roscoe Turner; Aviation's Master Showman''. Smithsonian Institution Press {{ISBN|1-56098-798-7}} *Kinert, Reed. 1967. ''Racing Planes and Air Races: A Complete History'', Vol.2 1924-1931. Aero Publishers Inc ASIN B000J40KCU
{{extreme motion}}

revision.comment: rm [[List of blood sports]] as I've now redirected the article to [[Blood sport]]
revision.text:
{{coord|51.4971|-0.1333|display=title|region:GB_scale:2000}} [[File:Jacco3.JPG|right|thumb|250px|''The Westminster-Pit: A Turn-up between a Dog and [[Jacco Macacco]], the Fighting Monkey'', by [[Henry Thomas Alken]]]] [[File:Rat Killing Dog.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Billy, the celebrated rat-killing dog, circa 1823. Artist unknown.]] The '''Westminster Pit''' was a well-known [[blood sport]] arena in nineteenth-century [[London]], [[England]]. It reached a zenith of popularity between 1820 and 1830, and hosted such spectacles as [[dog-fighting]], [[cock-fighting]], [[bear-baiting]], [[badger-baiting]], [[monkey-baiting]], and [[rat-baiting]]. A legal enterprise at the time, the Westminster Pit openly declared its activities,<ref name=Lennox /> ushering notoriety on the district in which it existed.
The Westminster Pit was located on Duck Lane, Orchard Street (since renamed St. Matthew's Street), and its dimensions were approximately {{convert|20|ft}} by {{convert|18|ft}}.<ref name=Lennox>{{cite book|title=Pictures of sporting life and character, Volume 1|author=W. P. Lennox|page=164|publisher=Hurst|year=1860}}</ref> The gallery was {{convert|3|ft}} above the arena and was capable of containing 200 people – or, by report of [[William Pitt Lennox]], "perhaps a greater number of less refractory persons, for the common run of spectators were so obstreperous and so agitated by various emotions, according to the amount of bets depending, and the various turns of the conflict, that a decent orderly person would feel himself much incommoded by a considerably less number."<ref name=Lennox />
Prior to the beginning of matches, the stakes would be formalised and the dogs weighed. It was common in the Westminster Pit (and other venues like it) for cheating to occur, often by way of covering a dog with substances – such as acid or pepper – that would deter his opponent from biting him. For this reason, it was compulsory that all combatants be washed in water or milk, and a participant was permitted to lick his opponent's dog as a precaution.<ref>{{cite book|title=The book of the dog|author=B. S. Vesey-FitzGerald|publisher=Nicholson & Watson|year=1948|pages=917–18|chapter=Staffords and Baiting Sports, by Phil Drabble}}</ref>
Perhaps the most famous dog to perform in the Westminster Pit was a [[Bull and Terrier]] named "Billy", whose fame was his rat-baiting ability. The October 1822 edition of ''[[The Sporting Magazine]]'' describes his feat of killing 100 rats in six minutes and twenty-five seconds: almost six minutes faster than what was wagered. Billy's best time ever is recorded as five minutes, or slightly over "by a very few seconds".<ref>{{cite book|title=London labour and the London poor|author=H. Mayhew|publisher=Griffin, Bohn, and Company|year=1861|page=56}}</ref> The name of Billy's owner is not consistently documented: some sources refer to a Charles Dew,<ref>{{cite book|page=96|title= Sporting magazine: or, monthly calendar of the transactions of the turf, the chase and every other diversion interesting to the man of pleasure, enterprize, and spirit, Volume 13|publisher=Rogerson & Tuxford|year=1824}}</ref> some to Charley Westropp,<ref>{{cite book|title=Noctes Ambrosianae, Volume 5|editor=R. S. Mackenzie|publisher=Redfield|year=1854|page=288}}</ref> and others to Charley Aistrop.<ref name=Egan>{{cite book|title=Pierce Egan's book of sports, and mirror of life: embracing the turf, the chase, the ring, and the stage: interspersed with original memoirs of sporting men, etc|author=P. Egan|publisher=T.T. Tegg and J. Tegg|year=1832|page=21}}</ref> [[Pierce Egan]] gives Billy's date of death as 23 February 1829.<ref name=Egan /> Later commentators have questioned the legitimacy of Billy's success; in particular, James Rodwell, in his 1858 ''The rat: its history & destructive character: With numerous anecdotes'', stated: "let it be borne in mind, and I assert it on the testimony of living witnesses, that numbers of the rats were dead before the dog commenced, and that the whole had been poisoned with [[Nux vomica (herbalism)|nux-vomica]] before being put into the pit . . . and when he did commence, several were thrown out as dead that were able to crawl away".<ref>{{cite book|title=The rat: its history & destructive character: With numerous anecdotes|author=J. Rodwell|publisher=G. Routledge & Co.|year=1858|pages=233–34}}</ref>
In 1830, an indictment was lodged against the Westminster Pit by the [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals|Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]]. The Society charged the proprietor, John King, with a [[nuisance]], while noting that it was "indebted to corporal Denny, of No. 17, Queen Square, Westminster, and to James Yewen, of No. 6, Horseferry Road, Westminster . . . for obtaining a sufficient number of witnesses, residing on the spot, to prove the case as a nuisance."<ref>{{cite book|title=Voice of humanity: for the communication and discussion of all subjects relative to the conduct of man towards the inferior animal creation, Volume 1|author=Association for Promoting Rational Humanity towards the Animal Creation|publisher=J. Nisbet|year=1830|page=24}}</ref> King was convicted, and, according to ''The Cottager's monthly visitor'', "the prosecution completely suppressed that notorious sink of cruelty and vice".<ref>{{cite book|title=The Cottager's monthly visitor, Volume 29|publisher=Francis & John Rivington|year=1842|page=272}}</ref>
== References == <references/>
[[Category:Baiting (blood sport)]] [[Category:Blood sports]] [[Category:Sports venues in London]]

page.title: World War I Victory Medal (United States)

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: April of 1919 → April 1919, Army’s → Army's (2)
revision.text:
{{Other uses|Victory Medal (disambiguation){{!}}Victory Medal}} {{Use American English|date=November 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox military award | name = World War I Victory Medal | image = US-Victory-Medal-Cobh-Museum.JPG{{!}}border | awarded_by = the [[United States]] | type = Medal | eligibility = Military personnel only | for = "service between April 6, 1917, and November 11, 1918, or with either of the following [[Expeditionary warfare|expedition]]s: *[[American Expeditionary Force, North Russia|American Expeditionary Forces in European Russia]] between November 12, 1918, and August 5, 1919. *[[American Expeditionary Force, Siberia|American Expeditionary Forces Siberia]] between November 23, 1918, and April 1, 1920." | status = Obsolete | description = A [[medal]] of [[bronze]] 36 millimeters in diameter. On the [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] is a winged [[Victoria (mythology)|Victory]] standing full length and full face. On the reverse is the inscription ''The Great War for Civilization'' and the [[Great Seal of the United States|coat of arms for the United States]] surmounted by a [[fasces]], and on either side the names of the [[Allies of World War I|Allied and Associated Nations]]. The medal is suspended by a [[Ring (jewellery)|ring]] from a [[silk]] [[Moire (fabric)|moire]] [[ribbon]] 1 3/8 inches in length and 36 millimeters in width, composed of two [[rainbow]]s placed in [[juxtaposition]] and having the red in the middle, with a white thread along each edge. | motto = ''The Great War for Civilization'' | established = {{start date and age|1919}} | higher = [[Mexican Border Service Medal]] | lower = [[Army of Occupation of Germany Medal]] | image2 = [[File:World War I Victory Medal ribbon.svg|124px|border]]

[[File:Streamer WWI V.PNG|230px]] | caption2 = [[Service ribbon]] and [[campaign streamer]] }} The '''World War I Victory Medal''' (originally known as the '''Victory Medal''') was a [[United States]] [[World War I]] [[service medal]] designed by [[James Earle Fraser (sculptor)|James Earle Fraser]].{{cite web |url=http://www.tioh.hqda.pentagon.mil/Catalog/Heraldry.aspx?HeraldryId=15283&CategoryId=4&grp=4&menu=Decorations%20and%20Medals&ps=24&p=0 |title=World War I Victory Medal |publisher=The Institute of Heraldry: Office of the Administrative Assistant to the Secretary of the ARMY |accessdate=2014-01-05}} Award of a common [[Allies of World War I|allied]] service medal was recommended by an inter-allied committee in March 1919.The Type I Victory Medal 1914-19. Richard Flory. Orders & Medals Research Society Journal, September 2009, page 145 Each allied nation would design a 'Victory Medal' for award to their military personnel, all issues having certain common features, including a winged figure of [[Nike (mythology)|victory]] on the obverse and the same ribbon.{{Cite book|author=Joslin, Litherland and Simpkin.|title=British Battles and Medals.|pages=230-1. Published Spink, London. 1988}} The Victory Medal was originally intended to be established by an [[Act of Congress|act of Congress]]. The [[Bill (law)|bill]] authorizing the medal never passed, however, thus leaving the military departments to establish it through [[General order|general orders]]. The [[United States Department of War|War Department]] published orders in April 1919, and the [[Department of the Navy|Navy]] in June of the same year.{{cite web|url= http://www.history.navy.mil/medals/ww1vic.htm|title= World War I Victory Medal|publisher= Naval History and Heritage Command|accessdate=2014-02-09}} ==Criteria== The Victory Medal was awarded to military personnel for service between April 6, 1917, and November 11, 1918, or with either of the following expeditions: *[[American Expeditionary Force, North Russia|American Expeditionary Forces in European Russia]] between November 12, 1918, and August 5, 1919. *[[American Expeditionary Force, Siberia|American Expeditionary Forces Siberia]] between November 23, 1918, and April 1, 1920.[http://edocket.access.gpo.gov/cfr_2008/julqtr/32cfr578.54.htm 578.54 World War I Victory Medal] ==Design== The front of the bronze medal features a [[Victoria (mythology)|winged Victory]] holding a shield and sword on the front. The back of the bronze medal features "The Great War For Civilization" in all capital letters curved along the top of the medal. Curved along the bottom of the back of the medal are six stars, three on either side of the center column of seven staffs wrapped in a cord. The top of the staff has a round ball on top and is winged on the side. The staff is on top of a shield that says "U" on the left side of the staff and "S" on the right side of the staff. On left side of the staff it lists one [[Allies of World War I|World War I Allied]] country per line: [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Serbia]], [[Japan]], [[Montenegro]], [[Russia]], and [[Greece]]. On the right side of the staff the Allied country names read: [[United Kingdom|Great Britain]], [[Belgium]], [[Brazil]], [[Portugal]], [[Romania|Rumania]] (spelled with a U instead of an O as it is spelled now), and [[Republic of China (1912–49)|China]]. ==Devices== To denote battle participation and campaign credit, the World War I Victory Medal was authorized with a large variety of devices to denote specific accomplishments. In order of seniority, the devices authorized to the World War I Victory Medal were as follows: ===Citation Star=== The [[Citation Star]] to the World War I Victory Medal was authorized by the United States Congress on February 4, 1919. [http://www.tioh.hqda.pentagon.mil/Catalog/Heraldry.aspx?HeraldryId=15241&CategoryId=3&grp=4&menu=Decorations%20and%20Medals&ps=24&p=0 Institute of Heraldry, ''Silver Star''; ''Citation Star''] A {{frac|3|16}} inch silver star was authorized to be worn on the ribbon of the Victory Medal for any member of the U.S. Army who had been cited for gallantry in action between 1917 and 1920. In 1932, the Citation Star ("Silver Star") was redesigned and renamed the [[Silver Star Medal]] and, upon application to the [[United States War Department]], any holder of the Silver Star Citation could have it converted to a Silver Star medal. ===Navy Commendation Star=== The [[Navy Commendation Star]] to the World War I Victory Medal was authorized to any person who had been commended by the Secretary of the Navy for performance of duty during the First World War. A {{frac|3|16}} inch silver star was worn on the World War I Victory Medal, identical in appearance to the Army's Citation Star. Unlike the Army's version, however, the Navy Commendation Star could not be upgraded to the Silver Star medal.Navy and Marine Corps Awards Manual, NAVPERS 15,790 Rev. 1953. ===Army Battle Clasps=== The following [[Campaign clasp|battle clasps]], inscribed with a battle's name, were worn on the medal to denote participation in major ground conflicts. {| class="toccolours" style="width:100%; clear:both; margin:1.5em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="7" style="background:darkGrey;"| Army Battle Clasps |- style="background:#c5d2ea; text-align:center;" | Major Ground Conflict | Start Date | End Date |- style="text-align:left;" | [[United States campaigns in World War I#Aisne May 27 – June 5, 1918|Aisne]] | May 27, 1918 | June 5, 1918 |- align=left | [[Second Battle of the Marne|Aisne-Marne]] | July 18, 1918 | August 6, 1918 |- align=left | [[United States campaigns in World War I#Cambrai, November 20 – December 4, 1917|Cambrai]] | May 12, 1917 | December 4, 1917 |- align=left | [[Second Battle of the Marne|Champagne-Marne]] | July 15, 1918 | July 18, 1918 |- align=left | [[Battle of the Lys (1918)|Lys]] | April 9, 1918 | April 27, 1918 |- align=left | [[Meuse-Argonne Offensive|Meuse-Argonne]] | September 26, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[United States campaigns in World War I#Montdidier-Noyon, June 9 – June 13, 1918|Montdidier-Noyon]] | June 9, 1918 | June 13, 1918 |- align=left | [[United States campaigns in World War I#Oise-Aisne, August 18 – November 11, 1918|Oise-Aisne]] | August 18, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[Battle of Saint-Mihiel|St. Mihiel]] | September 12, 1918 | September 16, 1918 |- align=left | [[United States campaigns in World War I#Somme Defensive, March 21 – 6 April 1918|Somme-Defensive]] | March 21, 1918 | April 6, 1918 |- align=left | [[United States campaigns in World War I#Somme Offensive, August 8 – November 11, 1918|Somme-Offensive]] | August 8, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[United States campaigns in World War I#Vittorio Veneto, October 24 – November 4, 1918|Vittorio-Veneto]] | October 24, 1918 | November 4, 1918 |- align=left | [[United States campaigns in World War I#Ypres-Lys 19 August – November 11, 1918|Ypres-Lys]] | August 19, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |} For general defense service, not involving a specific battle, the "Defensive Sector" Battle Clasp was authorized. The clasp was also awarded for any battle which was not already recognized by its own battle clasp. The World War I Victory Medal bears the clasps of the battles the U.S. Army participated in across the ribbon. Not all battles are shown on the bar clasps. Only the battles designated as battles that would have bars issued were shown on the medal. The famous [[Battle of Chateau Thierry (1918)|Battle of Chateau Thierry]] to hold the Chateau and the bridge as a joint effort between the US Army and the US Marines against the German machine gunners did not get awarded clasps. ===Navy Battle Clasps=== Navy battle clasps were issued for naval service in support of Army operations and had identical names to the Army battle clasps. There was a slight variation of the criteria dates for the Navy battle clasps, as listed below. {| class="toccolours" style="width:100%; clear:both; margin:1.5em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="7" style="background:darkGrey;"| Navy Battle Clasps |- style="background:#c5d2ea; text-align:center;" | Major Ground Conflict | Start Date | End Date |- style="text-align:left;" | Aisne | June 1, 1918 | June 5, 1918 |- align=left | Aisne-Marne | July 18, 1918 | July 20, 1918 |- align=left | Meuse-Argonne | September 29, 1918 | October 10, 1918 |- align=left | Meuse-Argonne | October 25, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | St. Mihiel | September 12, 1918 | September 16, 1918 |- align=left | Ypres-Lys (Service in support of the Northern Bombing Group) | | |} The Defensive Sector Clasp was also authorized for Navy personnel who had participated in naval combat but were not authorized a particular battle clasp.[[File:'Defensive Sector' clasp.jpg|right|thumb|Defensive Sector Clasp on Ribbon]] ===Navy Operational Clasps=== For sea-related war duty, the Navy issued the following [[Campaign clasp|operational clasps]], which were worn on the World War I Victory Medal and inscribed with the name of the duty type which had been performed: {| class="toccolours" style="width:100%; clear:both; margin:1.5em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="7" style="background:darkGrey;"| Navy Operational Clasps |- style="background:#c5d2ea; text-align:center;" | Operation | Start Date | End Date |- style="text-align:left;" | Armed Guard: Merchant personnel(freighters, tankers, and troop ship) | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | Asiatic: Service on any vessel that visited a Siberian port | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | Asiatic: Port visit must have exceeded ten days in length | November 12, 1918 | March 30, 1920 |- align=left | [[United States Fleet Forces Command|Atlantic Fleet]]: Service in the Atlantic Fleet | May 25, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[Aviation]]: Service involving flying over the Atlantic Ocean | May 25, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[Destroyer]]: Service on destroyers on the Atlantic Ocean | May 25, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[Escort destroyer|Escort]]: Personnel regularly attached to escort vessels on the North Atlantic | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | Grand Fleet: Personnel assigned to any ship of the “United States Grand Fleet” | December 9, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[Naval mine|Mine]] Laying: Service in mine laying sea duty | May 26, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | Mine Sweeping: Service in mine sweeping sea duty | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | Mobile Base: Service on tenders and repair vessels | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | Naval Battery: Service as a member of a naval battery detachment | July 10, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | Overseas: Service on shore in allied or enemy countries of Europe | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[Patrol]]: War patrol service on the Atlantic Ocean | May 25, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[Marine salvage|Salvage]]: Salvage duty performed on the seas | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[Submarine]]: Submarine duty performed on the Atlantic Ocean | May 25,1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | Submarine Chaser: Anti-submarine duty performed on the Atlantic Ocean | May 18, 1918 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[Transport]]: Personnel regularly attached to a transport or cargo vessel | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[White Sea]]: Service on any vessel which visited a Russian port or war patrols in the White Sea not less than ten days | November 12, 1918 | July 31, 1919 |} Unlike the army, the navy only allowed one clasp of any type to be worn on the ribbon. Members of the marine or medical corps who served in France but was not eligible for a battle clasp would receive a bronze [[Maltese cross]] on their ribbons. ===Army Service Clasps=== For non-combat service with the army during the First World War, the following [[Campaign clasp|service clasps]] were authorized to be worn with the World War I Victory Medal. Each service claps was inscribed with a country or region name where support service was performed. The U.S. Army issued the following service clasps: {| class="toccolours" style="width:100%; clear:both; margin:1.5em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="7" style="background:darkGrey;"| Army Service Clasps |- style="background:#c5d2ea; text-align:center;" | Country or Region | Start Date | End Date |- style="text-align:left;" | [[England]] | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[France]] | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[Italy]] | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | [[Siberia]] | November 23, 1918 | April 1, 1920 |- align=left | [[European Russia|Russia]] | November 12, 1918 | August 5, 1919 |} ===Navy Service Clasps=== The U.S. Navy issued similar service clasps to the Army for service in the following regions during the following periods: {| class="toccolours" style="width:100%; clear:both; margin:1.5em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="7" style="background:darkGrey;"| Navy Service Clasps |- style="background:#c5d2ea; text-align:center;" | Region | Start Date | End Date |- style="text-align:left;" | England | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | France | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | Italy | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |- align=left | Russia | November 12, 1918 | July 31, 1919 |- align=left | Siberia | November 12, 1918 | March 30, 1920 |- align=left |[[West Indies]] | April 6, 1917 | November 11, 1918 |} ===Campaign Stars=== Since battle and service clasps could only be worn on the full-sized World War I Victory Medal, 3/16 inch bronze [[service stars]] were authorized for wear on the award ribbon. This was the common method of campaign and battle display when wearing the World War I Victory Medal as a ribbon on a military uniform.[[File:Maltese Cross device.jpg|right|thumb|Maltese Cross device on U.S. WWI Victory Medal]] ===Maltese Cross=== Medals issued to [[U.S. Marines]] were issued with a [[Maltese cross]] device affixed to the ribbon. ==Distribution== The World War I Victory Medals were awarded after the end of World War I, so they were mailed to the servicemen instead of awarded in person. For example, the boxes containing the Victory Medals for [[United States Army]] World War I veterans were mailed out by the depot officer at the General Supply Depot, U.S. Army, in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], in April 1921. An outer light brown box with an address label glued to it and its postage area marked "OFFICIAL BUSINESS, Penalty for private use $300" contained an inner white box stamped with the bars the serviceman was supposed to receive on his medal. The inner white box contained the medal, which was wrapped in [[tissue paper]].
Only after filling out the application form A.G.O. No. 740 with the help of an authorized officer could it be officially forwarded to the Philadelphia Quartermaster Intermediate Depot for the veteran then to receive his medal by mail. The Army started issuing Victory Medals on June 21, 1920, not April 1921 as listed above. The Navy had a late start due to production issues and started in August 1920.World War I, Victory Medals, By James P Michels Jr, Createspace/Amazon.com, 2014, page 29. ==Name change== In 1945, the "Victory Ribbon" was created as an award for those who served in [[World War II]]. Between 1945 and 1947, the World War I award continued to be known by its original name, the "Victory Medal", and the World War II award was known as the "Victory Ribbon". In 1947, the Victory Ribbon became a full-sized medal as the [[World War II Victory Medal]], at which point the World War I Victory Medal adopted its current name. However, some military records as late as the 1950s continued to annotate the World War I decoration by its previous name, and the medal was often referred to as "Victory Medal (WWI)". ==An international award== Not only did the United States issue a Victory Medal, but so did a significant number of Allied and associated countries involved in the conflict against the Dual Alliance between Austria and Germany. The proposition of such a common award was first made by French Maréchal [[Ferdinand Foch]] who was supreme commander of the Allied Forces during the First World War. Each medal in bronze has the same diameter (36 mm) and ribbon (double rainbow), but with a national design representing a winged victory.Except Japan and Siam where the concept of a winged victory was not culturally relevant. ''The Interallied Victory Medals of World War I'' by Alexander J. Laslo, Dorado Publishing, Albuquerque. 1986 edition. {| class="wikitable" border="3" |- | '''Country''' | '''Designer''' | '''Manufacturer''' | '''Number issued''' |- | [[Inter-Allied Victory Medal 1914–1918 (Belgium)|Belgium]] | [[Paul Du Bois]] (1859–1938) | — | 300,000–350,000 |- | Brazil | [[:fr:Jorge Soubre|Jorge Soubre (1890–1934)]] | *[[Casa da Moeda do Brasil|Casa da Moeda]] Rio | approximately 2,500 |- | Cuba | Charles Charles | *Etablissements Chobillon | 6,000–7,000 |- | Czechoslovakia | [[:cs:Otakar Španiel|Otakar Španiel (1881–1955)]] | *Kremnice Mint | approximately 89,500 |- | [[Médaille Interalliée 1914–1918|France]] | [[:fr:Pierre-Alexandre Morlon|Pierre-Alexandre Morlon (1878–1951)]] | *Monnaie de Paris | approximately 2,000,000 |- | France Unofficial. Canale | approximately 200,000 |- | [[Allied Victory Medal (Italy)|Italy]] | [[:it:Gaetano Orsolini|Gaetano Orsolini (1884–1954)]] | *Sacchini-Milano *S. Johnson-Milano *F. M. Lorioli & Castelli-Milano | approximately 2,000,000 |- | JapanOn the obverse the winged figure of Victory was replaced by a warrior holding a spear. The medal shows a clearly visible “MK” ( Mint Kremnica). The medal may possibly be an unofficial strike by a veteran’s group. ''The Interallied Victory Medals of World War I'' by Alexander J.
